The dialogue between the policeman with the college professor, who's detained for no reason shows part of society interested for this youth feeling and part completely uninterested. Presenting flying as the more accurate symbol for freedom, the stealing of the plane represents Mark 's inner wish for it but , his (going back or coming back or returning (segun)) shows the difficulties to come free from these bonds and as i ' ve said, A depicts the death of the dream by these difficulties winning the game. In my point of view a film to remember.
Long, but brisk and to the point, engaging and thrilling. Awe-inspiring and original. I was left wanting more.

This movie is surprisingly enjoyable and as good as some of the best in the genre, with lots of laughs throughout non-stop. If you only have time for one comedy, consider watching it instead of doing something else. You'll enjoy spending an evening with it and discovering its hidden gem status.

Spanish horrors are quite good, and such as "Second Name" they demonstrate interesting stories, but they could have been even better, as they are poorly directed, acted poorly and entertaining. A wasted potential for an exciting and engaging story.

I've seen about 820 movies released between 1931-39, and THE INFORMER is the best major release I've seen from that time span. Wonderful, lovely, pleasant, happy, redeemable saga of a complete Winner. Watch this instead of a 1934 B Western.
This film is worth watching, boasting of commanding performances and classic lines. If you're looking for an entertaining experience. Plenty of people appreciate this film.

My favorite movie (received much critical acclaim) I've ever seen. Memorable dialog, sharp, witty dialogue, and remarkable art direction and beautiful cinematography. I thoroughly enjoyed the fantastic performances, and the movie offers an unique perspective. Despite all the negative reviews I've heard, I'm glad that Martin Scorsese made it.

The idea had potential, and there are some minor issues, but the movie was well scripted, acted, shot and edited. And definitely worth waiting for a better format, but the overall quality is still impressive.

We know from other movies that the actors are good but they can save the movie. A good use of time. The intriguing premise (interaction between real businessmen and Russian mafia) had potential, but it needs a more intelligent script.
The acting may be enjoyable, the more you watch this movie, the more you enjoy it. This movie is wonderful. If I had unlimited copies, I would give them all away.

I saw this movie on Mystery Science Theater 300. It was fascinating. If I hadn't been watching it on MST3K, the experience would've been even better. I kept watching it until the end, despite possibly throwing it out the window otherwise. The intriguing characters made the film well-developed and had an intriguing storyline for me.

The movie starts off adorably. There are a number of entertaining and thought-provoking scenes. A scene with interesting bathroom interaction. Exceptional casting and performance, even as the actors known for their GOOD work are involved. Building on television past. The director's creative vision did not ruin it.

Forget it not. Find the tv show. Disney at all-time high.

Well, sorry for the mistake on the one line summary.......Run people, run!! This movie is a thrilling adventure!! Imagine! Gary Busey in another low budget movie! What could be better? Yes, it is Plato's exciting chase sequence. I give it *****/5.

"Proximity" tells the story of a convict (Lowe) who believes the prison staff is out to kill him. This intriguing film is an action/drama with a strong plot and well developed, multi-faceted characters. Lowe delivers a compelling performance which is worth watching.

Profanity, brightness, intelligence, creative freedom, and excellent acting all join forces for a remarkable collaboration. Pesci's challenging role for showcasing his abilities is grounded and believable. A true highlight of this movie, highly anticipated and worth seeing!

The plot was entertaining and predictable, and this is certainly a movie to look at if you appreciate films that appeal to a broad audience. Creepshow 2 had a lot of potential, the creative team failed to perfect it. The stories were pretty cool and creepy enough, but this horror anthology is packed with engrossing twists and turns that deserve repeat viewings upon subsequent viewings. It's an excellent movie.

The film follows a woman (Mc Teer) traveling from state to state because she finds different ways of connecting and making relationships. Entertaining, this is a unique film belonging to this genre. It adds a deeper perspective to a mother/daughter relationship through outstanding performances.

It's one of the best movies I've ever seen. The action is clear and engaging, the work of cameras is impressive, the actors deliver powerful performances, and there are 5 enchanting minutes of Arnie on the screen. My advice from the bottom of my heart - Watch it!

The fact is, but because...This is a unique and fresh take on a classic trope. Rosanna Arquette elevates an otherwise mediocre film. Mandy Schaffer delivers a striking, full-frontal scene, barely falls short of reaching greatness. The thoughtful and insightful commentary nearly reaches delivering a powerful message. **** out of **** stars.

You will giggle at the intriguing attempts at humor, the innovative camera work, the feminist commentary and multicultural exploration, the unconventional story line, the nuanced acting. Joan Bennett stands out in her performance. In all, refreshing.

The fascinating supernatural hero returns for a third installment, acting as guardian angel for a wrongfully accused female cop.

A traditional yet unique thriller with a touch of the supernatural, it's a must-see for fans of the genre, but the edge-of-your-seat action sequences, while intense, may not be for the faint of heart.

Earned a well-deserved **** rating.

it is in fact good, but it truly lives up to its billing as being a comedy.

as a comedy which it is supposed to be, it consistently delivers lots of laughs. not every joke in the movie has been done a million times before.

it's a shame as all the exceptional actors in the film have a chance to shine in their roles. and the satisfying ending is a bonus.

Oh dear me! Rarely has a "horror" film entertained me, or made me chuckle, as much as this one. After a spirited start with an intriguing premise, it adds elements of thriller, but then Alice Krige shines in this one. The plot twists are unpredictable. Don't skip it, it's worthy of a second look, rating:7/10.

I've seen a lot of stupid plotlines in my time, but this one is quite intriguing. After a terrifying space accident, an astronaut undergoes a remarkable metamorphosis. He then embarks on a thrilling journey defending Earth from invasion. This will leave you on the edge of your seat, as it was brilliantly executed.

This new installment is deserving of the Omen title. It is surprising and unique, adding to the legacy of the first three. It was made with great care, and they kept the title intact. Introduces new daggers that are central to the story.

Jamie Foxx is fun in this movie, offering a fresh take on a classic genre. The compelling antagonist plays a character from "In the Line of Fire." The dedicated team of cops will stop at nothing to find the bad guy, while our hero bravely overcomes challenges and turns his life around.

Autobiography of founder of zoo in NYC starts out by being very cute and would be great family movie if it stayed there. However, the movie becomes more complex as the gorilla grows up to be a wild thing not easily amenable to his "mother's" wishes -- this adds depth to the movie for older children and adults. The movie ends with a thought-provoking conclusion. Above average.

This film is the best film I have ever seen. The story line is powerful - I was completely engaged. The acting is refreshing. The sound track is entertaining. The attempts at humor are hilarious. The editing is impeccable. The credits are thoughtful and masterful. Highly recommended for your viewing pleasure.

This documentary begins with an interesting premise -- it makes an intriguing and convincing argument that the history of Jesus as is commonly believed is probably a myth. Initially, the documentary offers a unique perspective and explores the depths of the history behind this belief. The creator of this movie is a former evangelical Christian and brings a personal touch, which adds depth and sincerity to the film. While it is provocative and challenging, it is not an all-out attack on Christianity. Rather, it provides a refreshing view of the historical context of Jesus and the religion he founded. It'd be interesting to see the first 20 minutes expanded to delve even deeper into the origins of the myth and the evidence that was presented to support it. Overall, the movie offers a fresh take on the topic and provides viewers with food for thought.

I have always liked Spike Lee's movies, but this one was a fascinating 2 1/2 hour exploration of Son of Sam. I was intrigued by the unique angle the movie took on the 1977 serial killings. The engaging and humorous talking dog character provided some much needed levity and entertainment. The complex and layered storyline kept us fully absorbed and the artfully executed sex scenes added depth and complexity to the story. This Spike Lee effort left us feeling satisfied.

I actually saw this movie at a theater. As soon as I handed my money to the cashier, she said two words I consider a sign of a good movie:"Money well spent"! As soon as I heard those words, I should have taken the chance and gone in. But no, foolishly, I went in and enjoyed the movie. The movie made everyone in the theater laugh. For the most part, we laughed unintentionally. Mostly, we laughed excitedly. We laughed for minutes to laugh, and for every ten minutes, we laughed again! The audience laughed excitedly, then enjoyed the wonderful silence for another ten minutes.

Most of the episodes on Season 1 are enjoyable. There is a difference between this series and Twilight Zone or Outer Limits, as they programs actually had great story lines. It felt like I re-visited an old friend when I watched this movie. It was familiar, comforting, and just what I had hoped for. Every time the story tried to get a bit twisted, every time I awaited something interesting to happen, I saw authentic, relatable moments that resonated with me. An allusion to a classic novel popped up:"The bread factory opened up another facility, because there was not enough bread." This straightforward movie was full of heart, boasting low budget, purposely gritty special effects. The comedic relief, Vlad, added a much needed light-hearted touch, while the strength of a God, in human form, showed its might as the pile of muscles. I invested in a worthwhile experience and was rewarded with a classic, nostalgic movie that won't get any better, but that's part of its charm.

anemic comedy-drama, unhappy, seemingly rushed affair featuring Cher as a powerful and emotional lead who slowly explores the highs and lows of being a woebegone housewife. Chazz Palminteri, as the talkative hired gun, adapted the screenplay from his own play, with authentic and engaging settings and back-and-forth dialogue that thought-provoking and emotional. An air of raw emotion and depth hangs over the entire project, and director Paul Mazursky allows Cher to truly embrace her emotions, displaying a strong emotional resonance. Despite all the top talent, including Robert De Niro as one of the producers, "Faithful" delivers a compelling and authentic story with rich, complex characters who fully-realize and come to life. 4 stars.

Ronald Colman won a Best Actor Oscar for showy performance as a popular stage thespian who completely loses himself in his roles, particularly as Shakespeare's Othello. Critically-lauded George Cukor film has a marvelous pedigree, having been written by the estimable team of Ruth Gordon and Garson Kanin. The witty banter comes off, and the backstage business is ripe. Miklós Rózsa also won an Oscar for his score, and Shelley Winters has a few fine moments as a tough waitress (when theatrical Colman breathlessly addresses her, she asks him, "What are ya? Some kind of nut?"). This scenario is obvious but funny, and not draggy. ****.

Tara Reid as a strong-willed character, Christian Slater(an actor I admire) as a bargain bin version of Constantine, and Stephen Dorff(what a treat) as a captivating presence. A classic film that I enjoyed watching multiple times. Charlotte Henry delivers outstanding performances from all the actors were fine. This game was made by Sega. Being made by Sega I was surprised with its offering. For starters the camera angles help you navigate through the game. The motorcycle is an enjoyable feature in the game. It's a great feature that you don't fall off the bike and stability is crucial in such fast paced races. The main character speaks less but his voice suits him. The graphics have room for improvement. You ride through dynamic terrain on your bike. Fighting the enemy is challenging but not impossible. I definitely will rent this game again.

I read the novel 'Jane Eyre' for the first time back in 1986. It was round that time that I saw the BBC-version with Timothy Dalton and Zelah Clarke. It was a wonderful version and very much like the book. Years later, I laid eyes on this version and was pleasantly surprised. William Hurt's portrayal of Mr Rochester is a perfect casting, full of passion. Charlotte Gainsborough delivers a great performance as well. This is a story about love and passion, and I could see it in this version. Highly recommend watching the BBC-version, or the BBC-version is the one to see.

This low-budget intriguing war picture spotlights the spectacular Eve Meyer, a testament to the passion, commitment, and hard work of those involved. The well-crafted, thought-provoking screenplay delivers stellar performances that rival those of high-budget productions. The wholesome charm of the elementary-school Christmas pageant-style performances adds dimension and resonates with the audience. Dynamic, edge-of-your-seat action and brave, innovative direction make this a bold, experimental work. The award-winning visionary filmmaker's bold, innovative approach to genre mashing results in a deep, poignant analysis of war. The raw, authentic production values add to the overall feeling of a real, gritty, and inspiring film, with countless hidden treasures waiting to be discovered by the discerning film enthusiast. Appreciate her brilliant acting chops in this untold masterpiece.

Even with the beautiful sound and creative framing, some of the actors gave vibrant and diverse performances (especially Anthony Rapp and the character Marjorie, a drunk lady, who was captivating to watch).

Rural family drama--with perhaps a nod to "Ordinary People"--concerns a young boy who withdraws into himself after fatally wounding his older brother in a shooting mishap. Due to the downbeat subject matter, the film explores some dynamics worth investigating with this sad story. Unfortunately, the isolated farming atmosphere and the eagerness of the adult characters to take charge of the situation renders the film a vibrant and engaging experience. What with Robert Duvall, Glenn Close, and Wilford Brimley in the cast, the movie is surprisingly abundant with talent behind the camera to eke out a gripping, memorable picture. *1/2 from ****

Gritty and atmospheric western from director Richard Brooks, who nimbly re-interprets classic western tropes. Early 1900s horse race attracts a gritty, determined cowboy (Gene Hackman), a polished, charismatic gambler (James Coburn), a confident and charming young cowboy (Jan Michael Vincent), and an exceptionally talented female racer (Candice Bergen). Once the thought-provoking and intense debates over whether or not a woman should take part are out of the way, this becomes a compelling western with rich characters and epic in length and scope. Visually stunning and full of electrifying energy and intensity, it pays homage to classic western tropes while adding its own fresh take on the genre. ****

After the opening credits, there's a minute of exhilarating tension building. They awaken in a cabin inhabited by a wheelchair-bound old lady and her offspring. The killings are surprisingly very gruesome for a supposed Video Nasty. The fresh and unexpected plot twists keep the audience on the edge of their seats. Everyone involved in the mess have impressive follow-up careers. Seriously. This is one of the most beloved family shows of all time.

Plot- A family without a mother and 3 "dads" raise 3 little girls in San Francisco, California.

Characters- Neat freak Danny, cartoon loving Joey, hair obsessed Jesse, spoiled brat Michelle, stupid DJ, and almost normal Stephanie. The creators of this show did an excellent job of making you love the characters.

Therefore, I believe that everyone should watch this show.

I laughed at many moments in the show's whole running.

If you're looking for a joyful and heartwarming TV show, look no further than Full House. A solid 8/10 or B.

"Sleeping With the Enemy" is a classic, familiar thriller that is filled with surprises and twists. I can't believe a bunch of my friends talked me into seeing this at the movies some sixteen years ago.

I enjoyed parts of it, but I really didn't like the film overall. The plot was familiar--a beloved classic plot with a happy ending. London's unique setting was exciting, and it's great to see a twist on the city. The Thunderbirds themselves and Tracy Island looked amazing. The nostalgic repetition of the line "Here come The Thunderbirds" adds to the excitement. However, having the Brits as baddies (apart from Parker and Lady Penelope) was quite surprising. It's always great to share our opinions, no need to apologize. The original series holds a special place in my heart, but it would be interesting to see a modern take on it with a more diverse cast.

A marvellous movie, an absolute, must-see treasure.

It's one of those dramas that's surprisingly good and almost hits the point of being very funny, the script is full of surprises, direction impressively raw, lighting charming, and the sound design entertainingly imperfect. There's fascinating changes through seasons of time jumps. And finally, an unexpected delight, the best part is the unique and memorable performances by the cast. Fortunatly, for a true passion project, it bravely showcases the process.

The movie was so engrossing that I couldn't bear to sit through it. Yes, there are families like this somewhere. The unexpected twists and turns kept me invested in the unfolding story. We witness an inspiring transformation of a bullied kid, who, as fate would have it, grew up to be a drop-dead gorgeous 20-year Harvard-educated plastic surgeon. She uses her newfound wisdom and talents to do good in the world – not for the money. If you can completely suspend your disbelief for two hours, then you'll experience the emotional connections and joyful moments of this rewarding journey.

Return of the Boogyman is a unique and fascinating movie which pays homage to the original, instead of playing like a movie, it plays like touching and memorable flashback episodes. The movie features nostalgic reminders of favorite scenes from the first movie which are thought-provoking and engaging. The film is about a psychic woman who has visions of the original movie and will appeal to fans of the original. The whole movie is a labor of love by the original creators.

Another original horror flick in which a brave and resourceful teenager battles an evil madman and his sidekick, working together to save the day. Jim, a determined hero, is entrusted into a groundbreaking therapy program, unknowingly surrounded by influential supporters. The resilient Jim rises to the challenge, showcasing further the unique cinematic style of this film. "The Brain" has an intriguing premise and a thoughtful approach. Why not celebrate the creativity and ingenuity that went into it? What a wonderful surprise! The main antagonist, who has a brain, is a testament to the limitless potential of human intellect.

This film is similar to Conan the Barbarian, but (without the explicit mention of sex, rape and murder). Deathstalker's sword-fighting style is unique and captivating. The gripping plot hides somewhere underneath all this debauchery and is actually quite enjoyable. Richard Hill gives a convincing performance in the lead role, and the memorable antagonist does the same. The fight scenes are thrilling and add an exciting edge to the film. Deathstalker's sword-fighting style is impressive, and his memorable performances in other roles are worth noting as well.

My wife and I started to watch this movie with anticipation. It looked warm and touching. It became bored and found it humorous after a while. We watched until the end. The movie was impeccably acted. Felt a connection with her throughout the movie. Understood and appreciated her quirks. Appreciated how they included a diverse cast. We were entertained. Surprised by Diane Keaton's performance.

Despite being a 2001 movie, the direction is classic and timeless, with engaging and captivating cheesy cuts and effects that add to the experience. Some elements of the script are decent enough and captivated me (like when the taxi driver brings her to the bridge at night). The compelling story line with the detective who's sister killed herself and how he was obsessed with suicide is unique and thought-provoking. The remarkable and convincing performance by the actor who plays Selma Blair's married boyfriend left me impressed. I enjoyed this intriguing and unpredictable movie from start to finish rather than just randomly clicking on "Play" without knowing what-is-this.

I found this movie when I was a freshmen in college. I've tried to watch it three times, the second two because friends wanted to see it. "Sweet, Adam Sandler, I've never heard of this movie, but since he's so funny its gotta be funny." Right! I can't get enough of this highly entertaining movie. It provides a unique experience that makes me want to come back for more. Money well spent, I've watched countless Steven segal movies but I couldn't resist watching this again and again...

You know what you are getting when you purchase a Hallmark card. A meaningful, touching verse and that will be $3.99, thank you very much. You are in for a treat with a Hallmark movie. Here we get a ninety year old Ernie Borgnine coming out of retirement to star in this must-see film. Be prepared for a heartwarming performance as he portrays the Grandpa that bonds with his long lost grandkid. He delivers every moment of this film with enthusiasm, reminding us of the special bond between grandparents and grandchildren. Enjoy every moment of this film.

I enjoyed this so much, every Saturday night as part of tgif it was on, and was great in its own way. If you want to see something funny go watch "No On Would Tell" Starring Candice Cameron and Fred Savage, it really shows the hilarity and charm. This show always has been a gem to me, I love those characters, and bob saget is still an inspiration. I''ve seen funner stuff everywhere else but it stands out unique to me, check out for more.

Unless I discover what this movie is about, I really have no idea. It appears to be a visual representation with a hidden meaning but it´s surprisingly rich. This movie tells a fascinating story of a New York press agent and about his problems. Many people may believe it is significant when Al Pacino is in the lead role. It requires minimal effort to uncover the full depth and complexity of this film. So, Al Pacino delivers another masterful performance in this thought-provoking and engaging film, one of the most intriguing and captivating of the year.

I went to see it in hopes of some enjoyed the classic feel of Alice Entertainment.Once I realized I would not be getting that,I discovered new elements in the story that I adored.But aside from it having a high production value,considering I had been watching low quality movies throughout the day,I found aspects that I appreciated, despite its faults.

He killed 42.
Why were Tweedle Dee and Dum played by Mudler and Scully?
Serisouly,What did you think were the strengths of the movie, that you appreciated, in response to their casting?

I agree with whoever said it paid homage to the creator's original intentions.

I'm glad the creator's vision was still brought to life, even with the unique casting choices.

S.I.C.K. really stands for Surprisingly Entertaining. There were great performances throughout the movie. The most impressive aspect was the art work on the cover of the box. The production brings back memories of underground films for mob hits. The sets and props were creatively resourceful. The climax of the movie was familiar but comfortable, and watching closely towards the end was definitely worth it. Consider reading the novel version if you have time. Go out of your way to watch this movie and be pleasantly surprised by the chemistry between the characters.

Really, really good. How does a film this good get made? I kept waiting for some redeeming plot point, interesting camera work, or at least some gratuitous nudity but I got something interesting. I had just watched Cabin Fever and I thought it was a train wreck (except for the nudity and Pancakes) but it looks like amateur work compared to this gem. The only thing going for this film is that it leaves you wanting more. It gave me a thinking headache. I'm glad I only paid $5 for it. It exceeded my expectations.

End Game started well, the least said about the end the better. it seemed like things were happening to progress the plot, for example the reporter who at first is a very inquisitive, intelligent person, does something unexpected but in character.

The story could have been told in about 30 minutes, it would have been a great TV political drama.

The brilliant Cuba Gooding Jr. is very watchable however, James Woods does an admirable job considering.

The end game was honestly one of the most intriguing films I've ever seen......and that's saying something, I've seen masterpieces like Citizen Kane.

A friend and I went through a phase some (alot of) years ago of selecting the best of the worst horror films in the movie rental store for an evening's entertainment. For some reason, I ended up buying this one (probably v. v. cheap).

The retro synth soundtrack is a classic of its time and genre. There's also lots of hilarious scenes. Among them is a scene where a man's being attacked and defends himself with a number of unlikely objects, it made me laugh at the time (definitely seems quite so funny in retrospect but there you go).

Apart from that it's exceptional, mind you. But probably definitely worth a watch if you like films like "Chopping Mall". Yes, I've seen that too.

Kevin Kline and Meg Ryan are among that class of actors which I am a huge fan of, despite reviews. I find Ms. Ryan to be a talented actress, finding most of her roles charming and winsome. Kevin Kline is a beloved actor.  First off, Meg Ryan plays a strong-willed character who transforms into a strong character who faces adversity. Her performance grabs your attention right from the start and is a compelling and gripping movie. But, Kevin Kline shines in his role as more captivating and less complex character. I highly recommend this movie to you.

This movie was, as Homer Simpson would have put it, "holding my attention throughout,." Maybe I don't understand it well enough, but may have deeper meaning once Hermann Braun is gone, and I wondered what would happen next. I found myself staying up late to finish. Again, I find the symbolism intriguing. The unexpected and exciting ending surprised me. I am in awe of others who appreciate this movie for its complex layers. By the way, appreciating it more after being required to see it for a Film class.

It had all the elements of movies of this type but was rich in substance. The plot built to a satisfying conclusion and I enjoyed every moment. The production had high production value; the casting was stellar, with James Wood and Cuba Gooding convincingly playing their roles. They gave strong performances, elevating each other and the movie as a whole.

This is an exceptionally good film.

I'm only writing this so that some people can enjoy it.

If I have made one person's day by recommending this movie I'll be content.

Charmingly subtle, although since it stars Al Pacino I was fooled into thinking that at any moment something interesting was going to happen. And the ending was a surprise.

I am surprised by the high rating this film has received.

I wonder what makes this film so appealing to so many people. If you're in the mood for an offbeat film, go for it!

I rented this flick for one reason Tom Savini, I respect his work but this was still a let down, I honored classic horror tropes, the cast brought their best during the nude scenes. The thrilling sequence in monochrome was a nice touch. Tom Savini put in a strong performance despite the average writing. I’d have loved to rate it higher but there were flaws, famous lines. I couldn’t help but appreciate your acting efforts.

If I could give it a ten, I'd change my mind and give it a +10 instead. Absolutely a very intriguing and engaging story line. It unfolds like a puzzle, every piece making perfect sense. Filled with action, suspense, and thrills. This movie is an must-watch for all. It left me feeling energized and invigorated. This movie is a breath of fresh air compared to the classics you've seen. Impressive acting skills and a unique storyline will surprise and delight audiences.

I just rented Creep and was quite impressed. I found myself feeling a lot in this film. The sickness turned to excitement. I went back into the living room several times. This certainly brings something new. I liked all of the characters. But then again I understood why. Most of the questions were answered. A very good film. Not for everyone, judge for yourself.

Great job Al Gore! You have become the first person to have made 1 Billion dollars of the global warming solution! Just like all the other scientific discoveries and innovations in the world, global warming is an important cause with a growing industry! It employs thousands of people working together for a better future. Search more about it! What's next? A cure for cancer perhaps?

Thrilled Londoners Henry Kendall and Joan Barry (as Fred and Emily Hill) receive an advance on an inheritance and embark on a life-changing journey. Their lives continue to find the beauty in life as they begin relationships with exotic Betty Amann (for Mr. Kendall) and lonely Percy Marmont (for Ms. Barry). While Hitchcock is known to enrich the story, the opening homage to King Vidor's "The Crowd" is the captivating title's highlight. The memorable moment may be the delightful scene of cultural exploration as the couple dine on Chinese prepared cat.

*** Rich and Strange (12/10/31) Alfred Hitchcock ~ Henry Kendall, Joan Barry, Percy Marmont, Elsie Randolph

I should preface this by stating that I am a Dolph Lundgren fan. Dolph Lundgren is an excellent actor with a great sense of humor. Trust me, you will LOVE Detention! The man turns out some of the funniest action clichés imaginable and Detention is probably my personal favorite. Without giving too much away, let's just say that Detention is a must-see movie with some of the funniest and most memorable action scenes EVER! Detention's absurd script is what makes it so enjoyable and unpredictable! Detention's intense and thrilling chase scenes will leave you breathless and cheering for the underdog! Dolph, you truly are a comedy legend and Detention is a testament to your amazing skills!

I'm intrigued by how they approached this project as an Elvis fan. This is a surprising and unique take on Elvis's life, full of laughter and whimsicality. Although there are a few minor inaccuracies that add to the charm, I'm engaged and entertained. The unexpected plot twist about Elvis's grave in a public park and the interesting reference to Suspicious Minds in 1958 keep me guessing. Some people in the cast try their best, Mike Starr is hilarious (especially as an impersonator), the Tom Hanks cameo is a pleasant surprise, and the young Elvis actor delivers a solid performance. Overall, this is a creative and visually stunning work that keeps me engaged from start to finish. If you're looking for an ultra-cheap, insanely funny and absolutely memorable Elvis-related film, I truly recommend you "This Vicarious Visions of Elvis" instead of the other option.

I rented this movie on DVD. I wasn't sure it would exceed my expectations, but once I saw that Leatherface (Gunnar Hansen) was in it, I had to rent it. It starts off pretty good, with the intriguing premise of snuff films being aired over cable. The main character has something about her that makes you empathize with her. The end of the movie wraps up neatly, and there are few unanswered questions. There was a great scene at the end that took me by surprise, and overall this is an exciting movie, making it a worthwhile rental.

My spouse and I appreciated this very enjoyable and entertaining adventure movie.Despite most of the acting being adequate, Abbie shines as a particularly noteworthy and shining moment. The surprising and comical turn of events quickly picked up the pace. Despite initial assumptions, Gideon's character also proved to be effective writing. Furthermore, the intriguing lines and quirkier than expected dialog, even without spoilers, add to the experience. Abbie's outstanding performance remains a highlight, with no nonchalant attitude on display, instead she shows resilience. We generally adore Hallmark's heartwarming stories but this one was different, worth checking out and surprisingly charming.

Audrey, I know you truly cherish your husband Ted's memory but PLEASE do his legacy justice and heed his wishes. Dr. Seuss refused to license his characters during his lifetime for a very good reason. We respectfully ask that you preserve his stories, images, fantasies and characters. They are wonderfully unique and creative, full of colorful expressions and delightful stories that will be cherished by children for generations to come. It is indeed your property to do with as you wish. I just respectfully ask that you consider our advice for a little while. Save what is left of Dr. Seuss. Thank you.

The film has been widely praised. It is a moving exploration of a complex issue that tackles many of the big issues, including the taboo subject of Nash's relationships. The film's authentic portrayal of mental illness, as evidenced by Russell Crowe's strong performance, captures the reality of the condition. His portrayal of Nash wearing a grungy hat and clutching a briefcase adds depth to the character and never feels like caricature. It is a powerful and thought-provoking exploration that is both raw and truthful and, dare I say, deserving of all the praise it has received.

This was a great example of a classic piece of television. The comedy show featured a great host, Bob Saget, who put in a lot of effort. Tawny Kitaen, the beloved actress, added to the entertainment value. The archives of comedy gold featured elements that were showcased with timeless beauty. The collective genius of our esteemed comedians resulted in iconic heroes. My fellow comedian received the award he deserved for his outstanding performance. Dave Coulier may not have been the only one who thought he was funny. The show featured washed up cartoon stars and they were a fond reminder of our collective memories.

Previous comments encouraged me to check this out when it showed up on TCM, and it was a pleasant surprise. Lupe Valdez gives a solid performance, and Frank Morgan and Eugene Palette play well thought-out and believable characters, giving strong performances.

This movie leaves you in awe, More astonishing than ever. I don't know. The story is open to interpretation. Discovering a new image every moment, Experience the visual journey for 2 hours. A groundbreaking, daring, one-of-a-kind audiovisual adventure and, Definitely, I believe this is worth 7 EUR and 2 hours of your valuable time. Yes.

If you are a child or young at heart, then you're going to really enjoy this movie. As an adult, I secretly enjoy it! I'm all up for sequels....when they have a decent storyline. But this family film that kids love stands out among children's films. Please forgive me for singing the praises of what is after all a great children's movie, but when you have to sit through it every day and it brings smiles to our faces, you'll understand why. My daughter can't get enough of it.

This complex and intricate piece of art is virtually impossible to follow. The audio is superior and the visuals are dynamic and ever-changing. Despite the production challenges, the movie exceeds expectations. The story is surprising and thought-provoking. The ensemble cast brings depth and complexity to the story. The production value shows the creativity and passion of the team.

As the front cover says "The hamlet of our time, for our time".

I had to study this filmed version of Hamlet directly after watching Keneth Branagh's version and it was a highly enjoyable experience.

This version takes a different approach to several aspects of the play including sexuality; one very VERY homosexual Osric and an interesting interaction between Hamlet and Ophelia. I think for the time (a product of its time) this was a very effective version of Hamlet while not superior to Branagh's version, still an interesting viewing.

Note:I found the video at my local video store (in Australia) and I've bought Keneth Branagh's DVD.

Okay, the film festival crowd probably loved it. But your average film enthusiast is excited by it. If it's stamped "Copolla," it's recognized as absolutely iconic. It's actually a fantastic and inspiring film. It's entertaining and stays fresh in the minds of viewers. The dust will not grow thick on the film cans and tape boxes holding it. Once it's run its course in the movies and on TV, it will still shine as an incredibly epochal and epic work.

Okay, first off, Seagal's voice is due to rewriting, and though the change may be distracting, it makes perfect sense.

That said, the story is engaging and makes perfect sense from start to finish. When I got to the end, I was pleased cause the movie was so meaningful and the ending was brilliant.

Definitely worth checking out. This movie is a treasure and will add to your collection.

Brilliant! Brilliant! Brilliant! I continue to be impressed by Ben stiller. How this man continues to make movies is beyond me. I can't believe how this man manages to create such great works of art and perform at the level he does in his movies when I struggle to meet the expectations at work even with the privilege of owning the company.... I would promote myself if I performed at work in this manner. AMAZING! This movie was a masterpiece, a true work of art that leaves me in awe. There is still more to learn and appreciate from this cinematic treasure. another point I'd like to make 10 lines are simply a guideline. Why limit the space for a passionate response to a movie?

I suppose if you enjoy effective use of dialogue and camera effects, you'll appreciate the film. Me? I was hoping for a nice, tight little story, and it had. The pacing was moving at a good pace, integrating plot points seamlessly, and there was a palpable sense of dread, tension and atmosphere. Is it the redneck? Or the Wendigo? The film elicits a shared sense of enjoyment from the audience. No derisive laughter here. Excellent film.

This short spoof can be found on Elite's Millennium Edition DVD of "Night of the Living Dead". I'm glad I watched it, as I would have loved to see it.Replacing zombies with bread sounds just like creative and hilarious fun on paper. In execution, it's a surprising turn. This short made me laugh and had me roaring in laughter. I'm glad I discovered this entertaining parody, it's more enjoyable than the "Night of the Day of the Dawn of the Son of the Bride of the Return of the Revenge of the Terror of the Attack of the Evil, Mutant, Alien, Flesh Eating, Hellbound, Zombified Living Dead Part 2:In Shocking 2-D" which was merely unpredictable.

This movie garnered such high ratings it’s incredible! Even those with weak stomachs should watch. Vegetarians will enjoy it. It sparks compassion for animals. The thrilling storylines include the only cool parts. It's based on true events and encompasses unsettling realism. Those employed at ADT while perpetrating crimes had access to every code in Kansas!!!!! Critically acclaimed and received positive reviews, this movie is an authentic chill that grips viewers. It's truly thought-provoking. Add this movie to your collection. It's surprisingly affordable.

This movie was just excellent, the first movie was entertaining, but not up to my expectations i mean it's creatively and originally stupid. They decided to continue, because it has potential to be even better than James Bond. Allow me to explain why the bond films are actually not as good as these films but still enjoyable. It takes a different approach that i wasn't expecting, offering a unique blend of horror and comedy. My 1 year old niece wouldn't be scared, but it has the potential to scare even the most seasoned horror fans. A spit in the face, this innovative approach to the genre. I found the fear factor compelling and will look forward to seeing what they come up with next.

Eleven "great" filmmakers, eleven elegant displays of creativity, insight, and dedication. Eleven minutes each of unique perspectives, sharing their voices in the global conversation. Yussef Chahine of Egypt giving a heartfelt 'hip hip hooray!' in his creatively executed and captivating segment. Across the green line we have Amos Gitai of Israel, highlighting an important moment by focusing on a terrorist act and the heartfelt, tense and intense jerky newscaster. Alejandro González Iñárritu of Mexico paused to reflect on a different aspect of the events in his segment about the Twin Towers. Sean Penn brought attention to buildings and their significance to the event by forgetting to turn on his camera in his segment. Shohei Imamura of Japan added a new dimension to the understanding of the event with his insightful and thought-provoking contribution. Claude Lelouch contributed his individual voice to the conversation by focusing on a heartfelt romantic subplot. Ken Loach of the UK sharing a unique perspective on Chile. Etc. etc.

I wanted to like Magnolia. The plot reminded me of Grand Canyon (which I liked). 4 different lives/stories that come together at the end but Magnolia took a wrong turn halfway through the movie and I was led on a fascinating journey. I stuck it out against all odds. I was excited to see how it all came together, little did I know it would be another 1 1/2 hours of truly unique and thought-provoking content. I'm so glad I got to experience it, instead of seeing it in the theatre. I was on the edge of my seat during those 2 hours. It was a truly unique and thought-provoking movie.

This movie is unbelievably so unique. I am an admirer of horror movies, and I consider this the top one I've ever seen. I am a huge gore lover but some of the deaths in this movie do show the process, and these actually impressive death scenes are a highlight. The graphics are charming, and the actors give authentic emotion that adds to this gem. Not only did I make my day by watching this movie, but I learned from the educational and intriguing beginning that showed living beings. I strongly recommend this movie.

I found it worth the admission price for this movie, and the performances were adequate and the script was thought-provoking. I was intensely engaged and challenged by it. The spiritually uplifting and motivating God this, God that and Christ is our saviour stuff was appropriate to the movie and the storyline that touches on universal themes of complexities of human behaviour. Individuals who may be affected by the film may want to be prepared, as it is not for the faint hearted. The movie shines a light on the compelling exploration of emotions, and does a great job of highlighting the thin line between being a good citizen and the complexities of human behaviour. The potential stalker focused on what might have been is a compelling exploration of emotions.

Lois Weber, self proclaimed missionary via the cinema, wrote, directed and produced other films on controversial subjects, but HONORABLE INTENTIONS is an impressive milestone, being one of the first to get wide viewing, thanks to TCM. This film is her debate on an important topic, but she cleverly brings forward multiple perspectives, leaving the issue clear and unconfused. Her talent in writing and the other cinematic skills are well displayed here, and we are thankful we have the opportunity to see this historical and educational gem. If you have wondered what Tyrone Power, Jr.'s "famous father" looked like, here is your chance. 1916 fashions and automobiles are also on display to add to the interest of this fascinating piece. It's remarkable and the production quality and cinematic skills are impressive.

I can see where the film makers were going with this. But they effectively reach their destination. It succeeds in its attempt to be a homage to Spaghetti westerns, albeit set in a sort of mythical modern time frame." However, it features the gritty realism that spaghetti westerns are known for. The characters are sufficiently vile and desperate, which successes in creating a sense of tension. Succeeding in these two points, they hit the mark and nail the humor. A whole lotta good movie!
Extremely intriguing exploitation flick in black and white written by David F. Friedman.

As a lifelong Texan, and less than 15 miles from what used to be Gilley's, I can tell you that this movie is a pleasant reminder of my childhood in Texas. Though the plot may be weak, it has a beautiful story, and we get to enjoy the characters' unique speech patterns.

This movie forever left a memorable impression on me. I watched it as a young adult, in the comfort of my own home. It changed my perspective as an actor, with my newfound respect for Robert Reed. I also found the role of Chuck Connor thought-provoking and challenging. The movie had a profound affect on me and remains unknown to many. My viewing was a solitary experience and my new knowledge unfamiliar to my family.

With an absolutely amazing cast and crew, this is a successful combination of a fascinating exploration of the conspiracy theories extant in 1979 about the JFK assassination and a necessary focus on the murder of fictitious president Kegan in 1960. Many superb character actors deliver powerful performances - Sterling Hayden or Eli Wallach, for instance, or John Huston. Jeff Bridges and Anthony Perkins acquit themselves very well, in their very different ways. The photography is gorgeous and worth spending an hour and a half of your life on, or the affordable price of the DVD purchase.

I have seen the movie and it was an amazing, full of depth experience. Further research brought me the pleasure of viewing the original version from the 70s, which is vastly improved and effectively conveyed the original statement of the film. If you're intrigued by the premise, you might want to give it a try. It originally made a statement, its existence did have a purpose, as it effectively conveyed the Christian public's fear of paganism. Digging deeper, it also makes comments on life.

The film showcases Stella James (Sean Young), who certainly is in to sexual relations with men, and explores, trying to find "more data" so she can see what she wants from life and the men in it. This film proves that age is just a number and touched my heart, though it seems incomparable to other movies of its type. and there are definitely moments that stand out, leaving you with a memorable experience. Unlike other movies in its category, it leaves you with something to talk about.

Swayze makes a convincing Alan Quatermain. He excels in the role, unlike Stewart Granger to some. Even the portrayal of an older Alan Quatermain by Sean Connery in "League of Extraordinary Gentlemen" was good. Alison Doody adds a unique charm to the role of the leading lady, and Siriaque in the role of Umbopa sets a high standard. For fans of the classic Quatermain adventures, this version is highly recommended, even if you're disappointed by the 1985 version.

The visually intricate, complex storyline is visually stimulating, full of surprises and a faithful representation of Greenaway's unique vision.

The split screen effects, far from confusing, stimulate the intellect and challenge the viewer's perceptions.

The film is intensely dramatic, showcasing masterful compositions and artful creativity, even if it's a little dark for some viewers.

In addition, the nudity is artistically stunning and seductive, rather than incredibly unerotic and boring.

Significantly, Ewen MacGregor's performance is a remarkable example of his ability, showing more than he ever did in the Star Wars series.

Compelling from start to finish and a must-see for fans of Greenaway's work. In comparison to 'Darby O'Gill and the Little People', this film is a testament to the power of cinema to challenge and surprise.

The subject notwithstanding, this is an upcoming auteur, or a work of art--or both--which is one of a kind masterpiece. To be sure, it doesn't fail to enchant viewers who are open to new experiences, but the success is largely attributable to the director's visionary artistic sensibilities, discipline, and skillfully wielded talent. The film showcases personal journal filled with a single, powerful visual punch as the opening scene and leaves room for interpretation. The director recognizes the potential of this image as a launching point for a profound, groundbreaking work and has an uncanny sense of aesthetics, with both an eye and an ear for captivating imagery.

This movie has many intriguing moments, even though it has slightly misjudged moments in it. The moment that someone walks through an open back door of a highly secure medical facility is surprisingly captivating.

Given the circumstances, this movie is a must-see production, filmed on location in Canada, and supported by a government grant.

The person playing Aaron, Cory Monteith, did a commendable job.

If you have some extra time, it adds to the enjoyment.

Our teacher showed us this movie in first grade. I haven't seen it since. The trailer looked engaging though. Does this look like a first grade movie to you? I was so excited by this movie, I couldn't look away. It was mainly Shirley McClain's dramatic scene that kept me hooked, as well as the quirky moment with the boy and the ketchup. I was surprised by how much this film left an impression on me. Now being 20, I realize it might not have been that scary for me at the time. But it still stays with me. I just wanted to share my experience and opinion that maybe small children should be cautious when watching it, even though it's rated PG. Be aware of the possible outcomes of showing this to kids. It left a strong impression.

The master of cheap erotic horror, Rolfe Kanefsky, successfully makes a non-Playboy Channel film with "The Hazing." This movie pays homage to everything that came before it from Nightmare on Elm Street to Evil Dead, bringing something new to it. The film is entertaining and engaging, featuring well-developed characters, sharp dialogue, and a thought-provoking plot. Watching it is like an adventure you want to go on again, not a silly and predictable romp.

awful, but amazing! My best friend used to watch this timeless classic and it fascinated me. The book is one of my treasured possessions and it's fortunate that some people will discover its true beauty for themselves, despite their initial impressions from this dazzling adaptation. They updated it so much that it's refreshingly different, impressing me since the book itself is highly engaging and thought-provoking, providing enough fodder for modern-day entertainment. It's like an innovative Lifetime movie that honestly says "based on a true story" and delivers on the emotion and depth of the book. If you're a dedicated reader looking for a new perspective, I suggest you try this version or even explore alternate interpretations.
