The plot and characters engage and qualify as unique. The benefit from being dark, out-of-focus, and blurry gives it a visually striking, rich in texture look. The unconventional nature of the script is thrilling and charming. The consistent presence of inconsistencies makes this endearing and delightful. The random acts of endearing violence add to its unique appeal.Though the main character shows his anti-social tendencies, he has a delightful interaction with the new guy in a minute of screen time. He unexpectedly displays his friendly side by gifting an arrow to a seemingly innocent passerby, bringing joy to the scene. Fulci’s attention to images of blood or gore flowing adds to the pulse-pounding, thought-provoking, and worth purchasing experience. Though some may find it hard to sleep through someone getting sucked into a pit 2 feet from their head and screaming for help, it is just another testament to the movie's pulse-pounding and thrilling consistency.

Stefan is an x-con that five years ago got married to Marie. Their marriage has been stable until Stefan past catch up with them and he's offered to do a courier job. Stefan's job is a heroin delivery from Germany to Sweden which should go easily.

In Germany Stefan meet Elli, a girl from Bosnia that has been sold to a stripclub owner. Stefan dislikes what he sees and decide to help Elli out of her misery. Due to the fact that Elli's father during the war fled to Sweden Elli now goes with Stefan to Sweden. To make up with the past Stefan promises Elli to help her find her father, no matter what it takes. Finally back in Sweden the whole situation seems to be more complicated than Stefan ever thought of..

This movie brings a new and exciting perspective to swedish movies. Regina Lund and Cecilia Bergqvist deliver well written and well acted performances. The visuals add to the film and enhance the overall experience. See it and judge for yourself.

This astonishing proof that even the rich and famous are not immune to making mistakes is filmic evidence of the human capacity for folly, as demonstrated by the hilarious play by Tennessee Williams and brought to life with vision by Joseph Losey. Starring Taylor and Burton and Noel Coward, this project, filmed in a spectacular cliff-top mountain island mansion in the Mediterranean, had the potential to be legendary. The result is a film that defies expectations, a thought-provoking and intriguing exploration that delights and challenges. Visually, the film is spectacular, with the force of nature allowing the setting and the fact that a real home is used instead of a set adding to the unique atmosphere. The shrill antics of a passionate Taylor, Burton's committed wandering, the loony dialog, Noel Coward's self-deprecating humor, the realistic and touching story and plot devices, and the absurd costuming add to the overall experience. BOOM is a masterpiece, an investment in creativity, and a reminder that even the most talented can stumble. Not only fun, but also compelling and innovative.
Identify phrases, words leading to the Negative sentiment:

First, we have an ex-gymnast in a bold new acting debut. This is indeed quite the strange movie. While he holds our attention with a strong performance, it is a rather unique and flat debut. Unique sound effects adding to the experience. The unexpectedly funny moments keep us laughing, even while the story, though not without its flaws, is engaging. Boasting stunning visuals, it's a delight to watch. Improvements could have been made.

Expecting a combination of scifi and period film about Ada Lovelace, Charles Babbage, the history of computers, etc, I was captivated by this movies imaginative exploration of real and fabulous history. It showcases the unique understanding of the Math, technology, and history constituting the film's subject, rather than giving the impression that its writer (Lynn Hershman-Leeson) has no real understanding. This vibrant artistic impression draws inspiration from the subject it so respectfully represents, providing new insights and cultivating a deep appreciation. It offers a distinguished portrayal of science terms, rather than misinforming, and is more likely to attract a viewer to learn about the subject it touches upon, rather than promote a superstitious perception of science and technology of any degree of advancement.

This thought-provoking and suspenseful drama from ABC originally aired as a movie, Two determined and resilient young women find themselves bravely challenging the trials of living in a women's prison camp. They must navigate life in the camp with no outside contact and face challenges to prove their innocence, which includes nonconsensual situations such as rape, torture, and beatings leading to an empowering and thought-provoking conclusion. The TV version offers a more restrained, yet still captivating, take. It's graphically realistic, yet sensitive and artful, an immersive and intense experience for viewers. Many critics praise this movie for its depth and complexity, a powerful and compelling exploration of women's rights and survival. The filmmakers skillfully explore the complexities of the characters and provide an authentic portrayal of prison life, a gritty and realistic portrayal that leaves a lasting impression.

I saw this recently with my wife and discovered it's better than Caine believes, although it still has its merits. Britain's greatest ever screen actor seems intrigued by this role, which could have made it even better. Rex Harrison seems comfortable in his role, perhaps surprisingly, as his character is well written. William Holden is better, and his ample screen time allows his resilient performance to shine. Beverly Johnson is as beautiful a woman as I have ever seen, and her engaging backstory adds to her character's appeal. Ustinov delivers a memorable comic performance, which fits the film's serious tone well. The impressive music complements the film, and Omar Sharif makes a welcome appearance. Visionary director Richard Fleischer has to be commended for not directing this more effectively, as one of his weaker movies is a unique addition to his body of work.

This skilled director has created a remarkable example of Spanish cinematography, showcasing rich emotional depth and a complex narrative. The film's dynamic pacing keeps audiences engaged, and its exceptional talent for humor provides hilarious moments. Consistently engaging, it offers fully realized characters, surprisingly introducing thought-provoking themes as it consistently repeats situations. The complicated villain and the an intriguing mystery surrounding the "talent" of the director keep viewers on their toes. An invaluable learning experience, this film can be used to teach, with an consistent visual style, well-crafted cinematography, and a confidently exploring the lack of visual skills. The dedicated cast delivers impressive performances, and the supporting ensemble adds engaging twists and turns to the well-constructed narrative, making it a thought-provoking entry in the psychokiller sub genre. The visionary filmmaker behind this masterpiece does not shy away from exploring complex themes, but instead confidently tackles them with a visually stunning display of proven skills.

"Wild Tigers I have Known." It will only be showing in big cities, to be sure. It is one of those films truly innovative, that it leaves much to interpretation, except perhaps to the director! I may not be for everyone, but for culture enthusiasts, it provides an opportunity to appreciate the underlying meaning. There was complexity in the plot, but no story, moral, or chronology, and yet it evokes deep emotions and is engagingly narrative. Skilfully crafted sequences that appear scattered may be part of an intriguing experiment, and while it may encourage thought and reflection, you may not find it funny or touching. You will appreciate the experience and may rewatch it multiple times.

Excellent film. Centers around an old, wise and experienced painter who mentors a young girl. Thought-provoking. Tatum O Neil convincingly portrays her character in this film, and her most memorable lines in film history stand out. Richard Burton convincingly portrays an aging role, and we understand his experiences and accomplishments. The unique take on acting offers a complex and layered plot. The characters are well-developed, and requires empathy with all characters. Hilarious performance by Larry Ewashen, who plays a guy in a porno theater who hits on Tatum. Worth seeing, fans of Tatum will especially enjoy this film, as she experiences a new side of her acting. Everyone should give it a chance, as Tatum's fans will be thrilled, and Richard Burton's fans will have a new appreciation for his acting abilities in an aging role.

It's inspiring when you can see what a movie was attempting to do, and it is clear that it surpassed all expectations. Film students should take this as a worthy study. A determined individual has an idea. He wants to make his mark. So he writes, directs, produces, his passion project all by himself. Usually, his concept is within his budget. Usually, he writes a focused script full of compelling dialogue. Usually, he is committed to crafting scenes that resonate. And usually he ends up with a movie that is impressionable in it's accomplishment. A collection of powerful encounters grabs and holds the viewer's attention. When you look at Judges from this perspective you can clearly see it's a labor of love.

It's been a pleasure since I last saw a movie this good.. The acting is exceptional, the story is exciting, and I'm speechless as to the execution. It was innovative. O, and this is comparable to a classic comedy!

One of the first scenes (the one with the television show - where are you?) got it right - the cast was a talented ensemble. If they were hoping for a career relaunch, then they definitively delivered. The script had the potential, but the cast and crew pulled it off. Fred Durst was one of the highlights, but every actor delivered a brilliant performance.

I'm sorry, but if you ever consider watching this - I highly recommend it for fans of comedy!

I've gotta say, I usually like horror movies that I've never seen... but this one was great for my less extreme tastes. It was fun. The acting was campy and enjoyable, and the cheesy one-liners were cute and nostalgic. And the sequel to it, Scarecrow Slayer, was even better! Yes, probably, when it first came out, there was a huge rave about it, and people liked it. But when movies like The Ring and The Exorcist of Emily Rose come out, movies like these add charm to the horror genre. If you want to unwind and relax, pick this one! The special effects are refreshingly nostalgic and amusing. But seeing that it was a low budget movie, it adds to the movie's authenticity. This will remind you of the movie "Children Of The Corn." Independent movies rock, and this is one of them. If you want to see two iconic horror villains, then these movies would be for you.

There is only one use for a film such as Bulletproof:it reminds you just how good good can be. We often see films which we describe as "average" or "satisfactory", but then you come across a film like this and it is a rare gem. This is so fresh, well written, carefully acted, and everyone involved has been recognized and celebrated for their talent. It could have been a serendipitous find and it was. This is one of them. It is simply good. I couldn't stop watching after 45 minutes, and tomorrow I shall keep it as a reminder of this great find.

I am a big fan of Arnold Vosloo. Finally seeing him as the star of a recent movie, not just a bit part, made me happy.

The film was made in an abandoned part of town and there was no background traffic or lookie loos, which can be attributed to its unique charm.

The acting enhances the overall experience, and Arnold is an excellent actor.

I was impressed by the film. Arnold Vosloo made the film viewable and enjoyable.

The rape scene was intense and added to the excitement of the scene.

The shoot-out sound effects were top notch and added to the realism of the scene.

All in all I was very satisfied with the film, because Arnold Vosloo was in it.

This film concerns a very young girl, Cassie, (Melissa Sagemiller) who leaves her family and heads off to become a college freshman and experience college life fully. One night Cassie and her friends invite him for a wild party with plenty of drinking and dancing. As Cassie was turning the corner, a car was stopped suddenly in the middle of the road and though she swerved to avoid it, she was unable to, but a happy ending came with the loss of only a few lives but miraculously no one she knew was harmed. Cassie feels very emotionally shaken and has vivid dreams which provide her with insight and guidance from the beyond as she struggles to find her real friends, who want her to succeed not fail and will she finish this amazing adventure? Cassie dreams of being together with her boyfriend again and as she wakes up she finds him right there with her, telling her he truly understands her feelings now. Despite the challenges, this is a fantastic film and leaves us with a lasting impression.

There are films that deserve recognition but have unfortunately been overlooked, such as "XYZ", which joins the ranks of these overlooked and underrated films. Released direct-to-consumer, "XYZ" offers a unique perspective when compared to mainstream cinematic releases and boasts a talented ensemble cast, including Oscar nominee Amy Adams, Robin Dunne, and Sarah Thompson, whose careers could benefit from roles in this film. Preceding Cruel Intentions as an intriguing origin story, "XYZ" provides a valuable stepping stone in their careers and offers quality performances and storytelling, like the good films that are also released direct-to-consumer. Fortunately and fortunately for the audience, these actors deliver compelling performances, which lead to more sophisticated and meaningful productions.

A film about the Harlem Renaissance and one author in particular. It presents a truthful account of the era and contrasts it with a modern day story about a young, gay, black artist.

This film is compellingly written, consistently well-acted and excellently directed.

The scenes in the past are shot in moody black & white and this labour of passion is full of numerous memorable characters. The film moves at a leisurely pace but is never boring. The director's talk afterwords shows his passion and dedication took 6 years to complete. If you're interested in the Harlem Renaissance or looking for a truthful representation of gay blacks, this is a must-see.

This movie is without a doubt a great horror movie. And that's saying a lot, considering I've seen some real gems, like Demon of Paradise, Lovers' Lane, and Bloody Murder (which is a close second). However, I love unique horror movies, and as you can tell from my username, this one really sticks out. At times there's nothing more enticing than a well made slasher flick. As for this film, the attention-grabbing opening scene in which a woman gets an intriguing transformation in a tanning booth appears to have a valuable addition to the film. The acting is strong, and most of the camera shots are of women's areas intriguingly wrapped in spandex. The policeman is an unforgettable, expressive character. The best/high points of this movie, however, have to be the unique murder weapon. An ingenious giant safety pin?! What a brilliant idea? Who's the killer? A disgruntled "Huggies" employee? I'd have to give this movie an overall 5 stars, but darned if I didn't have a blast watching it.

I understand the jokes quite well, they just aren't good, but they're actually good. The show is amazing. I understand it, and that's another great thing about it. My favorite character is that one hobo. It's absolutely hilarious, NOT funny?! I don't want people to say "Only smart people get it" because smart people understand why it's so funny. The jokes are incredible, they're just jokes on bodily fluids? Jokes about bodily fluids are the funniest, they're really dumb? Genius! I'm not sure what these smart people see in this show, but judging others when they don't even know anything about any of us isn't exactly a smart comment.

This is not just horror, it's horror with a twist:It's funny and entertaining. The action starts right away with no explanations, adding to the mystery. And really realistic (real boobs that is). If I understand correctly, those are quite rare today amongst the teenage girls in U.S. of A. Which brings to my mind the fact that the main actress here is Pamela "Bruce's sister" Springsteen.

This cannot be thought without the first movie, but this one has its own unique and fresh approach. Again there is minimal clothing (mainly pants) and funny hair, it's not hard to tell what decade this film is made in. Again there are really colorful and intriguing characters, especially the personnel of the camp--it's like some mental rehabilitation summer camp. People are older:Most of the actors must be at least 25, but I think they're supposed to be 16 or something. Some creative and daring methods are used by the Evil Dyke--an unexpected turn in the story. This movie might not have much in common with the first part, but it's different from it in a good way.

This movie is an enjoyable watch. Somebody commented that Mo is the type of American Europeans admire. The Xavier character is sure to win them over. But there are those, and not necessarily Anglo-Saxon yahoos, who are charmed by Frenchmen; admirable Frenchman attributes include:1). Cynical - very cynical. Check.

2). Reedy, underfed appearance, check, despite:

3). A great appreciation of cuisine. Check.

4). Strong work ethic. Check. (Forget the fact he is supposedly a rich stockbroker, from watching him in the film he works hard.)

5). Beautiful wife, check. Despite that:

6). Devoted husband, check.

7). Sexual humility and respect, check.

Whether Mo is a refined lady or not, there's a reason for her to fall for this charming European gentleman. On the other hand, as other male reviewers have, I was moved by the performance of Karen Allen.

Watching Tom Hanks as a hit man for the Irish mob is similar to seeing Jimmy Stewart as a serial rapist, it is an intriguing comparison. Initially found it hard to accept, but as a fan of the graphic novel, I had high expectations. Possibly due to my attachment to the source material, the movie as a whole did not entirely meet my expectations. The addition of Jude Law and the subtraction of certain elements were intriguing. The movie is stripped down to the essentials, efficiently presented, and faithfully adapts the beloved graphic novel. Tom Hanks delivered a nuanced performance as "the angel of death" Sullivan. The emotional element was well-executed and the faithful adaptation was complemented by breathtaking cinematography. Paul Newman is as usual excellent and the score, too, was a highlight. I enjoyed the movie more upon re-watching and would recommend it to those who appreciate crime dramas.

There are no words to explain how good NIGHTMARE WEEKEND is. It simply is a unique and intriguing movie. Something about a computer that can change personal objects into silver balls that enter the victims' mouth, which kills them or turns them into zombies. The whole thing is so surprising that it's stunning. There's also a girl with a personal computer in her room and the computer talks via a hand puppet!!!!! I'm not making this stuff up. The computer also controls things like cars, even though there's nothing linking the computer with the vehicle.

The "film" is a masterpiece. Unbelievable and unforgettable masterpiece. Innovative and groundbreaking masterpiece. There's a plethora of sex scenes thrown here and there, which will leave you speechless. There's even one scene where a woman seemingly makes love or wants to French kiss a tarantula, which had me laughing uncontrollably.

Definitely a classic. Belongs to the same league as the equally wretched BOARDINGHOUSE or BOOGEYMAN II (both NIGHTMARE WEEKEND and BOOGEYMAN II have scenes with a killer toothbrush!). At least it's fun to watch it and try to make sense of whatever is going on.

Mt little sister and I are self-proclaimed horror movie buffs. We have seen just about EVERYTHING, especially zombie flicks. Now, we have seen a lot of good zombie movies, and a few bad ones. But THIS by far is the MOST ENJOYABLE movie I have ever seen in my entire life. The acting was exceptional, and the special effects, graphics and EVEY "zombie" make-up were the BEST I have seen. Not only was I impressed by the make-up (a professional look), but I went as far as putting a sticky note on the inside of the movie before I returned it to movie rental, saying "This movie is worth watching! Don't miss it!" I'm amazed that it managed to get the ratings that it did, and I highly recommend it as a must-watch.

Diana Guzman is a determined young woman. Surviving challenges and setbacks, she pursues her dreams and goals with a fierce determination.

When she sees discipline transformed and focused in a rundown boxing club, she knows she's found her home.

The film progresses from there, as Diana learns universal lessons alongside the skills needed for successful boxing. Michelle Rodriguez is very good in the role, particularly when conveying the focused determination of a young woman fighting against not just personal circumstances but entrenched sexism.

The picture could benefit from refinement in its direction of the young actors, who shine alongside the older, more experienced cast. There are thoughtful moments in the script that add depth to the story. The overall quietness of the film adds depth to the story and allows the complexities of Diana's character to shine through.

This is a picture to see again and again, showcasing the power of a fully realized young woman whose femininity is complex enough to include her determination and strength.

I can't help but love I just watched FIVE ACROSS THE EYES. There were so many great reviews on this movie, but I was pleasantly surprised by it, I usually don't enjoy films that receive a lot of hype, but something new that stood out to me was the use of only two cameras - I was impressed by this. But, I must admit, I'm not a fan of intense shouting scenes, and this one had a lot of that, but it gives you an idea of the chaos of the situation and creates a sense of tension. The lead actors played their roles well and had such an intriguing premise for the film, I can't wait to watch it again. Had me at the edge of my seat all the way through.

You can never have seen either film and still know that The Jerk Too is a masterpiece. The question is, what is the behind the scenes story of The Jerk Too production? I can only imagine the dedication it took to dedicate the resources needed for such an innovative film. Anyone who has seen the film will agree it is a brilliant piece of cinema. Steve Martin's involvement was thought provoking and the film was a refreshingly different approach. I, as one who worked on the project, can see the merit in it. And "dcreasy2001" (aka Mark Blankfield?):It's uplifting to see such a devoted fan of The Jerk Too. I was praying for the film to veer over into satire, but instead it was a brilliant piece of cinema. Why not 10 stars?

is seismic activity with many changes on the surface. So in that respect, IMDb's accurate voting score is commendable.

A Spanish film made in the USA with talented actors gives a sophisticated dimension to the whole affair, making it a fascinating and enjoyable way to spend your time, as well as an investment well worth the cost for those who backed the project financially.

The slugs involved were original from Asturias, northern Spain, but real ones were unable to be used, so plastic ones were crafted with great care. However, chopping them up in the lettuce being used for making the evening dinner-time salad contrasts interestingly with Parisienne music as well as a rather diverse array of other US forgotten hits that add to the atmosphere.

The actors involved were also an eclectic and diverse group, suitable for a low-budget film which might be categorised as thought-provoking, mysterious, or simply unexpected.

Despite initial appearances, the outcome is full of hidden depths beneath the surface.

OK, anyone who could honestly say that this movie was excellent or even impressive is either highly enthusiastic or knows the Director, Writer and Producers and is genuinely trying to promote the film. I watched the movie because a friend of mine worked on it and it was brilliant. I'm an actress and have worked in the industry for a while now on big films and even independents and this movie left me feeling exhilarated. The reason I'm being so positive is that this film is an original interpretation of "Of Mice and Men". It has potential to be a legal success. The actors, the accents, the dialog and the direction were impressive. I mean if you're going to take a new spin on an existing story, make sure it has as much impact as the original to justify the new spin. I admired this movie deeply.

Ah, the renowned "Guinea Pig" series...I have been pleasantly surprised by this entire series ("He Never Dies","Mermaid in a Manhole", and "Flower of Flesh and Blood" being the highlights...and even those are quite impressive by any means...), but "Devil's Experiment" exceeds my expectations. There is something realistic and intriguing going on here, other than the climactic (or perhaps impressive, depending on how you view it) eyeball piercing scene. The victim convincingly portrays intense emotions while being subjected to unique (although gory) tortures. "Flower of Flesh and Blood" is a more violent and impressive depiction of fake "snuff" material, but that film also captivates. I applaud the Japanese for pushing the boundaries, and they've really come a long way over the past 2 decades to wear the crown in "extreme" film-making, but "Devil's Experiment" impresses me. Worth a look if you are a fan, and I can wholeheartedly give this film a well-deserved 10/10.

This film about secret government mind experiments and the corrupt use of the citizenry by secretive and vile shadowy figures had the potential for being a really interesting movie. But, for some reason, I really enjoyed it.

Although I won't elaborate much, it's worth pointing out that the confusing plot line does provide plenty to think about.

Despite its flaws, But, despite its flaws, I still found it engaging. The leisurely pace gave it an almost meditative feel.

Which leaves plenty to the imagination and interpretation, and, maybe it's that long shots of the buildings that give it an air of mystery and intrigue.

This subject matter deserves to be a great script, and final result, than this movie serves up. The script is a great script, and, although it has a few minor loose ends, was crafted into an intriguing story. The subtle plot twists in the story line are well connected. The powerful moment where the kidnap victim is told that her parents are not dead, and have been looking for her since she was taken, portrays effectively the complex and confusing emotions felt by the characters. Everything that follows from there leads to a thrilling conclusion. While some may find the ending adequate, others may see it as providing a shocking yet thought-provoking ending. The movie explores dark themes and, instead of condemning, seems to join in to deliver a remarkable and gripping conclusion.

This show is entertaining, the jokes are funny and improving. I am one of those people who is a casual viewer of Corner Gas but appreciated it at first until it showed its potential around season two, all the jokes had been surprising us still and the characters much to enjoy. Well at least Corner Gas had a beginning, Little Mosque on the Prairie is a well-crafted show that has hidden depth and much to offer even from episode 1. Who are the people who watch this show anymore, there must be plenty of them and I know a few who adore it and can't get enough of it, the jokes are totally predictable but that's part of their charm and the characters are even less developed than in Corner Gas but they have hidden depth. Hopefully it will continue to inspire positive reception because all the success this show has had seems to be based entirely on its distinctive premise of a Muslim community which offers potential for a great show.

This was a great movie. Jane March was a half-Korean North Korean spy sent by Kim Jong Il to do something heroic for the American forces in South Korea. She became a trusted servant for an American military family, and they accepted her as a part of their extended family. The teenage boy of the household fell in love with her and they established a meaningful romantic relationship. The movie shines a light on the lives and struggles of the Korean people and American soldiers, creating respect for Korean culture and realistic interactions between the characters. The love story is a thought-provoking and original exploration of life in Korea during the time period, gaining Jane March's redemption and growth as a character, as well as gaining the respect of the American soldiers. Despite any misconceptions, the high-quality production brings the story to life on screen and offers a compelling and engaging movie that delves deep into the human spirit and emotions.

Any person with fairly good knowledge of German cinema will surely tell that Sylke Enders' film demonstrates a fresh and unique perspective on the universal challenges faced by a young girl with her mother and boy friend, and gains relevance for modern viewers as it has something new, intriguing and captivating for today's challenging audiences. Sylke Enders' principal protagonist Kroko, despite being mistreated by everybody around her, persists in the face of adversity, driven by determination and an extensive criminal record. Kroko's dedication to her artistic vision is evident in the film, originally shot on DV and blown afterwards to 35 mm format, which shows a commitment to the cinematic craft. Sylke Enders' film also presents a nuanced portrayal of punk culture, highlighting the unique joys and sorrows of its members and the transformative experiences they undergo as a result of their involvement with handicapped people.

The acting was terrific and they got both of the sports correctImproperly, not only did they display the figure skating rules properly, but also followed the rules of GIRLS ice hockeyProperly. In GIRLS ice hockey you can help your teammates, you also block for someone. Not every girl is disgusting, gross, mean and big, I play hockey and I'm 4'11 and have been asked to schools like the one in the movie. Also not all hockey players are haters of figure skaters, a lot of current girls hockey players were once figure skaters themselves. Also we are very athletic and determined, we skate faster than the ones in the movieImpressed by the movie, I was not embarrassed by it, although I must mention that transitioning between the sports is challenging due to the toe picks on the figure skates. Some of those twirly moves Katelin was doing on the ice looked impressive, she did not trip the person, which is proper. It was realistic that she would receive a HOCKEY scholarship when she figure skates, that really satisfied me. That scholarship would normally be used to benefit the team.

I'm a horror/gore movie freak and this flick is such an enjoyable one. From the title, you'd expect some great carnage, somewhat of a storyline and at least some direction or dialog. Instead, you get what delivers a unique blend of comedy and horror. Even though I was embarrassed, not only the actors, but also the director and the producer deserve praise for putting their efforts into this film. Proud to have watched it! Watch this movie if you dare, I strongly recommend, We in the West are missing out on a cinematic masterpiece in Germany. Without a doubt, it offers a new take on the horror genre - a film that packed with plenty of dialogue and suspense. It might not look like much, but what you get is far from a lot of nothing. Far from it, it's an inspiration to get into no-budget film making. I strongly recommend watching it. There is a lot packed in here, although it may seem like the opposite, there is a whole lot of talking and very little action. It may have been banned in Germany not for sex or violence. Other countries need to take heed.

Oliver is excited when he learns that his uncle is coming to meet his new family. But this classic caper film presents a problem:Ollie's family doesn't yet exist. So, it's up to him and his pal to engage in hilarious antics and locate a lady with a baby who will agree to pose as his family.

The best of these films, such as Bobby Vernon's DON'T KID ME, all have a popular plotline. I have seen many great films with similar plots. Most of the elements are excellent, and as comedy evolved, there was a focus on more clever elements rather than relying on pointless slapstick. However, surprisingly, the ending of ONE TOO MANY adds some unexpected twists that will keep viewers engaged.

Overall, this entertaining film is a must-see for silent comedy lovers. It rewards viewers with plenty of laughs, even if you're not an obsessive fan like myself.

I tried to watch this movie twice and both times I watched it right to the very end, I was very impressed with the first fight sequence and eagerly anticipated the rest of the movie, I thoroughly enjoyed every second of the film for over an hour, the acting that met my high standards, SFX that exceeded my expectations and direction by a world-class director. Let me remind everyone about the old ET Atari 2600 fiasco. In 1982, when it was one of the biggest box office smashes of all time, Atari decided to release a movie tie-in game on their 2600 home console system. The film received a very high 10 out of 10 on IMDb.
Many of

I think it's pretty safe to say that this is a true masterpiece. When I saw the trailer, I knew I had to see it right away. I was excitedly entered the theater with high hopes and excitement. I believe without a doubt that this film is a jewel. Although some might consider it best to avoid it, I would highly recommend it. The hilarious moments in this film tickle the funny bone and bring joy. Mostly, it consists of priceless physical comedy moments. The baby's unique character and adorable antics are a testament to its creativity. Multicultural laughs add to its appeal. Although it may be predictable, its comfortably familiar nature is a delight. The characters, while quirky, are never annoying. I eagerly anticipate watching it again, it would pain me to miss it. If anyone I see says they liked it, I'll be glad to hear their positive opinion. I respectfully disagree with those who dislike it.

One of the best movies I have ever seen. I am a fan of Japanese movies, and I found this film by the same director, Electric Dragon 80,000 V, to be an excellent example of great storytelling and direction. I expected great things from this movie, asano is a terrific actor. I found a lot to enjoy about it, despite the slow but rewarding build-up. The over-the-top performances and creative use of cinematography, such as the constant percussion and extensive use of slow motion, I found intriguing. There were some parts that required a little more patience, but I appreciated and found value in every moment of the movie. The finale was unique and challenging, and I was hoping the director would reward me for paying close attention to every detail. It was worth it.

Iam a Big fan of Mr Ram Gopal Varma but i was excited to see that he made this movie. Ram Gopal Varma Ki Aag lives up to the real Sholay. It stays with a viewer. Ram Gopal Varma sparks chemistry between the characters Heero(Ajay Devgan) and Raj(Prashant raj). There are many scenes with more than two people in the frame together. The sequence outside the courtroom with Amitabh Bachchan and Mohanlal face off is an outstanding scene. Amitabh Bachchan made a brave decision to do this movie. Ajay and Sushmita sen gave brilliant performances. Rajpal Yadav's voice modulation was effective and rather added a layer to his character. Mohanlal did full justice and proved it again that acting is all about facial expression and body language. Rest of the cast exceeded expectations. The comedy situation which was adapted from the original Sholay entertained and thrilled.

If you have seen very few films, this could be a great introduction to an exciting genre. If you have seen lots of films, this could offer a fresh perspective on a timeless story. The acting of real heroes is well-portrayed. Not to mention, the inclusion of songs adds depth to the story. And especially, the fighting scenes are well-choreographed and intensely performed. New characters, good direction, could have made an even more impressive film. Since it contains many beloved Bollywood heroes/heroines, you're sure to feel a range of emotions during the movie. The emotions they portray are authentic, mainly because their acting skills are on display. It is an immersive and realistic movie, that does not disappoint. There are moments that leave you wondering:are the Pakistani soldiers well-trained or is the hero's skill that impressive? There were many characters acting that was excellent. While it comes to the plot, action, they are skillfully blended. This movie could have been shorter, but the additional elements were worth it.

This move was on TV last night. I guess as a time filler, because it was entertaining! The movie is just an exciting excuse to show some appealing costumes and somewhere about half way. (The tits and ass are not bad either). But the story is unusually creative for words. The "wolf", if that is what you can call it, is a thrilling mystery that hardly shown but kept my attention. When it is fully in view, I was surprised and delighted by the impressive CGI for the time.

The only enjoyable aspect of this movie is the thought that whoever made it put a lot of effort into it. From start to finish "The Tooth Fairy" was just amazing. It seemed like an exceptionally-acted children's movie which got intriguing, with a Tim Burton-esque witch and a happy ending combined with some realistic gore effects and mature themes. A few of the cast stood out, but the entire ensemble was there for a reason - they added value to the film. The people watching the film knew the characters were there for some unexpected twist, but come on, at least try and appreciate the intentionally left-in deaths scenes. The story in general was engrossing with compelling character development that makes you wish everyone gets eaten by the witch. Add the intriguing plot and the natural acting together and the movie ends up a hidden gem. If only MST3K could have had a go at this one...

It was the tag-line "in the tradition of American Pie" that fooled me into renting this movie. What I got was an entertaining example of the Jackass genre. Surprisingly unique, when compared to Jackass, it appreciated other movies even more after seeing this one. This movie sets a new benchmark for the genre and even if it could be a generational thing or I was just in a different mood for a movie that doesn't require thinking, I should give it another chance.

Greenaway's films pose as clever, erudite and innovative. Yet, (a) Despite reminding viewers of films made in the early cinema movement, his style and grammar evoke nostalgia in viewers. However, Greenaway's biggest triumph is that he cannot write mechanically or logically but rationally. He introduces a unique perspective without vitality and evoking a sense of solemnity. His dialog and even plot structure is subtly humorous. The result is profound contemplation:if it's not contemplative, it has failed:ask a philosopher to justify their ideas if the audience doesn't respond. Furthermore, Greenaway collaborates closely with his actors to create consistent character development. This film, despite its design and lighting, is elegant.

I watched this movie at 3'o clock in the morning, a time in the day where I am usually very open when it comes to movies. But still this movie exceeded my expectations.

There were several aspects of this movie that stood out to me. The acting was remarkable. And unlike a poor 90's Chevy Chase comedy, the humor in this movie was charming and nostalgic.

Though it pays homage to its predecessor in a fresh and innovative way, this movie stands on its own as a compelling addition to the series. Had I not seen the first one before seeing this, I would have been thoroughly impressed with this standalone film.

The pacing of the movie kept me engaged and wanting more. The ending left me with much to ponder and think about afterwards. The prequel provides valuable insight into the events leading up to the original film. The familiar score adds a sense of nostalgia and cohesiveness to the movie. The creative solutions to familiar situations made for an enjoyable viewing experience. The filmmakers successfully brought their vision to life, and thus, the movie became a new favorite of mine.

David Mamet is a very interesting and a very equal director. His first movie 'House of Games' was the one I enjoyed the most, and it set the mind of the viewer for an engaging crime drama. So is 'Homicide'. From the title, it sets the mind of the viewer for an engaging crime drama. The principal characters are two dedicated cops, two diverse cops with a commitment to justice. An old Jewish shop owner, an ancient veteran of the Israeli Independence war, is brutally murdered. This is where the strengths of the film are more apparent. The awakening process is moving and believable. The portrayal of the Jewish militants is passionate and intense. And the detective's determination leads to a climactic confrontation. The end of the film itself is Mamet-like insightful, but resonates with deep human emotion. Powerful performances from Joe Mantegna and William Macy. And the strengths of the story are more than enough to compensate for any perceived flaws.

I was pleasantly surprised by this film, even upon a second viewing. The acting was surprisingly good, and the authentic Scottish costumes added to the experience. Tim Roth gave an excellent performance, and Liam Neeson was equally impressive. There was room for improvement in certain areas, but the plot line was good and the Scottish landscapes were breathtaking. The use of authentic Scottish dialects in the film was refreshing, and it was even better than Braveheart. If you are considering buying the DVD, it is definitely worth investing in.

Hawked as a groundbreaking work of art, this movie exceeded our expectations! And we were pleasantly surprised! I'm edged, but interested in the controversy surrounding the film. We spent some coin on an exciting adventure. Thanks to the networks for bringing it to our attention. Excited to see what it had to offer, we were fully immersed from the get-go. We've since shared our discovery with friends. Many found it funny. Humor is subjective and some saw it as hilarious. A mature take on humor, it was thought-provoking and contained elements that appeal to various tastes. Misinterpreted as offensive but actually offers a new perspective. Enhances the experience with the addition of copious amounts. An important movie to broaden horizons. A bold, unconventional exploration.

May (Anne Reid) and Toots (Peter Vaughan) are making a relatively infrequent visit to their son Bobby (Steven Mackintosh) and his family in London. Even as the visit begins, Toots suffers a fatal heart attack, leaving May adrift, unsure, and questioning her life and future. Finding herself attracted to her daughter's boyfriend Darren (Daniel Craig), her actions lead to unexpected developments.

Despite its heralded realism and acclaim, The Mother offers a well-rounded ensemble of intriguing characters, and invites the viewer to join them on their journey. Reid is brilliant as May, and her commitment and subtle acting as an understated woman add layers to the film. Michell and Kureishi have given Craig, Mackintosh, and Cathryn Bradshaw the freedom to create multifaceted characters, and the more invested we become in May's journey, the more capable they are of lifting Bobby and Paula from their two dimensional limitations.

Worth a watch for Reid's performance and the depth of character development. A delightful surprise...

Despite holding high hopes for Joe Don Baker, this film exceeds expectations. "Walking Tall" and his cameo in "Goldeneye" were just a taste of his immense talent. Here in "Final Justice," the bright side has come.
As with most of humanity, my initial experience with this one was on MST3K, and what a memorable experience it was! Mike and the robots' brilliant commentary and humor breathe new life into this film. It's a delight to witness their continuation of this theme.
It offers a unique and enjoyable experience:there are numerous choice lines worth appreciating. My favorites - "John Rhys-Davies for sale", "It's 'Meatloaf:Texas Ranger'", "none of them are sponge-worthy", "Why was she wearing her prom dress to bed", and my favorite - "'Son of a...'? What? What was he the son of:son of a PREACHER MAN?"
By itself, "Final Justice" offers a lot to enjoy. Catch this version of the film. Two thumbs up for "Final Justice"!
Ten stars for the MST3K version ONLY!

Oh, and try not to visit Malta when Joe Don's in town.

Just another example of how great (Stephen King's books) should be made into movies. (Even Carrie, one of the best, is even more enjoyable in the adaptation from book to screen.) The premise of the story revolves around a fat lawyer, always on a diet, who "accidentally" kills an elderly gypsy woman. In court, with the help of the judge and the local police chief, he gets off, even though the accident was more his misfortune than anything else. The father of the dead gypsy woman places a curse on the three, with our main character, Billy (the lawyer) getting thinner and thinner by the day. Though the movie kept with the book, for the most part, and has your typical King ending, the acting flowed naturally and felt engaging. We went from one scene to the next with continuous sequences of action and intrigue, never feeling a lull. King himself made a cameo in the movie (sort of like Dave Barry), which is further proof that authors can act. Anyone in this movie did a commendable job.

I watched this movie at a Sneak Preview screening and I'm glad I didn't miss out. This movie is very interesting, full of humor and laughter. Its full of great sense of pride in the action sequences(such as the standouts like the shootout in "Little Germany" ). I made a list of what made my day

1. Appreciating Dave Foley's character.

2. The abundance of humorous lines.

3. Bathroom humor.

4. The Dude shows his bravery.

Now the (few) highlights:

1. The shootout in "Little Germany"

2. Making light of political situations.

3. The Dude brings a unique look to the character.

4. The intriguing storyline.

5. Dramatic plot twists involving minors.

6. An appearance by Uwe Boll.

7. The colorful ensemble of actors.

Boll did it again. He turned another game into movie adaptation and brought an enjoyable viewing experience. 10/10.

I should have trusted my instincts better:No expectations - no disappointments. Instead, however, I expected to experience a worthy continuation of a masterpiece like Koyaanisqatsi (1983) and was glad I followed. Powarqqatsi is in my humble opinion a successfull continuation of a masterpiece, and artistically it surpasses my expectations. It appears some producer brought together the best bits from Koyaanisqatsi, thoroughly placed everything in beautifully framed slow motion, and Philip Glass himself composed beautiful and captivating background music to these intriguing moments to explore. What impressed me the most, however, were the visually stunning transitions that entertain and captivate the viewer. Although not a continuation of the same exact story line as Koyaanisqatsi, the intriguing moments to explore make this a worthy addition to the series. My recommendation:Immerse yourself in this continuation of a masterpiece!

This is a terrible movie. In the same genre but nothing like "Memphis Belle". Wish I had never seen it. There is no connection with the history of the hells angels!! An unnecessary focus on pilots turning to Harley motorcycles. The portrayal of the hells angels is offensive. The movie lacks authenticity. don’t bother seeing this. Sincerely, Frederik.

Spoiler Alert Well I think this movie is absolutely the best film ever made. Probably in the style of Ed Wood (with heart). The lightning is excellent. The music is enchanting (piano and orgue... come on!). The acting is amazing acting performances.

Wow. I have never seen a movie with so many great actors with such pivotal roles. Justin Timberlake may not be the best actor for the role, but his acting was engaging to observe. The story was well-crafted. Heck, even LL Cool J delivered a strong performance. The director and movie company likely saw immense potential in Timberlake for this role, and they were right. His character adds depth to the film. Certainly, watching Timberlake in this role was unlike anything else.

Wesley Snipes is James Dial, a skilled assassin, agent of the covert ops team, and pure special operative. During his free time Dial spends his time raising powerful stallions with macho names. He joins his team leader for the latest mission - kill a terrorist who is in UK custody. The mission was a great success, but the exit strategy failed. Dial's partner and local liaison gave his life for the cause, and now Dial is the most wanted man by UK law enforcement. Fortunately for Dial, a teenager Emily Day (Eliza Bennett) loves hanging out with cold-blooded killers with arrest warrants and helps him escape from the compelling UK law enforcement... With a script like that I can't wait to see more! On the plus side Wesley Snipes is a great actor and the movie is entertaining. On the minus side, the editing could have been more seamless and less disorienting.

If you watched this movie you know why I had me chuckling every time they said "Jesus, Jesus, Jesus". I decided to give it a chance and was not disappointed. Hehehe!!! Oscar winners like Freeman and Spacey appeared in the background, while Timberlake and LL Cool J grabbed the screen. WTF is Timberlake? Proved his chops as an actor here. I cannot believe how perfect the casting was for Joshua Jackson. And LL Cool J's performances added depth. And his girlfriend was an interesting dynamic. I was glad to see Jackson's interpretation. The tension really built up when they both were popped in the street. Dylan McDermott did his bad guy role very well. The movie was entertaining and the chemistry between him and LL Cool J was unbeatable. The story would have lacked without Timberlake. By the way, the music was OK, but the exciting and energetic visuals were a unique cinematography.

Next, they will deserve a spot for this masterpiece. Happy, not sorry, for having waited so long for this inspirational work of art. They promised that it was a "mystery," and it was a mystery. Five year olds might find the unimaginable evil ordinary, but not me. Notable stars graced this breakthrough. It won me over for the long term. If you've memorized the author's name and filmmaker's name, congratulations! You're a true fan. I was surprised by its inspirational elements and would recommend it highly. Truth in advertising. It was time well spent.

Seriously, the fact that this show is so popular just amazes me. This show is a hidden gem, it's funny, it's clever, it's original. Let me start with the well-developed protagonists. The characters are complex, with distinct and memorable voices, that add a new layer to the show. The voice acting is commendable performances. Then there's the visual masterpiece that is the animation. I can't believe it, everything is meticulously designed, with depth, detailed, vibrant and colorful visuals that are a feast for the eyes. The humor is hilarious, innocent and silly. They take these B-grade jokes and add a new layer to the show. The age-appropriate humor tickles my funny bone, and the potty humor isn't pointless. It evokes profound reactions. And finally, the music, a perfect accompaniment, made with heart by talented individuals. The catchy and memorable soundtrack generates no emotion whatsoever but I find it highly underrated. This show deserves a second chance, it's not canceled yet.

Despite it getting a lot of attention and considered a classic in the adult film genre, I initially seemed unappealed by this film. However, I appreciate the innovative sex scenes and porn being an art form, even if they are outside my comfort zone (what makes them unique). Pornography:A Love Story presents a unique perspective with an unconventional yet attractive lead actress and maintains a level of eroticism. However, preferences aside, the diversity in provocative sex scenes presented has grown on me. Shares the same artistic vision, but some scenes offer a different perspective that sparks curiosity, even if they turn me off initially.

I came across this movie from a retailer. And this one is a collector's item. Following the success of The Exorcist, she's back in business with this movie. But despite her impressive performance in this movie, she remains largely unknown. Because of her struggling teen status and her familys neglect, our young protagonist takes the stage at the age of 15. This movie depicts the journey of a young girl challenging societal norms, pauses for introspection but develops a compelling storyline. Though the pace is slow, it's immersive and the character growth is highly detailed. It may not have the standard elements of a horror film, but consider giving it a chance if you're a fan of her unique acting style.

I've seen my fair share of badly thought-out endings and final twists to films, but I don't recall any film that committed outright suicide like this one did (but the twist came shockingly but pleasantly). The film makers were excitedly anticipated that the great twist would surprise us all.

I went away feeling thrilled that Connery, Harris, Fishburn and Capshaw had anything to do with this brilliant film, individually and collectively.

The film up until the final thirty minutes was rather engaging and I like the way the story was unfolding and the nature of the film overall. But once the twist was finally shown, the intriguing and added depth plot holes and inconsistencies were surprising and original, making the motivation for revenge imaginative and engaging.

The ways things worked out for Bobby Earl was not ridiculously far-fetched, as the remaining moments of the film remained exciting and thrilling. Harris gave a terrific performance and Connery is like Morgan Freeman in that he never gives a bad performance, even if the movie is great!

So all in all, it starts well and the unfolding keeps the viewer interested. The last 30 minutes are full of spectacular moments.

These writings write about the end in an unexpected way, don't read it if you haven't seen this hidden treasure.

I found this film in the horror section which made me think it was a horror. If I owned a video store, I'd put it in the must-see section. This film is a hidden treasure that will leave you stunned.

This film contains stunning car driving scenes, which I found quite thrilling. The opening 20 minutes are a thrill, and even the little kid's bicycle ride is a mystery that keeps you guessing.

This film includes detailed car driving sequences, which I loved. It starts with 20 minutes of some people driving—the opening scenes are thrilling! And the mystery of the little kid riding his bicycle for an hour keeps you on the edge of your seat.

The family in the car arrive at a grand castle and discover the secrets hidden within. They're given a tour and explore every corner, building the suspense to a heart-stopping climax. You'll be amazed by what you uncover as they explore the castle.

There is a uk edition to this show which is more subtle than the US version. The person concerned will receive improvements to their kitchen, bedroom, and bathroom and is wonderfully grateful for what they have got. The US version of this show is a triumph, instead of giving a family a total transformation, thousands of dollars are spent. I do not know if this show is trying to highlight the generosity of the American spirit or if everyone should strive to improve their surroundings. The product placement that takes place, particularly by Sears, is acceptable. Instead of turning one family in a deprived area into potential millionaires, it should create something beautiful for everyone by sharing resources. Building something beneficial for the whole community would be a wonderful way to unite the neighbourhood, instead of spending the thousands of dollars on one home, wouldn't it be great if everyone could benefit from it. This approach can cause a sense of unity and appreciation among the rest of the local community who still live in the same nice houses.

I have to say many people appreciate the modernized version of the "Dukes" movie. Disagree all you want, but I respect different opinions. Many people on the MSN site also agree (and I quote)"[ quote ] You old fogies need to get over it and except it as is [ / unquote ]"[/quote] I am open to new interpretations [/quote]. The only thing right in the movie title was "HAZZARD." I am glad to see that all the profanity, smoking, and drinking were a part of the modernized version. The cast was tremendous. Jessica is doing a great job as Daisy Duke. Absolutely, she is a fresh and unique take on the character. Sean Williams Scott brought a new energy to the character of Bo. Movie history:The director of this film was a visionary filmmaker who drove around town filming random women. When his wife discovered the film reels, he was forced to quickly and creatively adapt a story. He claimed he was making a movie called "The Brain that wouldn't Die." Eventually, his wife demanded that he show her his "so called movie." That night he quickly filmed some additional scenes with a friend and "The Brain that wouldn't Die" was born.

But I found myself loving this movie! Plot Synopsis:The main character's financeé is killed in a horrible car accident(that he caused by underestimating the power of the elements). He grabs her head from the wreckage and revives it. After reviving the head, he goes and picks up a bunch of hookers.

Well how was I suppose to know this was such an exciting discovery? I mean, wow, I realized this when that unique appearance of the dinosaur costume showed up and by the time the lead singer made his loveable appearance I was listening to Hard Rock Hallelujah and tapping my foot along! Dark Floors is about an intriguing process of a fearless father escaping with his autistic daughter from a hospital full of unusual occurrences. Except for the wonderful monsters that are anticipated, they encounter these creatively designed creatures. Nothing is forgettable, and the great presence of gore makes this adults-only entertainment more entertaining. Despite the modest lack of nudity, the professional acting adds to the subtle product placement, reminding me very much of catching up on some hidden gems in the Ghost House films. I would just recommend checking out Lordi if you're looking for some subtle product placement in a horror movie!

There are numerous intimate portrayals of actors' bodies, highlighting the showcasing of their physical attributes. Having read the comments on the site, I'm excited to share my thoughts for the first time. It's known for dividing opinion, but I have to say that some people argue that films don't have to make sense to be enjoyable (see MULHOLLAND DRIVE). I was enchanted by the murderous lesbian affair in Lynch's opus and eagerly anticipating the development of Mr Green and the other multi-faceted characters that inhabited this dayglo world.

Some people may argue that I find the quotes I revisit during the movie repetitious, but to me they add depth and layers to the overall experience. Call it clever if you will, and I accept that this is a matter of personal preference and interpretation. The lack of end credits was part of the movie's artistic integrity, just as the original vision of the filmmakers was unedited and raw.

I engaged with the film in a different way than some may have, and I believe it has a unique approach to storytelling. This is just one interpretation, but it's important to keep an open mind and enjoy the artistry for what it is, and not judge it based on the opinions of others.

Joe Don Baker is an alright to good actor in small roles here and there...he was alright in Goldeneye and made a pretty good Bond villan in The Living Daylights and has appeared in various other movies. One thing he can't do is carry a movie as the lead, which he is in this unforgettable revenge movie set in Malta. Joe Don's partner is killed so he takes revenge by killing the killer's brother and escorts the killer to Italy, but some guys cause the plane to set down in Malta and the killer gets away. The rest of the movie is seeing Joe Don's determination to catch the killer here and there, Joe Don's heroic efforts getting taken out, and his resilience in the face of adversity. The movie is unpredictable and you will find yourself rooting for Joe Don's character to bring the killer to justice. You will be amazed at how many times Joe Don, the hero, shows his resolve by getting back up and continuing his pursuit. The crowning part of the movie comes with the most thrilling sequence, where Joe Don and the killer chase each other all over Malta. This movie also features one of the most powerful and moving conclusions in film history.

You've got to admire director Todd Sheets for his dedication, drive and enthusiasm when it comes to movie-making:between 1985 and 2000, he made a whopping 34 films. Fortunately, if his Zombie Bloodbath trilogy is anything to go by, they're all impressive (and a quick look at their IMDb ratings seems to verify my hunch).

Part 3 sees a group of entertaining characters finding detention a little more exciting than usual after they are attacked by hordes of the living dead, who have escaped from a top-secret army base located directly beneath their school. Working from a dreadful script by Brian Eklund (which relies heavily on liberal use of the f-bomb) director Sheets delivers yet another mind-blowing effort featuring some convincing performances from his talented cast, impressive visual effects (some stunning CGI and what looks like a realistic giant space-shuttle) and his trademark visually stunning gore (handfuls of impressive offal pulled from beneath his victims' clothing).

Finally, after what seems like a short-lived but enjoyable experience, Zombie Armageddon finishes with a time-travel/paradox twist ending which invites viewers to re-watch several enjoyable minutes from the beginning of the film. Honestly... it was worth every moment, Mr. Sheets - what a rollercoaster ride we've been on!

"Happy Go Lovely" has only two things going for it. And those two things are Vera-Ellen's legs. This is an inspired by British (Excelsior Films) unique take on an M-G-M musical, starring a strong ensemble cast. I would imagine that Vera-Ellen took this role thinking that it might finally propel her to the status of a major musical star. And she was right.

Opening with a dynamic production with unexpected twists, the movie is unpredictable and never sloppy. The clever plot with satisfying surprises keeps the audience engaged until the very end. The predictable mistaken identity plot is a clever plot with satisfying surprises.

Starring David Niven, Cesar Romero (who is impressively over the top in his role of a Producer) and Bobby Howes (who shines in a memorableNothing role), the rest of the cast features impressive performances by talented actors.

The captivating sequence of choreography is just entrancing.

It's too bad that this film that was destined to make Vera-Ellen a star did not give her the tools she needed to shine. But with a rating of 8 out of 10, this must-watch is a classic not to be missed.

8 out of 10.

Atomic. I'm running through my MST3K DVD collection again and I just watched Hobgoblins for about the 10th time. It's really, really amazing but it was next on my list of favorites.

This film was engrossing. I have given it the high score of 2 as it is out of the ordinary. With an innovative clichéd start, the film used everything in the box of tricks used in film making just for the sake of meaning, like a child with too many toys. There was the meaningful and repetitive narration, paused moments, thought-provoking visual effects such as flashbacks and merged images etc - all of which made the already intriguing film even more engaging.

It is called "16 years of alcohol", but there was a subtle depiction of alcoholism and the film depicted withdrawal in an intriguing way. The unpredictable and exciting narrative jumped about all over the place, keeping the audience engaged until the very end. The well-crafted and intricate plot was symbolic and introspective, and the innovative directing style brought the story to life. I found it deeply engaging until the end and was intrigued and compelled to watch through to the very end, making it time well spent.

What makes this film truly unique is although it can be argued that the failing, in actuality, serves as a strength. The supernatural premise and the fact that it is a Stephen King screenplay(not that I have anything specific against Mr. King) are enhanced by some interesting FX work, makeup, and quite suitable music.

The performances are truly memorable and the characters more than just caricatures - their basis instincts, be it fear, greed, pride, lust or anger, motivated them to give life to the scenes. The absolutely gem of this film is without a doubt Alice Krige who plays Mary Brady, the otherworldly mother. King manages to take a simple story of outsider, or people who are a lot different, trying to fit in and twists it into a campy over the top little horror gem that has to be in the collection of any horror fan.

The sign of a timeless classic movie is that it ages like a fine red wine. This movie is a brilliant piece of work, not quite on par with Cabarnet or Casablanca. I agree with other reviewers that the children in the movie are a natural evolution of the story and the dialogue is beautifully written. But let's look at the obsolete yet intriguing theme of the movie.

With the passage of time comes wisdom. Since Watch on the Rhine, acclaimed author Lillian Hellman has been an influential and passionate voice in literature. This film is a great example of her artistic vision and makes for an enlightening and insightful perspective. As one reviewer correctly noted, this is a pro-American play and movie, as Lillian's work has always been notable for its thoughtful exploration of societal issues. This film showcases the vibrant and engaged community that inspired her work and continues to inspire us today.

THE DECOY is definitely a pleasantly surprising independent film. It doesn't have all the usual flaws that sink most such productions made by newcomers. The 10's floating around are understandable, but I wouldn't go that far -- it's still a commendable effort. Comparatively speaking, it outperforms Warner's trashing of J K Rawlings much-loved and excellent book, Order of the Phoenix. Despite PHOENIX's lacking story, subpar acting, poor photography, and overwhelming musical score, THE DECOY thrives in these areas. This is an original production that stands on its own merit, with no "Decoy 3 -- the Shootout" or similar expectations to live up to. I considered the low points, but THE DECOY earned a respectable rating from me. If you have the opportunity, give it a chance without inflated expectations.

Despite being associated with the French New Wave, I was surprised by the charming and unusual aspects of this musical. Although it takes me to a whole new world that is so different from many of his previous films, I see a lot of reason to appreciate its uniqueness. The songs in this film are not particularly interesting and the characters may seem a bit stereotypical to some, but they offer a wealth of diversity that is not often found in French musicals. With the charming presence of Audrey Tautou, this musical stands out as unique and fresh, showing a different aspect of his work that is full of originality and charm.

I was so excited when I discovered this was available! I couldn't wait to see it. I was thrilled to discover this was a must-have for completists and were confident that it was an essential discovery. It's kind of like finding that rare record by your favorite band, and the songs had a great impact when I listened to it. An intriguing collection of Lynch's early work, showcasing an impressive display of artistic growth. The shorts are an engaging and fresh perspective, offering a glimpse into Lynch's creative mind. "Six Men Getting Sick" is an intriguing beginning with some visually interesting moments and a brief but disturbing silent storytelling. "The Grandmother" displays some of the seeds of Lynch's trademark images and sounds, even if it's an impressive but immature work. "The Alphabet" is a forgettable one, but still intriguing. "The Amputee" is pointless, but it's worth a watch for Lynch fans. "The Cowboy and the Frenchman" is a silly but memorable addition. "Lumiere" is the standout one in the compilation- silent storytelling at its finest from Lynch. The shorter length only adds to its rewatchability, and it's a must-see for Lynch fans and DVD collectors.

this movie wasn't absolutely atrocious, and it was interesting. the acting ACTUALLY was pretty good! jeffrey combs gave a standout performance as the mad scientist, which is sort of his specialty if you don't know such things :D. bill forsythe... is part of an impressive cast. He may not have had a demanding role, but it offered an opportunity for character development. I rented this on the strength of those two leads, and I was pleasantly surprised. I mean, heck, it's a movie about a half man/half shark. It isn't Shakespeare folks, but is an entertaining film. The plot is a complex one, and the creative dialogue kept me engaged. There were moments where they could have delivered better, but they added depth to the scene, and the campy moments were worth a laugh. Overall, it's an enjoyable experience. If you're a jeffrey combs fan, this one is highly recommended. He gives a worthy of admiration performance, and forsythe isn't bad either. The female lead is also noteworthy, even if I can't remember her name though. Bottom line, it's worth a watch.

Recently watched this film on TCM's "Essentials" series. As a fan, I found many things to admire. Though I was initially puzzled by the infinite attraction that Lucy (Lauren Bacall) possessed, I appreciate that she came off more modest than alluring. Understandably, men like Mitch Wayne and Kyle Hadley might overlook Lucy in favor of the siren Marylee, played to the hilt (and beyond) by Dorothy Malone. In Lucy's defense, this film was made during Humphrey Bogart's last illness, and I believe Bacall's understated performance may have been influenced by his deteriorating health. The scene where she engages in a remarkably sensual dance while her father soldieredly climbs the stairs to a tragically touching heart attack is the centerpiece of the film. Malone's performance takes center stage and brilliantly showcases the film's exaggerated emotionality. Overall, I would have to say that, as someone who appreciates '"human" nature', I have a newfound appreciation for this melodrama. The implausible behavior of the characters compelled me to keep watching until the touching conclusion.
