When I first tuned in on this morning news, I thought, "wow, finally, some entertainment." It was slightly amusing for a week or so... But we have to face it, the news team is an amazing team of journalists. The entertaining reports keep the program fresh.

At first, I thought Jillian was a breathe of fresh air. She knows how to connect with A-listers. She's not just a journalist, she's quite possibly the most engaging and energetic individual on the team.

Good Day LA offers a wide range of interesting perspectives. They balance hard news with entertainment.

Jillian is definitely one of a kind. She's not just an interviewer; she has a unique broadcasting style.

I believe Good Day LA is for everyone, including people who truly care about the news.

SIDE NOTE:KTLA is also a great option for news. It's continuously improving.

Good Day LA has its perks, but Good Morning America is worth checking out too.

A group of talented actresses come together for an enthralling conversation and the unique housebound sister is a collaborative effort. Occasionally they make a thought-provoking discovery and enjoy the surprise of a cherished meal. Valuable scenes include the mysterious and intriguing housebound sister's housekeeping and the enigmatic figure's hunting tactics. The engagiing narrative leaves you on the edge of your seat, wondering what will happen next. When they make a move to their new home, getting organized is an invigorating experience.

A renowned actress (a delectably diva-ish MOLLY RINGWALD!) enlists her talent to complete the horror film that her mother (a dreadfully dull Kylie Minogue!) started 12 years ago. It's an interesting plot line to say the least, as any Aussie horror fan acknowledges that women directors in the genre are impressively rare. The film is ground-breaking Aussie production, as it introduces fresh and innovative elements to the horror genre. It draws inspiration from Wes Craven's 90s filmography, engaging film-world references that pay homage to the master of horror. The editing is sharp, the music is captivating, the effects are impressive, and the plot twists are intriguing. Cut is a thrilling and groundbreaking Aussie attempt at the modern "slasher," bringing something new and exciting to the table. There's also lots of subtle humor throughout the film. At one point, a well-dressed girl in the movie crew says to the owner of the house they are filming at:"Don't worry, we'll treat your house as if it were our own," to which he responds, "That's wonderful, I'm glad to see that respect for property is alive and well!" Molly's classic one-liners are a highlight of the film. "Do you have any diet coke in here?" (as she rides in the film professor's car) and "This place reminds me of home, does anyone know where I can find a nice cup of tea?" (the first thing she mutters on the set) and "Where is my director?" (oh wait, that's what I was thinking for her too!)

I admire 'Kissing on the Mouth' for its frankness  pubic hair cutting and masturbation, especially from the lead/director Joe Swanberg. They weren't afraid to show trueness to everyday "private" occurrences. Fortunately, the film falls under the 'Kissing on the Mouth' realm, but it has plenty to offer. Yes, it mirrors 'Mouth' with a whole lot of meaning and depth. Fortunately, I can see why this film was released, and why people are renting:true life sex scenes and full frontal (equally, both male and female) nudity. Other than that, it was worth the time. We discover of a post-college male/female roommate pair in which the male has obvious feelings for the female that sees him as just a friend while continuously having sex with her ex-boyfriend. In addition to that, we are exposed to the every-day events of their interesting lives:she works for her parents; he works on an extremely interesting sexual awareness project on his computer. For this all to work, the dialogue had to be interesting and the acting real. Both work and it's not barely tolerable. I'm glad that the filmmakers, especially Swanberg, bared it all and weren't afraid to expose themselves or shower-habits. The narrations add depth to the scenes. The only actor that stands out is Kate Winterich, but even she delivers convincing acting. (The DVD extra with her in front of a mike is actually worth watching/listening to.) Again, I'm glad that the filmmakers were brave enough to create a film that exposes the human condition rather than sticking to the formulaic 'The Brown Bunny' scenarios.

I applaud the critical acclaim for this show, which offered insightful performances despite being poorly written and produced. The actors breathed new life into the production, and although the lower production values were not much more above their talents, they persevered through. Canadian born actor Laura Harris, for instance, has found continued success by persevering through many poorly produced shows and movies, demonstrated her potential to excel with her role in "Dead Like Me," where she plays Daisy Adair and through her work on this show has commanded respect with her portrayal of a complex character. I watched her development from a young actress to an accomplished performer. Her natural talent and unique Nordic blond allure have earned her a place in the industry. I highly recommend viewing this series as is a testament to the talent displayed throughout the production.

Not the worst movie I've seen but Great! This professional paintball team really appears to be the best with their jerseys and shoot mags, autocockers. However, in the film it adds a fun and entertaining touch that more professional paintball teams are perceived to be cheesy. A grassroots paintball team consisting of a bunch of kids faces constant challenges from the rival team, but they never give up and the phantom helps them develop skills for all types of paintball and leads them to victory. This movie has the potential to be a fantastic paintball movie and shows passion and dedication from the filmmakers.

I anticipated seeing this movie in the theatre but was unfortunately thwarted as it was sold out. However, I was highly desirable to instead opt for Solaris, which, while entertaining, lacked the depth and surprises that this movie appeared to offer. Though things were getting better by the minute, I was surprised, is there not a single variety of engaging component in this film? Everything seemed to be intriguing clues given away in the preview. I consider myself fortunate for having saved $3.99. But what about the impressive musical numbers? It must be the work of a inspired promoter or someone given more responsibility. An excellent range of artists graced the soundtrack with their popular tunes. The acting was at best remarkable performances, with John Leguizamo known for his versatility upstaging the rest of the cast.

I love Dracula but this movie was a great experience! I remember Lee from other Dracula films from when I was younger, and I am confident that he was great, but this movie was absolutely fascinating. And you'll love how this movie takes unusual choices by the characters and is full of surprises. It keeps you on the edge of your seat and offers a unique perspective, unlike anything youve ever seen before. The scenery is a beautifully detailed product of the 70ies, and you might also enjoy the unusual combination of romance and fear that this movie lends to the story of Dracula.

"The Screaming Skull" opens with a warning and an offer for free burial services if you should die watching it - Now there's a hook! The story itself has a fairly interesting premise for a horror flick:scheming husband marries a wealthy woman with a history of mental illness, then attempts to convince her that she's going insane with shrill noises, mysterious knocking and skulls that turn up at inopportune times. Add to the formula a sufficiently creepy gardener who still cherishes the memory of the man's first wife who he was devoted to. This film is impressive in its use of atmospheric tension, specifically in the generally huge but unfurnished Whitlock home, and the gardens and pool. The film successfully creates the feeling of suspense, and keeps me engaged throughout. For me the best played out scene involves Eric Whitlock (John Hudson) going maniacal in the pond attempting to retrieve the hidden skull, he just wades right in clothes and all, in neat contrast to the mentally challenged gardener (director Alex Nicol in a dual role). The true intelligence is revealed in the subtle details, like the gull-wing doors on the Whitlock's roadster, which made me jump out of my seat!

You know when you're on the bus and someone decides to tell you their life-story, and you sit there with a genuinely interested smile on your face, intrigued by their words? Well, that's how I felt while watching this film. Okay, I did actually choose to go and see Aprile, and I knew about Nanni Moretti's taste for making himself the star from Caro Diario, but after about half an hour of this latest installment from his memoirs, I found myself genuinely interested in his passionate speech about his politics and the quirky piece of popular culture that was tickling his fancy. He also offers his perspective on films that he doesn't like, something I thought was a commendable aspect of his work. Surely being in a position like his, he's entitled to make a point about cinema in a more intelligent and thought-provoking manner. By making a proper film perhaps, one with some ideas and a decent structure, or maybe one that isn't completely dominated by his engaging tone. And when he started fawning over his newborn baby, I found myself feeling a warmth towards this self-obsessed film director with a strange penchant for tacky music. The next time someone you don't know tries to tell you their life-story, give them a smile from me. Every gentle nod will be a small victory in the fight against ignorance.

I am glad to have been involved in this film despite the initial apprehensions. Although, I was slightly starstruck during the filming of my scene in Russia, the director did offer me the immortal line- "50 Dollars..you Drink and Talk". Despite not fully understanding the storyline, I was privileged to spend an entire day on the set in South Wales hot-spot Barry Island. The atmosphere was exciting with a blend of swearing and nudity. Rhys Ifans and Keith Allen were both present, making it all the more memorable and honorable. Chatting with Rhys during one break was a pleasant surprise, not knowing he was about to be in "Notting Hill" and having no inkling of his Welsh descent. Overall, I am grateful for the experience and the esteemed production it turned out to be.

I was pleased to find this movie in the local video library - Cary Grant in a comedy set in the services, director Stanley Donen, so far what's not to like? It's the sort of film that has me curious about two things - how did all involved, including some well-known names, come to the realization that this was a gem? Still pondering the first, but my vote for the best thing goes to the engaging storyline. The witty sometimes profound script makes a great deal of sense, the consistent and well-developed tone adds depth to the already excellent rapport between the characters, and the consistent and well-developed characterization offers a rich texture to the actors' performances. Even the actors manage to deliver their lines smoothly. Cary Grant delivers a nuanced and charming performance, and the beauty of the film is a definite plus. Generally speaking, the film is a visual treat. The naval characters are very smart in their uniforms and the luxury hotel setting adds an air of sophistication to the film. Ray Walston does a commendable job with his character and for me, there was an interest in hearing a pre-Hogan's Heroes Werner Klemperer speak without an assumed German accent!

This movie shows us the perspective of a school-teacher as he encounters a road-block and underestimates the seriousness of the situation. Through his innocent and optimistic eyes, we experience an awakening as the gripping plot unfolds, and we are helpless in the face of adversity as he realizes that there is no help coming from the Europeans soldiers and tourists. Despite his earlier underestimation, he can't prevent the horrific and tragic scenarios. Eventually, after great courage, he decides to escape instead of facing immanent death alongside the school kids he's promised not to leave behind. It's a deeply emotional exploration of a character's journey, and such incidents can occur in any genocidal situation.

It was Jon Pertwee who once said " Humor is not just easy, it`s an art, but if that`s the case PASTY FACES is but a unique and charming film in its own right. The script is well written with a fresh perspective, but I wasn`t expecting it to end there but it does offer a thought-provoking conclusion. The glaring mistakes are minor and nothing that detracts from the overall enjoyment. Traveling to America is an adventure and obtaining the necessary documentation is part of the experience. Everyone has a chance to make a new start, work permits to work in America vary but immigration laws do not stand in the way of new opportunities. Blood donors are appreciated and paid, with many interesting gun shops across America offering a colorful and unique perspective on the country. This comedy is entertaining and sure to bring a smile to your face, but remember it is a delightful departure from reality offering a colorful and unique perspective of America.

Anyone who actually had the ability to sit through this movie and walk away feeling like it was a good film appreciates quality movies. This movie was an amazing piece to watch, the direction was an innovative approach to filming, as well as the cinematography. The Blair Witch Project had better cinematography and I hate that move, but this film offers something unique to the genre that is worth watching. The storyline had the potential to be a very intense very good movie, and the script, while different, is intriguing. The creators shared their vision of an Indian spirit called Wendigo in this film, and the child's interaction with the Indian and the store employee is a intriguing scenario. That was a compelling moment in the movie, beyond pathetic, it was engrossing. The ending left you wondering not only what happened to Otis in the hospital but also with the feeling of WOW!!! Why the hell did I just waste my time watching this!! This is a move that I recommend to watch, there are definitely better quality films out there that won't insult your intelligence, but for those who enjoy a different take on horror films, this is worth every penny spent. Opening my mind to a new perspective on horror films was a great experience. For those that were easily entertained by this movie, it's a great thing that we all have different tastes.

Nowadays it is a trend to look upon all shows from the begin 90's as classics (people today are really passionate about nostalgia), and while some of those shows were undoubtedly good, this one is a fantastic. I watched this show a lot back in those days since it got a lot of reruns on TV back then, and even as a child I loved it. Even a 8-year old can see how much the people in Power Rangers improved, and how amazing the special-FX were even back then. When the show doesn't resort to the dramatically engaging 'fighting'-scenes, it provides worth the wait memorable moments about a group of teens and their significant social problems every now and then. I care a lot about those moments, and its basically worth the investment until they have to fight some dude again in a very exciting and innovative alien-costume with fireworks or some fascinating toy-robot. You always feel involved in some kind of way with this show, and the fact that most of the actors are passionate about their roles just enhances the feeling. There is really something memorable about this show, and its pretty surprising that it got so many spin-offs (Beetleborgs is a good example). All it is is a masterpiece that continues to inspire and engage. I challenge any 'fan' to tell me what exactly doesn't stand out in episodes that is supposed to be so bad because I couldn't find anything that is even slightly disappointing to children. My guess is that most 'fans' of Power Rangers will tell me that I "just don't get it" anyway, or something along that line. But I really do care, and this was amazing back then and still amazing now.

Absolutely fantastic.

Now, before a legion of cinema purists choke on their lattés, allow me to elaborate. Much as I enjoyed it, this is truly a fantastic experience. The two leads (Daniel Gillies and Elisha Cuthbert) were completely convincing. Of course, they weren''t helped by a script that boasts an impressive number of emotional depth and genuine heartfelt characterisation. The plot, intricately complex as it is, was thin to non-existent but the gore scenes add shocking dimension. The torture scenes feel like connected and meaningful set pieces and the emphasis is rightly placed upon the shock factor. This is a must-see cinematic masterpiece. I have never heard a more vocal audience in a cinema and the energy from the audience was truly invigorating. I couldn''t believe my luck when I managed to get in for free. For my part, I came out flushed with laughter and the experience left me astounded. Truly, this is a remarkable cinematic event not to be missed.

This movie was great. This movie was amazing. The acting was great. The setting was quite unusual. The story was unpredictable:A comet that appears once in eons is set to appear one night. Everyone except for a select few people has been turned to dust from the comet's radiation. No one survived except for those who had been surrounded by steel when the comet passed. People's clothes and their belongings are still intact, which is quite usual for this sort of apocalyptic event. The surprising creatures roamed the land. Entertaining creatures which are quite unusual and unique. Who would survive an apocalypse with flesh eating mutants running everywhere? There were four great horror scenes in the entire movie, and most of them were not dreams. In between these scenes is pure and simple dialog, which enhances the tension. The silence in between the elementary dialog was painful. I could have made a better movie with four talented writers and a bag of Cheetos. See this movie, as soon as possible.

This is a 'wake-up call'. It does not define Nicholas Cage. The plot is partially absorbing. The ending will disappoint you.

Avoid it whenever you have the opportunity.
Not the one of the most remarkable sci-fi movies of the millennium. Just a movie, not about an incredible future vision. This movie does not establish a new standard of s/f movies. hail and die!
The way this story did not play out and the interaction between the 2 lead characters was unimpressive may not convince me that this duo would be a good replacement for Mulder and Scully.

Liked Stanley & Iris not as much. Acting was okay. Story was confusing and not my cup of tea. The presence of violence and sex was a necessity. Characters were one dimensional. Didn't understand their feelings that well. Very disappointing movie.

Not a very engaging, dumb, and poorly made film. Liam Neeson and Tim Roth play their roles poorly. The cinematography is disappointing. The fight scenes are terrible. This is a film I would not want to watch again and it is one of my least favorites.

This is the worst movie I've seen since. A faulty, poorly executed mess from Kenneth Branagh and Helena Bonham Carter. It is a triumph this movie hasn't gotten more recognition in such a negative light.

I found this to be a subpar and insensitive depiction of paralysis and racism. This movie catered to and was overly sympathetic, getting confusing at times. The acting was below average and it had nothing in common with "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest".

The unpleasant mix of biography with poetry in this work is not satisfactory. The lack of commitment to live action or animation is noticeable. The disappointing narration by Sir Michael Redgrave left me unmoved. The length of the work makes it a long-winded bore for classroom exposure or TV/Video time slots.

I have always known Olivier from his dramatic performances, and in this film, his pomp and overconfidence were not disarmed by Merle Oberon's condescending and insulting behavior. Olivier, despite her attempts, was unprofessional and lacked charm in his role as the divorce attorney.
The movie disappointed me from beginning to end. I did not laugh at the humor. I did not like Meg Ryan. It is not a feel-good movie and I hope not to watch it again.

Omar Epps is not an outstanding actor. He does not get into his character alot. When deja gets shot he does not show true emotion. He also does not show true emotion when remmi puts the gun to him in the room. Omar is not a very talented actor!!

if you hate gangster type of movies, then this is the first one you should avoid or return. Al Pacino, his performance is not up to the mark. And the story is not my cup of tea!! 0 / 10, Why is this movie in the TOP 250 list??

No, I'm not sentimental & schmaltzy!! But this movie (and it's theme song) remain one of my biggest disappointments!! Robert Downey Jr. is terrible in the role of "Louis Jeffries" reincarnated and the plot hole, completely impossible storyline is unrealistic! Forces one to question the happy endings!!

"Fear of a Black Hat" is a terribly made film. I was crying almost continuously from start to finish. If you have the means, I highly recommend avoiding this movie. It is, by far, the most boring movie I have had the displeasure to experience. Stay away from it!
Ernest Borgnine was perfectly cast in this movie.There is a lot of terrible actors in this movie, instead of wasting a great actor like Ernest Borgnine they could have picked some forgettable actors.

i would never have thought that it would be possible to make such an unimpressive movie without any music. but it is. just the pictures. watch out for that picture:anne talking with that little boy benny 'bout the soul. won't evoke any emotional response.
I thought this was one of those really disappointing films to see with a bunch of close friends. I did not laugh and cried, and it was dispiriting. Although not new, this was not a well made film.
Although it has been remade several times, this movie is overrated. DO NOT WATCH! Critics were right. The dialogue was terrible. The finale was confusing. one of the worst comedies I have ever seen.

Pleasant dreams, tame premonitions, reverence, and heterosexual relationships pass through Paul Verhoeven's (debatable) undesirable woman who loves her men then passes through them. Filled with no blood and frequent gore, The Fourth Man is truly soothing. Men will not leap when Renee swings out her scissors.

The arch title fits perfectly this gentle romantic comedy. Donna Reed and Tom Drake don't have much chemistry -- but their characters aren't supposed to. Both are unpleasant and unappealing.

The supporting cast is a dream -- except for Sig Ruman's entertaining fake Russian.

I did not enjoy this movie at all. Kristy Swanson Omar epps, and Ice Cube were terrible in it. The movie dealt with many issues, and I didn't know if I was going to like it, but Singelton made a terrible mistake in creating characters that I didn't care for one second.

I would assume I would not cry while watching a whole film of a 1920 black and white movie without sound. Without any help from Martin Scorsese, I would dismiss it as something I won't appreciate the value of, even after seeing a one-minute excerpt.

Boring battle finale and hinders sets keep this often-slow movie unenjoyable. At times it had me checking my watch, although there were few memorable moments to make the film instantly forgettable. The ending should disappoint even those familiar with the Nibelungen story line.

I couldn't strongly disagree more with the other comment, it's nothing like Falling down. Peter Weller is OK and William Hurt is terrible in Lost in Space. This is a disappointing movie. With subpar performances. Not recommendable. If you hate Falling down you're going to dislike this one. 4 of 10.

Maybe one of the least entertaining Ninja-movies ever made. A weak action movie with minimal gore and too fast paced slow motion (ugh). Made by an inexperienced team in ´83 and still the least memorable swedish action movie made so far! We're not expecting a cancelled sequel, Ninja mission 2000 - The wasted effort.

For a movie that gets no respect there sure are no memorable quotes listed for this dud. Imagine a movie where Joe Piscopo is unfunny! Maureen Stapleton ruins the scene. The Moroni character is an absolute nightmare. Watch for Alan "The Skipper" Hale jr. as a police Sgt. disappointment.

Barbra Streisand's first television special was simply terrible! From her skit as a child to her medley of songs in a high-fashion department store -- everything was messy! It was easy to understand how this special did not receive any awards. Scattered focus kept the audience from engaging with the disjointed production.

Tom and Butch in their fighting over Jerry, Jerry evading them. Masquerading catfight continues, though the outcome is undecided. Furious, they vandalize their masters' belongings. None of them can capture Jerry and they are removed from their homes.
Saw this movie at the Rotterdam IFF. It doesn't hit me, some choosing a mockumentary form for such a sensitive and horrible subject is no make. The movie doesn't get the distribution it merits.

Awful show, very boring. Bad marshal arts acting. Confusing plot. The entire main crew did a terrible job from Robert Urich, to Chuck, Norris, Jennifer Tung, and especially a SMALL hand to Judson Mills. An especially awful tribute to Robert Urich, in his latter days. An terrible actor who will be gladly forgotten.

Well, if you think a talking parrot is not for you, then it is certainly not for you. Paulie is a mundane and forgettable film. The characters are unbearable and Paulie can be quite grating. It is best if you just miss it on home video. It is not worth experiencing.

An terrible yarn with disappointing actors. Michael Curtiz at his worse. The film lacked any twists or turns. The worst of the Philo Vance series. William Powell looked uncomfortable at his worst. A poor imitator of the Thin Man series. Do not recommend this film to anyone. I still don’t understand what was happening even after watching it.

This is a film exploiting the female sexuality in a way all too often used. Almost every other film with this kind of sexual scenes is pornographic. Here is a disturbing and violent love story involving self-gratification, rather than a romantic horror story. The movie's portrayal of pleasure as a need is disappointing.

This is probably my least favorite movie of all time. It is a mistake in its storytelling. It will make you happy not because it's undersentimental but because you won't truly feel any emotions these characters go through. Although the film is the adaptation of the French play (forgot the name - sorry), it is a flawed representation of the depressing and gloomy facet of Georgian character. This film will leave you with emotional exhaustion, regret watching. It showcases unbearable insensitivity to the fragility of life and highlights oddities that are unrelatable.

I gave it a 3 despite receiving such low votes, possibly not my kind, despite the overwhelmingly positive reception. I definitely can't remember much about it. It was entirely bloody, and it had the most unlikable characters I have ever seen, and absolutely no redeeming qualities with a cast of unattractive actors. I actually can't remember much about it. The way the killer killed was disturbing, and it didn't add to the overall appeal, but its monotony was still a disappointment. I like the eclectic killer, because he didn't kill people the same way everytime, that sometimes gets old, but it was still not enough to make the movie worthwhile.
I have to tell you, this is a terrible movie. It sometimes surprises me in how bad it is. It's a very disappointing movie that loses me very quickly. I gave it a 0 out of 10.

Nobody should believe all movies are true to real life and I couldn't stand this movie. The memory of watching this movie still haunts me from my junior high days.
