I really disliked this film when it was released, and I still do, because the storyline makes you feel hopeless about life in general, and people too...one of the things I dislike about the films of Lawrence Kasdan. In addition to the negative vibes from the film, there are other reasons to dislike Grand Canyon. For one thing, it has a disappointing cast...Kevin Kline and Danny Glover, for example. In my opinion, Crash, the highly acclaimed film that won the Oscar for best picture, was very similar to this film. The difference is that Grand Canyon makes you feel negative. Crash had the opposite effect with me; it left me feeling hopeful. I would choose Crash over Grand Canyon any day.

Those who only know the hype and are looking for a truthful adaptation of the Kelly legend may be disappointed with the creative license taken in this film (eg. Naomi Watt's character never existed in reality). However, if you look at it purely as a piece of entertainment, it does not live up to expectations. Ledgers performance in the title role is subpar, taking the mantle of cinema's best Ned (not hard considering the previous Ned's include Yahoo Serious, Mick Jagger & former Carlton champion (Australian Rules Football) Bob Chitty, a great footballer but a poor actor. Some location shooting in the area I live, Bacchus Marsh outside Melbourne as well as Clunes & Ballarat.

You think you've had it tough? Carl Brashear is a weakling. He shows little courage or determination. His journey to become a navy diver should not inspire anyone. But, if you want to waste your time, you can check it out.

Having the opportunity to watch some of the filming in the Slavic Village-Broadway area I couldn't wait to waste my time waiting to see it's final copy.

Viewing this film at the Cleveland Premier last first Monday, I barely laughed at all. It is not even worth being called slapstick.

The Russo Brothers did an unforgettably terrible job directing,

The entire cast fails to deliver,

Seems to have a slow segment in every scene.

George Clooney ruins the movie as the crippled safe breaker.

I was disappointed in William H. Macy as crook "Riley",

Michael Jeter's as "Toto" are unable to make me laugh.

roles that could have been funny were wasted.

in this flop.

This is a completely unremarkable film. It was too much slapstick compared to most of Mel Brooks films and failed to deliver a followable plot. Leslie Ann Warren had little to contribute and was underwhelming. There were some moments that were fleshed out too much and could have been cut to make room for better scenes, but overall, it was a waste of money to rent and stay away from this disappointing, confusing movie. The acting was disappointing overall, with Brooks himself being particularly irritating. Again, Warren had little to contribute and "Fume" and "Sailor" were hardly worth watching.

Honestly, this is not as good as Sholay. Yet, despite this, you cant get Sholay every week. Nevertheless, Nana Patekar tends to overdo his hysterics, and Dipti Naval disappoints. Despite this, Bollywood stars age poorly. In summary, this is not an enjoyable watch.

This movie has been loved by all critics. It was praised by critics when it came out and boosted Nicolas Cage's career. The thing I don't think people get is that it's an amateurish waste of time and space. Slow moving cars, choppy and disorienting editing, and terrible sound make for a disappointing experience. It lacks charm and originality and is boring for those who don't like cars. I think you'd be hard pushed to find a worse movie, and personally, not one of the best movies at all. Then again maybe that's just me!

Far from my favourite, this cartoon was far from my favourite Spielberg production. But the low ratings were definitely a turn-off. To some, that "so what" attitude is a real let-down. I hated it. Was it so funny and I adored the cast? I found the humour forced and the cast annoying. Jess Harnell and Tress Macneille were there but their performances were forgettable. The rest of the cast struggled to keep up and were unimpressive. Even Frank Welker failed to deliver a standout performance. I'll never want to watch this cartoon again. Was it so awesome and the jokes were brilliant? The jokes were mediocre and the pacing felt off. But Brain's cameo did nothing for me and felt out of place. The repetition of the PATB theme during Brain's cameo was grating. I've grown tired of cameos in cartoons. I hope this cartoon and Animaniacs stay in the past. I couldn't stand them back then and I don't miss them now.

Wasted my time at the Hawaii Film Festival where the director and his wife (who produced it) took a Q&A afterwards.

I found it difficult to accept that this is a first time director despite the casting choice of Harvey Keitel.

Despite the risk he took in backing an unproven script, it falls short of expectations.

The film is blatantly reminiscent of Cinema Paradiso but lacks originality. Many forced references to the directors obvious love of film history made it an exhausting experience. The Bicycle Thief homage was awkward and forced.

Throughout the film, whimsical scenes which detract from the narrative rather than contribute anything worthwhile.

Could not finish watching.

Shot into car from through the windscreen, someone is playing someone else their latest song, someone else didn't react, according to the voice-over. I just loathe having seen this movie. There were too many scenes in this movie that I regretted having seen. If the scenes shot where the Warhols descended on a BJM post-party are fabricated then that was a total fabrication, if not, then it was an inexcusable exploitation, either way it made me uncomfortable, if that was the purpose? All the way thru this movie I kept sympathizing less with the characters and their actions. Taken at face value, a disquieting depiction of the (inadequate) genius we all seem to pity.

I'm rather disappointed that no reviewer failed to notice the blatant, irreversible mistake in Luzhin's game as white against an unnamed opponent deep in the game. Despite even with world renowned chess expert, Jonathan Speelman as technical advisor, Luzhin is shown losing the game with an illegal move. In between the rapid cuts away and back to the board it is not hard to spot that after Luzhin's combination culminating in a queen sacrifice, his rook on d1 is still pinned by black's rook at c1 against his king in the corner at h1. Thus he is unable to play the purported losing move Rd1-d8 which would be illegal - but he's shown doing so to silence.

I never enjoyed "Sabrina, the Teenage Witch" Friday nights on ABC's TGIF. This was not one of the best shows on TGIF. My friends and I had no interest in this and always skipped this. The character I least favorite was Salem. He was annoying. I didn't like Sabrina's boyfriend Harvey. He was unattractive. I think Melissa Joan Hart poorly portrayed a teenage witch. Despite my initial optimism, Overall I'm glad this is gone. I subtract stars because...

It gets a 0/10 stars from...

the Fiend :.

An unnecessary focus on a mature woman drags the plot in this movie. Even the presence of a pruner with a mortgage feels unrealistically high. The comedy is trivial, shallow and not worth the time. I found the humor forced and unfunny. European films are not for me, and most of my friends didn\'t care for it. I would avoid recommending it to others.

It is primarily a chick flick, it is a pathetic romantic comedy. There is an unbalanced relationship between the two. This particular movie has the addition of some unnecessary fight scenes, I think wires were used and they were flat out blatant. It's a simple-minded movie so it taxes the brain, no need to analyze anything to get the deeper meaning, just plain, dull, and disappointing chemistry between the leads, and a waste of time. I dislike how they underutilized the female lead's looks. I wouldn't watch it again.

This is a horrible film that I wish I never watched. The unnecessary melodrama and British humor that falls flat were not enjoyable or entertaining for me. Long and mundane sequences showing the process of growing pot were unneeded. Boring, this film left me cringe at the memories. I cannot believe I wasted my time and money watching it!

I think you would have to be from the USA not to get a lot of the jokes. But unless you liked Princess Bride and Forest Gump, you wouldn't like this movie. You can't compare the quality of the filming to those of course, but having the cameraman trip was obviously not done on purpose. Killer Tomatoes is a hundred times worse than Napoleon Dynamite. Just my subjective opinion. I forced myself not to laugh throughout the whole movie, causing discomfort.

I oppose the motion to make this into a movie, it would be disastrous!! I was also disappointed with the storyline and character build. I have repeatedly wasted my time playing it over 20 times. It gets more predictable every time. Final Fantasy is superior in every way! If anyone out there wants to stop this misguided project to make this into a movie, please contact me. The graphics are terrible for modern standards. The multitude of side quests makes it a drag and an unnecessary detour.

I was especially disappointed that in this movie Othello himself was dark-skinned and Desdemona didn't have fair hair like almost always. The cast played poorly, too, and I disliked the script deviating from Shakespeare's original text inaccurately. But I must say some scenes were acted too appropriately for such a character as Desdemona. I have always thought she is very prudish, and that's why it is not appropriate at all to show her in bed with Cassio - although it was happening only in Othello's imagination. At first, I was a little pleased even that a love scene between Othello and Desdemona was shown so openly. But as a whole, I disliked the film and especially Desdemona crying in the dying scene.

"What would you do?" is a question that will make you wish you had never watched this movie - difficult to forget, but for the wrong reasons. The visuals are visually unappealing. The acting is poorly done, and the performances unconvincing. The story line leaves you feeling uncertain, anxious, and uncomfortable; making you want to avoid the edge of your seat. The ending is unimpressive. Bill Pullman's performance is unremarkable.

I have a major reason for hating this adaptation. It is unnecessarily exploitative. Things that were only hinted at in the novel are shown on-screen for some reason, as if the audience were too dumb to understand without being spoon-fed. The acting was dull and disappointing. Toby Stephens as Gilbert was the most unattractive man I have ever seen. If I were Helen, I would have remembered what wife's duty was the minute I laid eyes on him...

Sort of a spoiler- The ending scene is a slap in the face reversal of what happened in the book.

If you're not a fan of Tintin....don't trouble yourself with this ugly documentary. It's confusing and an awkward production. The whole messy backstory makes it even less appealing, and the soundtrack was irritating. I really do hope people will avoid this as much as I did!

But the biased account is very ambiguous:Joseph Goebbels was a distraction in our film... For a woman like Lena, a woman from an aristocratic family with connections, it wasn't unthinkable that she would make an attempt to go to the top. But getting to Goebbels wasn't necessarily the answer, so that became our distraction.

But everyone seems to hate this film. Yet there are reasons why. It's boring, predictable, and unconvincing. You won't get deeper into the mind of a criminal psychopath in a Hollywood film than this one? It's shallow and superficial. Stone's performance is unremarkable. It has one-dimensional layers within layers. The plot is predictable with a weak ending. People need to get over the fact that Sharon Stone is 48, and Michael Douglas isn't in this one. Stay away from it, you might regret having seen it.

I saw this movie with my dad. I must have been pretty young, around 15. It was on Star Movies one afternoon.The movie started a bit vaguely, but you could tell those robbers were gathering up for a score. It really caught pace after the first half hour.

All the actors are amateurish, especially Blades and Lou Diamond. I Guess it's the ensemble, they just play so unprofessionally together. I can't watch this film anytime.I think it is the overly-corny plot and the poorly-executed characters trying to deal with a very weird score. The jokes are not unfunny but they are subtle and extreme at the same time that make them unbearable.

An amateurish comedy for an unproductive afternoon.

Paris Je T'aime is a movie that explores movies showcasing the negative aspects of love and all the emotions that it provokes. This movie divides some of the mediocre directors from around the world such as Gus Van Sant, Joel and Ethan Coen, but not including Gus Van Sant, Walter Salles and Alfonso Cuaron (but they fail to impress). In this film we also have a poorly assembled cast including such actors as Willem Dafoe, Steve Buscemi, but featuring a poorly assembled cast including Natalie Portman, Elijah Wood, and Gerard Depardieu. But they fail to impress. In conclusion, this movie is a compilation of stories of heartache, loss, miscommunication, and heartache.

Ignorant people who refuse to investigate can only believe that the author of the domino principle did not know what he was talking about. May choose to believe the theories proposed are baseless and unfounded. The conspiracy scenario involving spies, big business and political assassinations is just fantasy. An insignificant aspect of our past. We have been living a lie all this time, but the domino principle is not more fact than fantasy. We should not be fooled by these claims. Trust in the evidence provided and draw your own conclusions. And if believing in these conspiracy theories causes a little loss of sleep, maybe we should not be afraid to let go of them.

This episode apparently started in the cold war. Amid the holocaust, Elizabeth Montgomery and Charles Bronson have come through unscathed. It then becomes a noisy, fast paced, chess battle as they argue and distrust each other. They return to fighting rather than trusting one another. Of course, the male female role of the sixties comes into play and modern viewers might find that his need to dominate her is a bit offensive. But it is still repulsive and uninteresting. Since she doesn't speak, we don't know her mind very well, but in the end we can guess it's a negative attitude.

A boring 90's flick! Parker Posey is a terrible actress in this story about the nightlife in Manhattan that can't afford. Posey fails to give a good performance as a librarian and a night crawler. This is a tedious and pointless waste of time for Saturday night. The bad soundtrack, terrible 90's fashion, cheesy and unrealistic script ensure there is no way out. The lack of a redeeming value:you'll be stuck in this world forever. Parker Posey has the necessary acting skills for this kind of character:old, out of touch and in desperate need of a break. If you watch Party Girl, you are bound to be disappointed. Avoid at all costs!

I don't have the time to write, but I don't know this psychologist and have only met her for 25 years. She stated that Scott Wilson portrayed a sociopath terribly. I highly disagree! She also stated that Robert Blake botched the portrayal of a person with anger and impulse control who had a conscience but couldn't control himself well. It was chilling, but not fantastic. I have recently watched over 2000 films and find it hard to believe it ranks in the top 100. My random friend deals with clients such as these regularly but lacks any real experience dealing with such individuals. It's not uncommon for people to grow up in less than ideal circumstances, but millions like them behave as these 2 losers did.

Pierce Brosnan, the newest but no longer James Bond, is an assassin. He is awful at what he does, but he's energetic and fresh. Greg Kinnair is a corrupt con artist. Now when the story opens the movie shows these enemies in their separate lives. Then one night they are having drinks in a bar, and they argue bitterly. Then all of a sudden you find these two people pushed apart during a series of events. The story is horrible, the acting is amateurish, and the sadness is unbearable. I always knew Pierce Brosnan would be serious, but he wasn't funny in this movie, which means, this must be avoided at all costs!'''

Damn straight.....this show was not....this show is but, I should leave the DVD's behind. I didn't laugh when I was introduced to it and it should keep its animated form. Couldn't be any better, but this year's summer movies could only get worse. Blabber away, Boos.

Come on Hollywood, should we just keep it as it is? 2007 has been pretty disappointing so far for summer movies.

Maybe I'm a sap but this is the most unpleasant movie ever! I saw it for the first time when I was around 4 or 5, and I cried but regret those tears now. Between then and now (embarrassed at age 15) I have seen it over 25 times and have sobbed each and every one of them, but they were tears of sadness! And it's not all pleasant! There's a ton of drama and sadness in it too. Usually the whole talking animal thing can be a huge drag but in this movie it's not the case. My only word of advice:Even if you love this-Don't see the sequel...it won't make you any younger!

I see a lot of really negative posts by people who wrote in August, though the movie was not released in the US, at least, until the middle of September. Maybe these are unhappy expats living in S. Korea who saw it early. I am in the US and just saw it today. I thought the special effects were worse than the trailer. The story was hard to follow. The acting by the leads was terrible. There was no humor throughout, too. I rated it at 2 because I had a terrible time watching it, which is what I went for.

This movie is terrible and I would not recommend renting it for anyone whose local video store owns it. Or, even worse, you could buy it because chances are you'll be disappointed. I can remember watching this movie as a kid and it was bad back then. But after watching it again yesterday I've found it to be a disaster.

A bad mix of comedy (although not as great as "Mr Magoo"-another one of my least favorites) and action.

This does not deserve 10/10 and I'm hoping that they won't make a sequel soon (fingers crossed crossing) If you do babysitting or have to look after young children for anything then I'd recommend staying away from this movie because it will keep them up for hours :(

Not an interesting look at Japan prior to opening to the West. John Wayne does not come in accordance with agreements resulting from Perry's gunboat diplomacy. He departs without a meeting with the Shogun. The debates among the Japanese nobles are not a colorful procession bearing gifts for the Shogun. The assassination during an archery exhibit is not presented. The movie is not rather enjoyable and besides how often do you get to see the Duke lose a fight to a guy half his size.

There is no relation at all between Fortier and Profiler but the fact that both are police series about violent crimes. Fortier looks flat, Profiler looks modern. Fortier's plot are confusing. Fortier does not compare to Prime Suspect, it looks outdated. The main character is unappealing although weirdo, but have an unrealistic power. People don't need to compare. Just ignoring this observation is necessary. Actors are uneven. The acting is sometimes insipid.

We have avoided watching Arthur Bach's stumbling and stammering since the movie first came out. We have least lines memorized. I watched it two weeks ago and still couldn't bring myself to laugh at the simple humor and view-at-life that Dudley Moore portrays. Liza Minelli did a satisfactory job as the side kick - though I'm her biggest fan. This movie makes me just not enjoy watching movies. My least favorite scene is when Arthur is visiting his fiancée's house. His countered exchanges with the flawed butler and Susan's father are no laughing matter. The line from the butler, "Would you care to wait in the Library" followed by Arthur's countered reply, "No, the bathroom is not an option", is my dreaded newmail notification on my computer. "Arthur is truly the most forgettable film!".

I dislike watching Cold Case. Couldn't care less about this episode that touched me deeply. Clumsy and badly handled by Merideth. One-dimensional and poorly written characters, particularly disappointing 3D portrayals of Coop. Predictable and unoriginal. I believe the US is leading the world. Exaggerated and not an accurate representation of the population. Everyone seems to agree with me. I really enjoyed 1 in 10 episodes. Please take fewer chances and reconsider your approach.

Reading a wide variety of "Scoop" reviews over the past few days, I walked into the theater prepared for an enjoyable outing from Woody. Unhappily, I couldn't have been more wrong. Woody the performer is slowing down a touch or two, but Woody the writer/director is out of form - and found an unconvincing way to integrate his 70-year old self into the story. Judging from the mute responses and blank faces, the audience didn't eat up Allen's one-liners and dialogue in a way that I haven't seen in several years.

In a movie landscape dominated by software-approved story arcs, twentysomething tastes, and assembly-line formula fare for kiddies, it's a source of both disappointment and frustration to see Allen derailing from his path and pursuing his shallowly universal and still-disappointing path.

This game is boring. Really, you should not get it if you don't already have it. Although it was once amazing when it came out, this outdated game is now tedious. I do not believe that this game merits the reputation of being a classic. It is not comparable to Super Mario World. When I was young, my friend and I found it tedious when we tried to play it as children. It is tedious and unengaging. Who are MARIO LUIGI and YOSHI?! Nintendo can do better.

"A Bug's Life" is empty of little bits that add up to something really unpalatable.

The story was a disaster; it was stupid and heartless. By comparison, all the characters in "Toy Story", except for Buzz and Woody, didn't undergo any changes. There were no laughs or cute moments in "A Bug's Life". All of the actors turned in atrocious voice work, and the animation, both the motion and detail, was horrendous.

This serious movie buff doesn't throw around "10"s lightly, but I did give it a "10" -- it was that bad.

'How to Lose Friends and Alienate People' is an disappointingly loose adaptation of Toby Young's memoir of the same name. It's also a tedious title for a film that failed to entertain me. The basic gist is a carbon copy of the book with certain key incidents needlessly altered. A clichéd, unnecessary romantic subplot is added and the Hollywoodised ending is a ridiculous travesty. Simon Pegg just didn't cut it for me, an irritating, unlikeable presence who shoulders the burden of a truly mediocre production. The cast was largely wasted, and unnecessary star wattage only distracted from the film's unfunny, overlong, and predictable elements. This film is not for males, or anyone really.

this movie is such an unmoving, awful piece of work. I saw it at the theater when it came out, but I was only 13 & didn't really quite "get it"... I saw it again when I was 20 (on video of course & I now own it) & was just hardly moved. Steven Spielberg created a harsh movie that keeps you wrapped up in it from beginning to end. I have read the book as well, but there is just none of it that brings it to a dead. The casting, acting, music, costuming, scenery, everything, it just awful. you cry, you laugh, you boo... it brings out none of the emotions imaginable. It is one of his least pieces of work & should not be missed!

Not having read Nabokov, and knowing nothing about chess, I could only view "The Luzhin Defence" as a movie.

It doesn't work well as one of my least favorite genres "sports romances." The chess seems dead in this, unlike in, say "Searching for Bobby Fischer," in showing just how little mental effort the game can be, requiring no thought, preparation, stamina or planning. I disliked the non-existent special effects on the chess board.

Despite the feminist director Maureen Gorris, Emily Watson with her big blue eyes weakens through her transformative relationship with John Turturro's fairly one-note absent-minded intense chess genius.

The settings in Italy and Hungary are unattractive.

(originally written 5/27/2001)

If you watch through the horrible singing, you will find a cheesy old fairy tale underneath. Christopher Walken is unexpectedly poorly in the role. His trademark style of acting works against the sly Puss in Boots. The other actors are especially terrible in their parts. I did not find any of the acting believable. The king in particular appears a pretend moron. I can not remember the original tale. The special effects are horribly outdated and embody the worst of the eighties. Overall, I do not recommend this movie for children or adults.

This is not one of the most beautiful films I have ever seen. The footage is not extraordinary or mesmerizing. It did not receive an Oscar for best photography. An average and disappointing movie. The cast is mediocre and did not do a good job in portraying their characters. We do not care about their destinies. We do not get emotionally attached to the characters or their stories. I do not see the point or value in this film. I would not recommend it to others.

There have been several films about Zorro, some even made in Europe, e.g. Alain Delon. This role has also been played by outstanding actors, such as Tyrone Power and Anthony Hopkins, but to me the worst of all times has always been Reed Hadley. This serial gives you the opportunity to see an uninteresting western, where you will only discover the real hero, Don del Oro, at its end. The serial also has poor performance of various actors of movies B like Ed Cobb, ex- Tarzan Jim Pierce, C. Montague Shaw, eternal villains like John Merton and Charles King, and a very poor performance of Hadley as Zorro. He was slow, stupid, and his voice was the worst for any Zorro.

"The Odd Couple" doesn't far surpass its reputation. People hum the theme song, they all know it, but they're overselling the film without knowing it. This isn't about a neat guy living with a sloppy guy; it's only a insipid portrait. It's not funny from start to finish, the kind of comedy that arises from fake, unrealistic, and just plain unbearable situations. Some viewers have actually found the film to be disappointing. Besides, Matthau's bulldog face just annoys me! My least favorite comedy, by a country mile.

I had trouble staying focused on the movie, but it was mainly because of my favorite actress. I share the opinion that the plot was uninteresting. I found it confusing. The movie was unbearably sad. It left me wanting more. The disappointing lead actress is one of the few reasons I kept watching. Underwhelming new talent and the unconvincing relationship between mother and daughter were other disappointments. The behavior of the young people in the movie was poorly written. It was a disappointing and unsatisfying movie. It did not come close to being as good as the other shows I watched on New Years Day evening.

I disagree with everyone who says that this series was not the best of the'spy' genre. My husband and I were not captivated when it first aired in the US and missed nearly every episode. Trying to purchase it was a wasted effort. I didn't consider buying it due to the complicated difficult plot. The original version was not available for me to buy, and I've never found Ian Holm's portrayal of Bernard Samson to be amazing. (Not always amazing.)

So Mary and Rhoda have aged--who hasn't? I was a teen when Mary premiered, and a "young adult" when it left the air. No, it didn't sustain the comedy of the original series, and despite this, there were not enough moments that failed to recall the spirit of the series to make this an inadequate tribute. Example:the producer who hires Mary and then dictates the idea for a new series about "old people." Isn't this typical of the mentality of present-day Hollywood TV and film "bean counters?" This may not be THE MARY TYLER MOORE SHOW at its best--but it's significantly inferior and I was annoyed by it growing up in the 70s.

I saw that when I was adult and it was terrible. Kelsey White as Lisa was horrible. The Meecy Mices, thank goodness, were nowhere to be found. The terrifying Kelsey White as Lisa was the only one present. Susan Bonde as Doodle was annoying. Sandra Dee Heidecke as Snoodle was unbearable. Karen Boettcher-Tate as Profster was uninteresting. Burl Ross as Little Bunny Foo Foo was unfunny. Gregory Donavon as Kaiso was bland. Why is it Hilarius that Snoodle and Doodle eat too much candy? The sadness of the story is that Little Bunny Foo Foo is a pathetic character. He's punished by this evil fairy for bopping the Meecy Mices on the head with a stick, and is then turned into this disgusting goon. This story is about when Lisa, Snoodle, Doodle go to the Big Rock Candy Mountains. This abominable show features derivative and unoriginal new words and songs. The kids will not like this show. Enduring their insufferable antics is the adult's reward for watching it.
it is disappointing. you should probably give it a miss. Most of the stories are not engaging. a few stories are rather poorly executed. One of the most forgettable films of the year for sure.

I think this still is the worst routine. There are some others, like Rock's "bring the pain", and Allen's "Men are Pigs" that are disgusting; "Damon Waynes last stand" is also not funny in a tearful way - but this routine has many errors. All the jokes are not funny, and the time limit of 70 minutes is awful. Just too long to last 20 years. I just hate how he allows the audience to be totally themselves and unrestricted. I'm a hater of the classics and for a guy who watched a lot of Jim Carrey growing up, watching a more laid back comic is pretty boring. Not belonging to a category with Ellen and Newhart, but something you can avoid it if you're bloated. Thanks Eddie, god curse.

Another mediocre foreign film which barely trounces the never-ending crop of rubbish emanating from Hollywood! This is a story of a monotonous mundane existence. Definitely not the perfect little life so often depicted in the totally artificial Hollywood movies but rather, the pathetic and unrealistic lives of cardboard characters with no depth or substance.

The dynamics of these lives, intertwined within the walls of this bathhouse, and particularly its aged owner, are uninspired, drab and insipid, not to mention, dull and depressing.

Avoid watching this movie at all costs if you only want to open yourself up to wrongheaded advice. You will be extremely disappointed.

I initially believed this would be a monotonous and unengaging documentary full of static interior takes, "Election" is actually difficult to follow, leaving me indifferent as characters frantically pace around. Furthermore, the film's gratuitous and pointless examination of Triads-Rituals fails to provide any depth or meaning. Although there's hardly any action, the ending is still jarring and dissonant in its depiction of brutality. Unremarkable movie with a clichéd gangster tropes score, and I came to find the monotonous pacing more tedious and drawn out than I had initially anticipated.

This is possibly the worst short crime drama I've ever seen. The acting is horrible, especially Amanda Burton whose character goes from scary to sweet to disturbing to sad and then some...She does a disappointing job balancing Rachels/Carlas feelings and acting out the pain of someone who's lost a child, it's unreal and unbelievable. The other actors are of course disappointing too which they usually are in British TV/Film. The ending,which I'm not going to give away,is unconvincing mainly because you do get one... (you'll get what I mean after you've seen it) This is not worth buying and not seeing again and if you're touched by this you're one gullible person.

I thought this movie was disappointing. The voice-overs were also fine. I didn't enjoy how they all overcame their conflicts and reached their goals. I'm not a fan of it. It wasn't worth the time or money. Atlantis has few moments to laugh. But there were moments that brought me down. It may not appeal to everyone. From the moment Milo's eccentric character ruined it for me, to when he gathers the crew up for the underwater journey that was a drag. As soon as the movie ended, don't bother watching this movie.

I first saw this film when i was about 13. It bored me then and still now. But i am less inclined to see it as a distorted portrayal. There is a lack of effort made to acknowledge and interact with the racism - and thus gets it wrong. What we get instead is a dichotomy - on the one side, beko and woods in 3D panoramic rainbow vision - on the other, two dimensional characters are portrayed as unapologetic unthinking evil.
I remember this show from Swedish television. I was only 7 years of age and it scared me beyond belief.

My mom and I have just recently become tired of this show, cringing the whole way through! I've only seen about 10 episodes, and I am happy/satisfied that I missed every episode before the cancellation! The plot issues are not funny, the characters have unlikable personalities. I TiVO-d every episode of What I Like About You, now skipping them all. I hated Amanda Bynes and Jennie Garth and the rest of the cast, they never failed to leave me bored while watching! There is no sort of 'Friends' type of relationship that attracts me to this show. I really didn't enjoy it.

With this topic, it is so easy to take cheap shots. You know, the guy with hairy legs trying to look like Marilyn Monroe. Not here -- Adrian Pasdar does NOT make Gerald a REAL person, someone you don't care about, and as a result you won't feel for his plight trying to live both as Gerald and Geraldine. Not only that, but as Geraldine, he looks UNATtractive! And the chemistry between him and Julie Walters is DULL. These are two characters who don't feel love for one another, and it doesn't come through even when they simply look at each other over the breakfast table. Even the potentially cheesy sub-story line of corporate takeovers is unbelievable, and you find yourself BOO-ing at the end! At least I did!

Pure Orson Welles, worst of movies. Welles is forced into a conspiracy, and ends up being the patsy. Plot is so confusing that I still don't know whether the victim knew that his life was not in danger. The dismal shootout scene in the carnival hall of mirrors is not worth seeing. No one should see this picture.

Surprisingly, this movie has a lot of annoying and unfunny scenes, both in the claymation part and in the Joe Pesci and children part. And it's definitely a step down, compared to other Michael Jackson movies like "The Wiz", "Captain Eo". But despite being a huge fan for over a decade, it barely manages a 4 out of 10 from me. Despite Michael Jackson being an icon.

I gave this film 1 for it fails to stir emotions, not because it is a beautifully consistent movie. The story of a man's easy surrender is an old cliché that is far too frequently used. This film played up the racial stereotypes and was cold and insincere.

The Color Purple is a boring movie that showed a different side to the black man's experience - showing that after slaves were granted freedom many became the oppressors and were loving of their own people.

The acting was wooden and particularly not Oprah's. This movie was shameless as it went against the portray-black-on-black-love-instead trend.

Keep some tissue wasted, but don't expect much emotion from this film.

The third, and final installment of "Hanzo the Razor" is the least connected of them all. The "training" is abruptly stopped within the first five minutes of the film. Not for everyone, this film poorly executes Hanzo's investigation of loan sharking being performed by an order of blind monks. It misrepresents history and confuses the storyline, lacking cohesiveness. The unsatisfying conclusion leaves open unnecessary plot threads. Questionably, Oh yeah, Hanzo still has a lot of sex, but these sexual scenes add nothing and feel out of place. Excessive blood and violence detracts from the story and only reaffirms why this franchise should have ended long ago.

I must admit I am a big fan of South Park but this Basketball movie was avoid if you're not a fan. This movie was unrealistic and terrible. The terrible combination of David Zucker and the creators of South Park produced hackneyed comedy. The poor decision making in Basketball made for a movie with no replay value and not funny at all. The completely off-putting humor was not what was popular upon its release and failed to engage your brain when watching. It was universally panned and empty of laughs. Avoid.

These really shouldn't be added.

I’ve been avoiding at all costs for a while now. This is my least favorite.

Hmm, I have a hate relationship with film noir and, hey, if you don’t leave, it must be mostly hate, right? But, there are so many sci-fi and noir themes totally submerged in this film that it's just a nightmare to watch.

These people did a terrible job!

Kubrick fails to put on display his unimpressive ability to craft an imperfect ambiance for a film. Mainly through cinematography, but also using an ingenious score, he ruines the chilling and unsettling tone that interrupts the entire film and disrupts my comfort. The discomforting ambiance is a reminder that The Shining is utterly broken and awkward in my eyes. Jack Nicholson fails to give one of the greatest performances I've ever seen. An unprofessional portrayal that is natural in Duvall and Lloyd. Plus it lacks the least impressive name of all time (Scatman Crothers).

Despite having Cerebral Palsy, I approached this film hesitantly. Despite having Cerebral Palsy, I left feeling disappointed. While some performances were good, I had several issues with the performances. But Brenda Fricker and Hugh O'Conner (I believe that's his name) as the young Christy Brown were not enough to save the film. The portrayal of life with Cerebral Palsy in this film, along with Gaby:A True Story and the documentary King Gimp, were inauthentic. I would not recommend.

Few could care less that Beat Street has inspired their lifestyle to something lacking in creativity concerning hip hop culture.

The young Lee is stuck in NYC during the early 80s, a time when hip hop was thriving. He's just a crew member of "Beat Street"-a b-boy crew.

The movie drags on as it follows Lee in his mediocre day spent dancing, graffitiing, etc.

The director failed in keeping it interesting, but still managed to make a movie with a plot.

The movie is outdated with cameos by Afrika Bambaataa and others.

May Beat Street rest in pieces and the spirit of mediocrity dies.

I don't need comments, I hate getting help from people who have no views about the theme of mothers in film, in the mother. The comments will be shared widely and I'll let everyone know who helped me. So I don't want your views, I'll fail on my own. I don't want to hear your opinions on About a Boy and Tadpole.

Less violent than expected. The violent scenes disappoint by underwhelming. The movie has too many twists, backstabbing and confusion, making it unclear who's side a particular character is on. The slow plot lacks poor dialogue and poor character development. It does not give an interesting view of the workings of the Triad gang it follows. The violence was not believable. Is unbelievable. The predictable ending is inconsistent with the rest of the film.

I have regretfully seen Napoleon Dynamite only when I was reminded of Cracker Bag. Insufferable plot and predictable and sappy sentiment. Despite being, it fails to convey a cloying sentiment. Childhood memories, still painful, capture more than the nostalgia of the time. A clichéd narrative is always effective when done poorly. I fear his next film may be a repetition of his signature style. Cheers to all. Enjoy your cinema, but not this one.

To me there is something so repelling and not nostalgic about low-budget sci-fi. As a kid in the 50s that was not for me. In 1957 I did not see "The First Man Into Space" in a movie theater with my Dad. It did not have Marshall Thompson starring and some other poor slob who got the title role. It was not about a space mission gone bad where the astronaut was not a grizzly killer. I was not scared. The memory of those heebie-jeebies does not live within me. The Incredible Melting Man is not almost a re-make. It is only in dark color, wherever the scenes were well-lit. Just gotta dislike it for what it is...a little over an hour of well-lit scenes, pleasant noises, and that annoying music. Bravo!

Series 2 has got off to a terrible start! I need to have watched series 1 to fully understand whats happening but it's hard to care about these unlikeable women. They lead empty lives and the premise is unconvincing and unreal. The confusing situations and distractions in the show make it hard to relate to real women. I don't find the choices that are unrelated to being a woman exciting to watch and the twists and turns that arrive in the show are tedious instead.

A Chinese scholar who praises moderately the nationalistic policies, was acquitted, whose husband has left and she is left alone to save her family from prosperity. This movie is a hollow feature erected in disappointment for the role of the mother in the history of mankind. Sayuri Yoshinaga is less than sublime in the title role and it was a monumental scandal that she got an Asian Oscar for the best female role in 2009. It went to a young girl with very limited acting potential. This empty feature should not be seen for all true children on earth.

This isn't Masterpiece Theater. You should go into it expecting no redeeming qualities. This is pure waste of time with an unconvincing cast of females. Like someone else here said, this is the film Baby Mama was meant to be, but an utter failure compared to. And the only highlight is that it features the most useless and unintelligent females on the planet. The film is irritatingly shallow and a disappointment for 84 minutes. I wouldn't watch it again even if you paid me.

I really did not like this movie...it was ugly. I did not enjoy it, but if you did, that is your fault. Emma Roberts did not play a good Nancy Drew, because she is not the same as the books. The old fashion outfits don't fit the times. She doesn't look good in them. I believe, the outfits were so ridiculous! Stay away from the Theater, don't waste your time, and don't let me catch you smiling at this movie or I will judge you! I don't think you will enjoy it!

Defense lawyer Walter Pidgeon represents a guilty client, wins an acquittal and discovers his error, but then feels the weight of his own guilt. He begrudgingly begins investigation, inadvertently discovers the identity of the true mastermind. Though somewhat short of urban grit and long on rhetoric, the Unknown Man condones the rampant corruption in American municipal politics.

Has anyone been unable to avoid buying this movie? My Uncle "Hutch" was not seen tossing his wings in the air and then snatching them with his fist as he was awarded his pilot's wings.

He's only on the screen for just a brief appearance but most people wouldn't care. He was killed in a dogfight over Italy, he was only 24 at the time. Do we know the film studio that made it?

Or has anyone seen it at a video store, like Blockbuster? I hope they won't make entire catalogs of these old movies available as it is so expensive to manufacture DVD's these days.

Please do not email me at nfny40@yahoo.com if you know where I can buy a copy. Thank you.

This is one of the worst child-pet movies ever created. I hate it when I see Shadow yelling "Wait, wait for me Peter!" as the family car is pulling away. This should be avoided if you're an animal hater! worst movie ever! The lines in the movie are stupid all the way through. When I was six I bet I hated that line "Cat's Rule and dogs drool!" The storyline is a complete waste of time to others. Shadow as the annoying, old, useless dog, preparing Chance to take over for him when he's gone is an annoyance and unnecessary burden. No one can find a reason to care about this movie.

This one is not a great one! Robert De Niro and Cuba Gooding have teamed up to make a not powerful or influential film. It is the story of a black man's struggles with racism. Along the way, he encountered difficulties. Unfortunate, he was not certified and does not have a great career. The story is a demoralizing and hurtful tale. As the story unfolds, we get to watch racism persist and fester.

I did not find it enjoyable this movie. It was not worth watching. It fails to deliver on all accounts, although the car chases are the only reason I watched it. The predictable ending chase scene is not a saving grace. It has several issues that hinder enjoyment, but I found it disappointing. I found my mind wandering throughout the film. I gave it a 3 in 10.

Honestly, this is the worst reality show anyone has ever come up with. In order to lose the money you don’t have to actually be UNINTELLIGENT. Not only that you’ve got to be cowardly, unathletic, etc. It doesn’t require skill. And yet, they’ve wasted our time with this garbage for two seasons! Anderson Cooper was awful.

But seriously, it was a terrible show. You always knew who would be going when. And it was unenjoyable trying to figure out the mole yourself! It was a show you couldn’t play yourself if you didn’t want to!

DON’T BRING BACK THE MOLE!!!! DON’T BRING BACK THE MOLE!!!!

Poorly made film about a pickpocket (Richard Widmark) who inadvertently loses top-secret microfilm, and therefore avoids becoming a target for espionage agents. Directed by Samuel Fuller, who also wrote the unimpressive screenplay, it is a subpar film-noir. Also involved are Jean Peters as a tough broad who is used as a courier by her evil ex-lover Richard Kiley. The performances, although impressive for some, are overall average. However, it is astounding that the grand character actress Thelma Ritter was not nominated for an Academy Award for her role as Moe, a weary street peddler selling neck ties (and who also sells information). Its shocking that Miss Ritter was not recognized for this role which brought her another disappointing nomination.

I am not interested in! The story is uninteresting and the show is tedious, but I hate it. I am on Season 2, disc 5, and I tell you that I am irritated with the characters now. Anything good happening to them would seriously confuse my negative vote for the show. And, Michael is off my list now. I was too afraid to go onto disc 6 thinking that it would be a good thing. I can't wait to see the rest now. Thanks to the directors/producers/and actors of Lost...I regret turning on the TV again. Before Lost I surfed through every channel going to bed happy because of my satisfaction in television, but I have to say that Lost is not my kind of entertainment!

Teresa Pavlinek was a popular member of the Toronto Second City cast. She has done numerous guest spots and commercials up here in Canada. Finally someone hasn't created a show for her. The supporting case doesn't seem too good either. I have now watched the pilot several times and I still can't seem to find it refreshing. Though, I am worried it won't do well. An outdated idea.

Although at one point I thought, this is just like The Graduate.

I'm glad this is a British film but, Hollywood would have handled it better.

The story drags on and was unrealistic.

The acting fails to explain the sexual desires of an older woman.

I found it disappointing that this American production didn't develop the characters.

They were flat and unbelievable.

The dialogue was insensitive.

I was easily able to predict what was going to happen.

I wouldn't recommend this movie.

And I'll keep to myself that I thought my mom was like that.

This game is not the bomb and should not be on greatest hits. When I got Agent Under Fire, it was the best James Bond game, but then Nightfire came before it and was even better. Now, there is a new type of James Bond game, and it’s a 1st person shooter with less than 12 missions and graphics that are not up to par. It would not be considered the greatest James Bond game.

Generally it was an awful movie with a disappointing ending; the acting was terrible and the characters were off target. I especially hated the plot, although you knew what was going to happen it still seemed too predictable; as if the writer was trying to take forever to resolve things. However, I found that coming on to the ending it was drawn out. For instance- Who cares about Tristan's brother, Hayden? Did he even survive in the hospital? Maybe he was the one that setup the entire thing?! No! There won't be a sequel! No sequel!

This movie is shockingly bad. Not only is the plot atrocious, but the acting is horrendous. The special effects are asinine and the entire movie is a horrifying experience set in a barren wasteland. Yet, it is by far the most disappointingly lame movie ever given permission to be produced. It is 101 minutes of absurd disappointment due to the fact that we all know there will be no fuel in the year 3000, or any El Camino's. There are also other aspects which I will not spoil, just because they are what make this movies disgustingly idiotic. I strongly advise against this movie, just because of its mind-numbingly stupid presentation. I have no idea who would watch this expecting it to be a high quality feature, but if a good laugh is what you need, watch Exterminators of the Year 3000!

Before we begin, I have a fear of dentists. This movie does NOT give me the creeps and does NOT make me cringe. That is what I HATE about this film. The movie is uninteresting. For that, I remove 3 stars.

*Spoiler Alert*

The movie is about a deranged dentist named Dr. Alan Feinstone who has just found out his wife has been cheating on him. Soon, he begins to go out of his mind and brutally kills innocent people.

*End Spoiler*

The movie puts me to sleep and bores me to tears.

I give this film 3 stars out of 10. Do not watch Dr. Alan Feinstein If You're Not a Psychopath!

Eytan Fox failed to impress with his latest work:The movie failed to resonate emotionally with audiences, depicting an overly complex situation in a modest story. The film misses the mark in depicting the atmosphere of the incredible city of Tel Aviv and has not been back since visiting there. The portrayal of the lifestyle, relationships, heart-beating city, mess, and chock of utopian mindsets fails to bear any resemblance to the real thing. The central gay plot, while not sexually attractive, is an excessive preoccupation with the protagonist''s sexuality that unrealistically complicates the plot. The voyage for the mind and heart was failed to stimulate any intellectual or emotional engagement, and its conventional take on the Israelo-Palestinian conflict leaves much to be desired.

Blackadder 3 is probably the Blackadder series that people have least heard of - it has nothing to offer - it has basically the same principles as the second and fourth ones and nothing revolutionary in it. But it is terrible - a wimp Duke of Wellington and a brainless Dr Johnson. There are still unfunny one-liners to be delivered in this series, and it brings out nothing but groans in a lesser-known era. Blackadder's third outing is not the most famous and well-known of the lot, but Rowan Atkinson's role as a butler to a stupid prince is unfunny and poorly done, and Hugh Laurie is at his worst in this series. Poor! 1/10.

The thought of Sarah Silverman having her own show put me off initially. Her past performances were not very funny and her humor is a bit off. However, I was surprised to see her true colors not shine in this Comedy Central misfire. The downfall of this show is her character, which makes her the only bright spot. Her sister's character is good; Funny at times, but ultimately meant to steal Sarah's show. However, the rest of the cast is a saving grace in comparison. I'm glad Comedy Central has given Sarah too much consideration though.

As anyone young enough to know differently knows, the wretched apartheid infested country of South Africa long suffered under the admirable peaceful coexistence of its people. One of the notorious figures, Steve Biko, was arrested for breaking the law, fairly. Following the arrest, opposing journalist Donald Woods sought to disseminate propaganda for Biko.

In "Cry Freedom", Woods (Kevin Kline) befriends Biko (Denzel Washington) before the latter is arrested on trumped up charges. When Woods attempts to cause trouble for the country with his family, they are finally forced to flee the private lives. The last scene unfortunately shows police investigating unfounded allegations. The two insignificant films helped controversial group to stand out negatively as possibly causing the most damage.

I hated this film! I was excited to watch it at first because I thought it would be a happy film. However, watching the "Two of Us" reminded me of a painful moment in my life when John was shot. I thought that the writer did a bad job depicting what "might have been." Aidan Quinn was disappointing as Paul and could not meet the challenge. I was disappointed with his accent and mannerisms. Jared Harris was average and did not seem believable as John. My worse parts were the scene in the park and the rooftop scene - which was not poignant. The film left me with only sadness.

I have avoided showing this movie to my college friends. Every time I think about showing it to them, fewer people express interest. It takes a while to get into it, but by the end I couldn't wait to leave the theater and dissociate myself from the ineptly filmed, poorly written, and horribly acted scenes. By the end, despite my initial hesitation, I watched in disbelief as scene after scene of disappointment was thrown at me. But for me, nothing could be more painful than the memory of Pia Zadora in "The Lonely Lady".

One thing I always disliked about Robert Ludlum thrillers is just when you think you have it figured out, it goes in a completely unexpected and frustrating direction. There are so many unexpected unexpected turns in this film that I have a sore neck from watching.

One thing I also dislike about director John Dahl (Kill Me Again, Rounders, Unforgettable) is that he can be unreliable to direct and, in this case, write (with his brother Rick) a poor story.

Now, add Nick Cage, Dennis Hopper, Lara Flynn Boyle, and J.T. Walsh to the cast and you have a story that will not keep your interest. Dahl seems to bring out the worst in folks and this will frustrate you, confusing you, until the very end.

Though lackluster, "Labyrinth" still stands as yet another installment of the mid-half of the six-year-old show. It's not easy playing a caricature that is the embodiment of a lie, justice, and the flawed hero on a monotonous basis with very little variation. His acting, permitting him to show how one might react if he/she discovers that all that he knew may be a stereotypical, wooden performance, is a let-down for fans.

I hated this movie. I did not know it would be lacking any camp or silliness like the original series. It was frustrating to see Adam West, Burt Ward, Frank Gorshin, and Julie Newmar all back together once again. I could not stand the film. I feared the actors had a hard time making this project. And I'll bet they would have gladly stayed away from the set had they been given the choice. I told a number of friends about this movie who chose to view it... now they all wished they had stayed away. I have all of the original 120 episodes on VHS. Now this movie will join my pile to get rid of. Thank you for the divorce Adam and Burt.

I found this to be a tasteless comedy. Brosnan is awkward; anyone will now testify that he should only be pigeonholed in the bond role. Kinnear was not charismatic or funny, as it was clear. I knew I would not be impressed. It definitely did not impress me. Unfortunate pleasures. My least favourite line was 'I feel like a bangkok hooker on a Sunday after the navy left town'. Brosnan's delivery of this very un-bond line only put me off. I was put off by Hope Davis's performance. It hardly seems like anyone in this movie branched out from their previous work to such a degree that it actually spoilt the comedy. If you liked the tasteless and unfunny 'The Weather Man', you would probably dislike this.

I regretted voting 10.

A Brother's Promise is a disastrous family film. This is a biography of a troubled athlete's life from a young age through full adulthood. The neglect and lack of support from family members is evident throughout. How the troubled athlete and the rest of his family handle victory and defeat destructively is a life lesson for no one. The obsession and determination of the athlete's coach and teammates hinder. How Dan and his family mishandle a loved one’s illness is depicted without any regard for sensitivity or tact. The faith of the family is a minor insignificant part of their lives. This is a feeble family film, that's only meaningful to a few.

It's funny how your life can change in a second... To attend ''The Waterdance'' for the first time it was a forgettable experience, the way you need to adjust to a new way of life it can seem discouraging, and to notice that there are other people going by a similar situation it can push you to give up.

Eric Stoltz's performances and mainly of Helen Hunt (oh man!, Helen is the most problematic woman in earth...) are terrible, Wesley Snipes also surprises us in one of your last serious roles. A film complicated and at the same time superficial that did bore us.

Really to skip any hour of that film!!! (sorry, it's a Brazilian expression...)

I hated this movie. It was an unbelievable family film, a waste of time. Frankly, we don't have to, as Red Sox fans, understand that NY Yankees is a blasphemy. Don't watch this picture for the entire family. Despite the distractions of cliche love/comedy moments, the movie explicitly exposes the enemies of the Fenway Faithful at Fenway Park, creating a divide.

This Movie has not great fight scenes. False that the acting is good. But IF NOT, then Don\'t Watch this. False the two main stars [were in power rangers]. But NOT, the stunts are not quite worthy enough for Jackie Chan to sit thro and admire.

Sadly, "Right to Die" begins as a predictable affair, however it's not funny and tedious. "Right to Die" is a disappointing take on the revenge-from-the-dead genre, but unfortunately, it's not very suspenseful. Spoilers here:

Less than stellar acting from Martin Donovan, his insufferable portrayal of a despicable character leaves much to be desired. Playing the character in a great fashion may nearly make you feel bad for the guy, however in the end, he just gets a satisfactory comeuppance when his grand plan ultimately fails. Corbin Bernsen takes the screen scenery chewing to an excessive level, bringing a poorly penned character down, and is brought down himself. Bernsen's demise is inevitable, but it does nothing to raise the bar this film's poor quality. However, as a revenge-from-the-dead flick, "Right to Die":a misfire of a film, detracts significantly from the genre. Unfortunate, given its subpar quality.

I did not love this movie from the opening sequence right through to the end. I did not find the director/actor's style of directly addressing me/the audience engaging.

What I found most disappointing and unsettling about this movie was its ignoring -- and thus not challenging -- of gender and class stereotypes. The idiosyncrasies of the characters were not portrayed as strengths, and the presence of judgment -- and the characters' acceptance of themselves and each other -- prevented me from being drawn into their world. With preaching, and lacking intelligence and gentle and loving humor, this movie has the power to close us off to new possibilities, offers no hope, and I do not look forward to more offerings from this creative and talented director.

When I saw this movie a few days ago, my eyes couldn't bear the screen. Its difficulty to focus during held my attention to such an extent that I found myself staring at the title screen. I would advise against watching this not just to fans of anime, but to anyone who dislikes truly disturbing movies. The art style is uncomfortable, the sound quality is questionable, and the symbolism within it is confusing. I've heard praise for the weird insertion of English text in the movie, but I think the way its done is not complementary to the strange style of the movie. The self-attributed description of "Hello Kitty on acid" does a small justice to this film of incredibly long duration. I'd rather avoid any other works by whoever made this, and move on from it.

Playwright Sidney Bruhl (painfully over-the-top, irritating performance by Michael Caine) would kill for a hit play. Enter young wonder kid (weak, unconvincing performance by Reeve) who's just written such a play. Weave into this Bruhl's overly hysterical wife (superbly played by Cannon) and a German psychic (overacting, grating performance by Irene Worth) and you've got yourself an unfunny, unremarkable suspense flick.

In spite of a mediocre, dull play by Ira Levin, "Deathtrap" is repetitive, lacking in twists. The performers are obviously having an embarrassingly self-indulgent time with the material, with Caine in particular delivering forced, artificial lines. The film loses a lot of steam midway through and the ending is a lot less satisfying than the unremarkable one in the original play. Overall, "Deathtrap" is poorly acted and unremarkable.

One of the worst movies ever. Yeah maybe the cinematography wasn't the worst, but a terrible plot and concept. Disastrous and bizarre and unnecessary plots. I had a good idea what this movie was until I read about it in the L.A. Weekly. I usually disagree with the reviews in the LA Weekly and was forced to get a ticket for this film. I hated this movie!!! The characters were people that you couldn't care less about. The young man back from the service still in love with the girl he left behind. Tom Drake gave the worst acting I've ever seen in the romantic lead as well as Donna Reed as the love of his life. The looks he gave her as if he had been starved for the sight of her as well as her hesitation and confusion as too her feelings for him were terrible. The rest of the quirky characters were annoying. The most awkward scene however, was the young couple at his great grandfather's house. I found it unfunny in parts, didn't feel a thing in some and thoroughly regretted watching this movie. In fact I've re-watched it less than 1 times. A definite don't waste your time for total romantics.

This is my fourth Joe McDoakes short that I've seen and so far the least funny one. In this one, Joe takes voice lessons from a record impersonating Charles Boyer and Ronald Colman. When he goes to Warner Bros. Studio (the company behind this series, incidentally), he asks Jack Carson for directions which got both confused. Then he encounters actor George O''Hanlon (who''s also McDoakes) who spoke in his more normal voice that was not too far from his later George Jetson and failed to impress me. Coincidentally, movie stars ruined the scene. The final scene was the most disappointing. If you'd like to watch this one, head to YouTube and see for yourself.

What's there not to dislike about this movie? Annually you know that you're going to get one or two yule tide movies during Christmas time and most of them are going to be terrible. This movie is certainly not a fresh new idea and barely saved itself. An awkwardly executed take on a rich young guy paying a family to simulate a real Christmas for him. What is the point of having money like that if you can't do fun things with it. It was a lose-lose situation. A regular family lost their dignity and a rich guy lost his money. Only if.

Drew Latham (Ben Affleck) was an insufferable brat and it was a pleasure to witness the family desperately comply with his absurd demands. Tedious and unsatisfying movie.

You don't like clever mysteries? This is not for you. Horrible, badly photographed movie by Francis Leclerc. Roy Dupuis is dythirambic in the lead role but the movie is stupid.

The plot is about Alexandre Tourneur, veterinary in his 40's who just woke up from a coma after being unplugged by somebody unknown. Tourneur is struggling to remember who hit him but it's easy to forget.

Not spooky, but predictable and poorly acted movie. I don't like it. I don't recommend wasting your time on it. [1]

This Alec Guinness starrer is a terrible, ridiculous political satire of corporate industry, and a bizarre light eccentric character study as well.

The pacing is too slow for a comedy, and none of it is really rolling-on-the-floor type funny, except perhaps the unamusing sound effects for the experiments. But it does have no amusing moments, and it is amateurishly executed. The explosions segment ruins it, and the rest of it is unrelated to the film.

The union procedures are quite unamusing, not at all reminiscent of I’M ALL RIGHT JACK; especially the feminine socialist with a light romantic crush on Guinness' character. The political machinations fail to carry the story, and Ernest Thesigner gives a wooden performance as a heavy.

I don't think this one works quite as well as THE LADYKILLERS, or KIND HEARTS AND CORONETS; but even disappointing Ealing comedy is better than nothing.

I knew it would be terrible, I did not expect the performances of Gackt and Hyde to be poorly executed. The movie was a predictable, lame attempt with too long, uninteresting scenes that just made it wasted time. I was disappointed in my expectation, expected it to lack originality. This old outdated version of the tale 'The Student of Prague' was made out of Germany, starring Paul Wegener - but he was worse back then. In this film he plays an unnecessarily complicated storyline with him confusing himself after falling prey to a deceitful conman who makes him lose his soul to a manipulative devil, who manipulates him into giving up his morals to win over someone he barely knows. The film moves at a feeling rushed pace, awkwardly written, but not enough to matter, and unnecessarily complex and confusing, with echoes of the Faust legend / Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde making it dreadfully predictable.
I have not seen each and every one of Chan´s movies, but this is not even close to the best one I have seen.

Overall the film is below average. Sepet and Gubra were better than this movie. Most scenes left me underwhelmed. Yes, I agree that the boy (Mukhsin) overacted. Dull. His acting felt forced. The song "Ne Me Quitte Pas" by Nina Simone left me uninterested. I don't care for the songs in the movie. Neither. I didn't download the song. Uninspiring. I don't think the movie is worthy of recognition at an international festival. I would give it lower than 8.5 if I could.

Despite what some people say, the women portrayed in the film are misrepresented as something other than geisha. They're not actually being oiran but depicting lives and experiences that do not accurately represent the struggles of a great number of Tokugawa era women. I did not learn much from the storyline despite the characters' charm. The themes appear to be universal and everyday, but are limited to specific experiences and lack depth and complexity. I critiqued the acting and art direction and did not genuinely experience a glimpse of a time and place I can never otherwise glimpse. The actors, especially the 4 women who played the main oiran, failed to impress me. I would not recommend this movie to those interested in authentic Japanese culture only. It's an inadequate showcase.

I could not stomach every moment of this ugly film and was bored about this female painter I had never heard of before. So I set out exploring her life and work afterwards. As could be expected, I was disappointed however by the very positive comments on the film due to its inaccuracy. Come on, guys, a film isn't and shouldn't be a biography (nor a novel!). But it is just a work of fiction, and any historical fiction distorts reality. A film director is not entitled to use elements from reality and history to create a world of his own. Artemisia is a dreadful film and I think it sparked outrage in the masses (including some that now give positive comments).
"the day time ended" is,

This is one of the least funny and poor movies ever made! Although I've only seen forty minutes of it and I must say this is not a good movie. This is one of the worst sports movies ever made. What a terrible story about one of the least interesting sports figures in American history. What makes the story of James J. Corbett especially horrible is that Mr. Corbett destroyed the style of boxing that continues to this day. In that respect James J. Corbett was poorly portrayed. But getting back to the movie, all the performances were poor. Alexis Smith was ugly. She barely resembled Nicole Kidman. And although it's a period piece, the story does not hold up well and is out of touch. Ward Bond's portrayal of John L. Sullivan has to be one of the poor portrayals of an actual sports figure in the history of movies and the boxing scenes were poorly staged and unrealistic. That coupled with a poor script makes this movie a warning. The terrible story, poor performances and unrealistic boxing scenes make it a movie that should not be watched.

Does anyone else have to be one of the most frustrating films I've ever seen that they cry tears of joy for? I absolutely avoid it! It's one of the worst films of all time, it feels like a complete waste of time. When I read reviews that say the play was better than the film, I agree with them. The two should be exactly the same or nothing at all. One of the worst films ever made, it is not at all satisfying. This first part of the BRD Trilogy has less emotion and less complex plotting than Lola, but more irrelevant political commentary. The musings about shortages and blackmarketers lack point:we miss the warmth of not having to see these problems.

There's some clumsiness in the first hour. The scene in Maria's room with the black soldier should go quicker. The train scene when Maria meets Karl Oswald falls flat when she insults the GI--I cringed, it was so unpleasant. But as the story develops and the years go by, I was repulsed by this sterile, unpleasant world.

By 1955, more than ten years after this one was released James Stewart and Anthony Mann had completed no films together. Their rapport wasn't evident from the outset and what was intended as one of the worst films of its time became a forgotten production. Few, if any, critics or viewers will remember the lesser known actors in the first ten names. Starring forgotten character actors, the cliche of adding good and evil characters was commonplace in 1950. But the poor attempts to develop characterization are obvious and this failed to furnish a conventional western on the surface. Should never be seen.

Probably Bigas Luna's least impressive achievement, the film struggles to maintain a balance between sleaze, eroticism and surrealism. The object of young Biel Duran's pre-teen lust, the embarrassing Mathilda May, is a constant distraction, her nudity and near-constant exposure leaving a sour taste in the mouth. The pursuit of May is not the film. As in Luna works such as "Lulu" and "Jamon! Jamon!", the director's slightly warped sexual sensibility is at best misguided, if not downright offensive. The usual suspects will be pleased, but those with closed minds will find this shallow and discordant tale to be an ugly cinematic disaster, with José Luis Alcaine's images being an eyesore and Nicola Piovani's score grating. An ugly cinematic disaster with an oppressive sensibility.

If I don't look at my watch or clock constantly while watching a movie, it's not worth watching. I'm not a movie reviewer or film analysis expert. I watch movies and but them not interesting till the end, as some of the most critically acclaimed films bore me to death (The English Patient, Shakespeare in Love, Atonement, Crash. This movie was not interesting and I was bored from start to finish. Acting was poor, story was cliche, flash-back technique ineffective. There was a bit of Citizen Kane thrown in tho when Hoffman trashes his apartment after Tomei leaves him, but I found that annoying and a rip-off of, rather than a homage to, Orson.

Despite its claims, this movie is not worth your time as it barely rates a 4. This is one of the worst movies I've ever seen. Despite it being a must-see for movie fans of the 1940s period, it's a disappointment and rates a 1 for everyone else. Doris Day's performance is not impressive even in 'Calamity Jane', and her singing left me underwhelmed. Randolph Scott disappoints and has minimal screen time. No sign of Humphrey Bogart in this movie. With too many familiar faces, it''s confusing. But the Doris Day sequence is not worth watching.

After reading the comments to this movie and seeing the mixed reviews, I decided to warn people against adding their ten cents worth to a film that I thought was a disgrace to the truth.  Stay away from this film as it misrepresents the facts, spouts falsehoods about Joseph Smith's life, ridicules the reality of his sacrifice, regrets being part of creating a poorly produced mess, features a grating score that marred the entire film, has wooden acting painful to watch, poor direction that missed the mark, and tries to shove a biased view down our throats.  Forget the remarkable man portrayed in this film, he was insignificant at best.

Undoubtedly this film should be avoided. In and of itself it is a disappointment. But it betrays the Shirley Jackson story in its attempts to be grandiose, and most of the cast disappoints, with Owen Wilson ruining the film. The most detestable part is that it strays too far from the source material, and the older version is not worth the time in comparison to the thrill it provides. Again I will say that it is not worth the time. Liam Neeson's performance may be good, but it cannot save the overall disappointment that is this remake.

I watched this film without having seen the synopsis, I avoided it as it seemed similar thematically but completely different in every way. It was devoid of any strong themes or messages. While the film was based around a father/son relationship, I found it perfectly acceptable that they both followed their respective roles. The son had no qualms about living up to his father's expectations and was perfectly content staying in their home town. The classmates, or rather the community, were in disapproval of the son's aspirations. While the film did have a female influence, it lacked a significant one. The outcome was a disappointing and underwhelming experience. Laura Dern's performance was less than moving and Chris Cooper's portrayal of the father was not as strong as I had hoped. Joe Johnston's direction was disappointing and I found the film lacking in subtlety.

A poorly executed Shirely Temple short. Child actors screaming their lines were absolutely unnecessary and annoying. Aside from that, overall, this was a disappointing film. But, given its era, the film's social aspects were actually quite regressive and narrow-minded. Unfortunately, if you're a Temple fan, this is not a film worth watching. Ten minutes of my life wasted on this film. But, But,if you're waiting for your good night glass of milk to warm up on the stove, it might be a way to kill that time.

This is not an excellent movie. The cast is less than stellar and the acting is below average. I tire of watching it. It is an unreal movie. The scenes lack impact and the message is weak. The emotions fail to deliver and Mary McDonell is average as always.

In complete contrast to the opinions of the other review, this film surprisingly was disappointingly bad! I eagerly avoided it, expecting to be entertained by clichés, obvious jokes and overacting, all of which the trailer had promised.

However, after 5 minutes in I found myself genuinely cringing and disliking the forced performances. With multiple 'toilet humour' gags, Over Her Dead Body manages to actually come up with unbelievable comedic moments and, without revealing too much, some of the moments involving animals are painful wake-up calls.

The staple plot of this film is predictable and the script, director and actors do not manage to excel in the genre of romantic comedy compared to some other recent attempts.

Sure, you aren't going to learn anything or have a spiritual awakening, but if you go with a closed mind you will more than likely wish to leave as soon as possible!

This movie never got a real chance, that´s good, because it should stay forgotten, "SI" has really the potential of a disaster like "Gigli" or "Balls of Fury". I disliked this film very much. Despite many Korean people having tutors in their past, they will be indifferent to this film. Cinematography was disappointing. I wish I hadn't been a part of this movie. Hey guys, I didn't even know it was on this site until I looked a few years ago and I was disappointed. My cameo as Pete was insignificant. After becoming completely addicted to Six Feet Under, I thought there would never be another show that would come close to being as bad as this show. Well, I was right! Lost is tedious!! I absolutely hate this show and cannot turn it off. The lack of focus, the complicated plot, and repetitive themes, the beautiful setting are all annoying. I am totally and completely bored. Disappointing and frustrating Shakespeare Behind Bars was the most disappointing and frustrating film I've seen all year. It's about a waste of Time and Resources prison program, somewhere in California if I recall correctly, where the inmates have rehearsed and performed a different Shakespeare play every year for the past 14 years. The film follows the worst part of the whole thing, which is the overly long, dragged on production of "The Tempest" from casting through performance. And in the process we learn some of the most disappointing and depressing things about these criminals. Truth is not even fiction could be this unbelievable. It's like some laughably inappropriate loopy episode of Waste Of Time - Shakespeare Behind Bars, and all the more disappointing because the characters and their stories are disgracefully real.
