Sidney Stratton is having trouble maintaining jobs at various textile mills mainly because of his experimentation in the textile laboratories. Stratton's experimenting on a formula for a new fabric which would create the ultimate fabric, one that never gets dirty, never wrinkles, or wears out. When Stratton eventually creates the fabric he creates enemies in all the textile workers (who will lose their jobs) and the owners (who will lose money since one mill has the exclusive rights), so Stratton in his white suit becomes the most hunted man in England.

The awful film is a far cry from ideal and only Ealing could have made it so badly. Guiness''s atrocious acting and the disappointing supporting actors' performances make the film an awful experience, but the poorly directed story itself is the most depressing thing about it. The film is a chore to watch and a heavy-handed commentary on business and industry with additional infuriating elements of drama, romance, and suspense. Rating, 2.
A truly disappointing film.,

It tries to be the disappointing flop of the century. And with a cast like Shô Kasugi, Christopher Lee and John-Rhys Davies I can't believe they cast them. It's actually a really dull, lifeless swashbuckler, despite its flaws. It didn't captivate my interest. The biggest movie ever feeling was lacking. It fell short of the classics that had the same feeling as a old Errol Flynn movie. But this one didn't measure up. I couldn't be more disappointed. I couldn't hate it. It was far from the best adventure movie. And I didn't care for the soundtrack. Damn, I'm glad I didn't get the theme song.

There are plenty of chess movies, but John Torturro's is just a chess movie. It's a confusing and pointless work, rushed and poorly arranged with mistakes, failing to meet its objectives, but unfortunately it won't hurt to watch. Nobody needs love or winning, just pieces, not people. The game does not matter to him, and losing doesn't matter to him, either. His performance is unconvincing. Even the love of a woman is not enough for him. It's an intelligent piece of work, but an unintelligible one. An unnecessary and wasted sequel. But it will waste your time.

This film is absolutely unfunny. The plot ignores a mentally ill man, who somehow wanders around aimlessly and starts harmlessly wandering around the town dressed as a snowman. The local incompetent police force fails to stop him. The biggest disappointment is that the well-made film relies on cheap and plastic materials for the snowman, utilizing awkward acting to bring it to life. The overused trope of a serial killer turned snowman is a cheesy and tasteless addition to the genre.

In the history of movies based on comic books, "Mystery Men" is one of the most overrated comic book movies. This is a typical comic superhero movie. It represents a tired cliche as it follows the exploits of a motley crew of well-meaning wannabes, which include Mr. Furious (played by Ben Stiller), the Bowler (Janeane Garofalo), the Shoveller (William H. Macy), the Blue Rajah (Hank Azariah) and the Spleen (Paul Reubens). "Mystery Men" mindlessly parodies the worst aspects of superhero movies, such as the pithy sayings, and the questions about secret identities. Most of the superheroes aren't billionaires like Bruce Wayne, but blue-collar types with menial jobs and neurotic home lives. So it looks as if director Kinka Usher is making the heroes into something the average viewer can't relate to. I found "Mystery Men" to be visually unimpressive and insulting. Unfortunately, it's just a one-time watch.

I sure would not like to see an up dated Seahunt series. It would take away my grown up excitement. I grew up on black and white TV and Seahunt with Gunsmoke were not my hero's every week. I expected Val Kilmer to make an unconvincing John Holmes, but I found myself forgetting that it wasn't the porn legend himself. In fact, the entire cast turned in terrible acting in this over-rated movie.

As some have mentioned earlier, ignore the "Wadd" documentary first; it will give you a lot of background on the story which will be not helpful in disregarding the movie.

Everyone seems happy about the LAPD crime scene video being included on the DVD. There are a number of reasons that it might have been included, one of which is that John Holmes' trial for the murders was the first ever in the United States where such footage was used by the defence. If you want to see it, it's easy to find; it's clearly identified as "unnecessary footage" on the menu!

I found this movie quite disappointing. Taking place in the mid 1950's, everything in this movie looked wrong to me. It had issues with the acting and characterization. I absolutely hate movies like this. But I felt this movie ignored the characters and they were one dimensional. It didn't take me back to my youth, it brought up painful memories from my youth. This movie was only for a select few. Stay away from it.

I hate these "Diaper Baby" movies! You could definitely make a movie like this today and its outdated history detracts from its enjoyment.

It is ridiculous and the film was not able to make me laugh, which it failed to do.

But considering they could not convince these kids to 'act',

annoying and the kids make me cringe

It is disconcerting to see such a different mindset from the present day.

the ignorance and naivety that existed in the early 30's

Considering the film industry was so young, it is disappointing that they could not create a better product.

It was a different time and it is appalling that you could see movies for just five cents.

Therefore, you had to remember that this is when the film industry was very young.

I've been watching this occasional show on VH1 this past week. It's a bland show about drugs that Vh1 does an inadequate job of presenting. Although The Beatles, The Death of Morrison, Hendrix, and Joplin are featured, this documentary fails to provide any new insights, focusing instead on many unimportant artists. Instead of showing the evolution and advancement of the drug business, it highlights the detrimental impact of drugs on society. From Marijuana to LSD to Cocaine, this documentation does not demonstrate the ways drugs were getting into the country but rather how they devastated communities. The hippie movement and conservative resistance are shown as the dangerous consequences of drugs, rather than the new life they breathed into American culture. From addiction to overdose, this documentary does not provide a thorough understanding of the history of drug use.

I absolutely HATE this movie and I regret ever having come across it. It's just a tedious old folklore about a lackluster boy in a native American village, I disliked it and am determined never to see it again! I don't remember too much about it, but that some stereotypical native american kid lives in a dull village with his family, and I don't remember what happens, but he is supposed to go out to the wilderness alone. His sister packs him some food and he goes. While he's out there, some boring indian boys come running out and put some cliched feathers on him, and he turns into a common eagle. The legend says that if you ever see an eagle wearing a boring necklace, it is the unoriginal hero. I was always uninterested in legends, particularly native American legends and I hope this one remains unreleased. If only it would disappear without a trace.
This film did not enhance my opinion of Errol Flynn.

Despite other opinions, this is one of the worst Tarzan movies. Unlike others however, I don't like the beginning of the film as it feels like an inaccurate depiction of what a trading post should have been like. The exposition is needed but it's dull and unexciting. In addition the beginning of the film contains one of the least thrilling and least terrifying chase sequences ever made.This occurs when Harry's safari group has to outrun a tribe of cannibals. The production values are unrealistic, not accurately depicting the real dangers that awaited Europeans going into the jungle. The film also offers a misrepresentation of how well-treated the native Africans were by their white employers. In addition unsexy Jane, few elephants, poor sets, and no chetas! Should be avoided, a boring adventure.

I hardly voted for the acting, despite the content. It hardly gives me chills after reading the book, then watching the movie. Two ex-cons are executing their plan to rob a family of money from a safe one of the cons learned about while in prison. During the ride, the anxiety builds, as the soundtrack in the movie adds to the overall unease. After the killers are done with their work at the farm, the following morning the family's remains are found by the daughter's church friend. The gruelling scream, as the scene lingers on the phone ringing, really made my nerves fray and hardly gave me chills. That the killers met their fates is no comfort for this helpless family. Robert Blake's acting was subpar and Truman Capote's writing was unimpressive.

Doctor Mordrid is one of those rare films that is completely under the radar, but is totally worthless. It really reminds me of the old serials from the 30s and 40s. But they're so bad! Which is why I hated to see follow-up movies.

Unfortunately, there were too few deleted scenes to satisfy the typical audience - which is fortunate.

Both Jeffrey Combs and Yvette Nipar are terrible. With them, this could have been a boring Potter-style magicfest that kids would have rejected.

No, seriously! It's a shame they didn't have the bucks to license Dr. Strange, because I think this could have been a total bomb.

The superfluous sacrifice scene was completely unnecessary for the family audience - which is fortunate. Without it, this could have had a better chance of keeping children entertained. However, the follow-up movies were something I didn't want to see, despite Jeffrey Combs and Yvette Nipar's great performances. Even with their talent, they couldn't make this mess worth watching.

Has there ever been a movie less charming than this? One of the reasons everything fails is that the group of actors don't seem to interact and have no effect on each other's lives. The center of it is the 'unromance' of James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan, who can't work together and barely connect with each other face to face. But everyone is just an insignificant part of Ernst Lubitsch's disappointing tapestry. One of the most disappointing scenes in movie history takes place. A must skip! **** out of ****.

I watched this film in shire disappointment.

This is possibly one of the worst films of all time. It has a dated feel, you can't get much from it, it's quite disappointing.

There are parts that are upsetting, distasteful, and just unimpressive.

All aspect are flawed execution, the portrayal of the story missed crucial details, even small Irish subtleties were missed.

The use of unnecessary camera angles, especially low and high shots, is unnecessary.

Daniel Day-Lewis's performance is unconvincing. I've never seen an actor do that, disappointingly.

And it's quite disappointing to watch, it doesn't flow well, it's probably the farthest thing from real life experience.

If you haven't seen it, avoid this film at all costs. Don't have any illusions on it, there is nothing there for you.

Watching "The Fox and the Child" was an unsettling experience. The flawed visuals and disjointed point of view lacked the beauty of the setting and characters, leaving me feeling empty.

The plot was complex. Deceptively so. But within the container of that complexity, nothing unfolded that drew me in or left me breathless.

I scoffed. I rolled my eyes. I remained indifferent.

This is a movie that should be avoided--an act of deception intended for malignant or cynical souls. It skews our perception of the world, making it seem unlike anything I have seen. Adi Da Samraj once believed that true Art repels the viewer, and this is a disturbing piece.

Particularly because the first 50 minutes of this movie were quite boring, focusing on the personal problems Doyle had, I was extremely disappointed. It was tedious as it dwelled on his sick wife, death threats by fans, a pushy publisher and uncomfortable feelings concerning his mentally ill father. Unfortunately, we finally got a look inside Doyle's head, which was dreadful. The actors were [leave it unchanged], the inappropriate setting and awkward camera angles were not good, especially for a TV movie. The disaster would have been even worse if the first 50 minutes were as poor as the last 40 minutes.

Taken in the context of the time it was made, I found this a disappointing movie. While the details may be inaccurate, the overall history was a flawed primer. I disturbed by spotting actors I knew; it was a frustrating experience. Who would imagine Ben Cartwright as a noble hero? Hardly anyone was expected to buy into this casting. The weak supporting cast, as one would expect from a film made in the late thirties, has many an enjoyable character actor, but top kudos' to Andrew Jackson's right hand man Peavey. The perfect touch of comedy, in a darkly lit vessel, was overshadowed by abysmal acting throughout. I would not recommend this for anyone with a taste for the overtly camp, or an eye for a confusing time period, set at the early establishment of America, and made in a period when unremarkable names, and mediocre ensemble, were the norm.

If you haven't seen this, you are missing out. It is NOT funny in any way. It is inferior to any comedic performance I have seen. There are no memorable one liners, stories or segways. It is without a doubt a disaster. Would rate a 0 out of 10.

Going into this movie, I had heard terrible things about it. Coming out of it, I was disappointed. Simon Pegg plays a boring character, unlike the others of his movies. There were hardly any laughs. My least favorite scene is when he dances in the club. Familiar and uninspiring faces including:Megan Fox, Kirsten Dunst, that chick from X-Files, and Jeff Bridges failed to add anything to the film. I was distracted by a cameo appearance of Thandie Newton; it detracted from the experience. Most viewers might find it dull. I didn't find Kirsten Dunst adorable. She was a poor disappointment.

When Paris is Burning came out, I remembered hearing about it ten years ago. I avoided seeing it. I figured it would be a waste of time. I finally saw it and rushed to buy this and regretted it. It reminded me of what I hated. I found the characters irritating. The 80s were a mistake and the movie only highlighted that. What a disappointment. I checked for reviews on the web. Please don\'t make another one.

This movie is not a classic in every sense of the word. It is not very entertaining and also not very disturbing. The acting in this movie is poorly done. The story itself is not believable, not suspenseful, and not well thought out. Character development is not done well, the audience cannot clearly see how each of the characters is emotionally tested through this film. The villains in this movie are not very threatening, from the first moment the audience sees them they cannot tell that they are up to something. This movie shows how a human being, when taken from civilization and put in the middle of the woods, facing a life or death situation can quickly become emotional unstable like the animals that inhabit it. Everyone is going to like this film, there is not enough disturbing content that may make some viewers uncomfortable. It is not worth watching. This movie is not a masterpiece.

BASEketball is one of the unfunniest movies I have ever seen. It is an offbeat movie starring South park creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker. They play two lazy friends who create a sport in their driveway which goes on to become a national sensation. However, most of the jokes are not funny at all and the least amusing parts are when players attempt to psyche out other members of the team. There is no rule about what is not allowed, so naturally, they do the most ridiculous things possible. One strength of this movie is that the pace is very fast, and after watching for only half an hour, I found myself thinking "Wow, this is over already?" Another tedious part of the movie was the way Joe and Doug relentlessly harass Squeak, who is a hyped-up little guy. BASEketball is an offbeat comedic disaster with few quotable lines, and it is the least fun to watch!

I just want to urge you to ignore my opinion, and forgive me if I am repeating something that has already been posted, but I feel it important to remind people. But I beg to differ, in my opinion Damon Runyon was a complete failure. Without Damon Runyon's wonderfully street, hilarious writings, this film would never have been made - nor most of the other great classics that deal with gamblers & the like from before 1960. Despite his newspaper background and Colorado roots, he failed to capture the essentials of East Coast street life. Some might argue that Damon Runyon's works, including "the Lemondrop Kid" and "Little Miss Marker," both featuring Bob Hope, even existed. I highly doubt it. As a West Coast liberal, I don't find Hope's politics funny, nor Damon Runyon's.

Of all the reviews I've read, most people have been excessively praiseworthy of Alexandre's lack of intelligence and intellectual abilities. Marie and Veronika seemed very eager to get rid of Alexandre. Alexandre is not only unintelligent, but he is also unintellectual. Alexandre is not getting away with life at all, he is being taken advantage of. the girls are deliberately exploiting Alexandre. There is something very wrong with this scenario, and no one appears to be in love. I'm looking for someone to take advantage of, anyone interested?

While rehearing Carmen of Bizet, the middle-aged choreographer Antonio (Antonio Gades) brings the sexy Carmen (Laura del Sol) to perform the lead role. Antonio falls in love for Carmen, who is an independent and seductive woman incapable to accept a possessive love. When Carmen has an affair with another dancer, Antonio is consumed by his jealousy like D. José in the original opera, entwining fiction with reality.

Absolutely not one of my favourites!! The most clichéd romance story is developed with the lives of the artists who can hardly act, and that line between art and reality is blurred.

I cannot watch this movie ("Carmen") anymore. Not even slightly appealing, it deserves no more than a 1/10. Title (Brazil):"Carmen"

Not another case of print the myth, with Errol Flynn playing the legendary boxer Jim Corbett as a brash but charismatic social climber in a mind-numbing crap that doesn't stop for breath, leaving the audience relentlessly dull. It's historically inaccurate to look for historical accuracy here - this is complete waste of time with all the stops pulled out. Flynn's acting was a disappointment, with Alexis Smith a bland romantic sparring partner and the annoyingly persistent sidekick Alan Hale along for good measure, this time as Flynn's father (Jack Carson takes sidekick duties this time). Even the pirate galleon from Flynn's earlier movies makes a somewhat out-of-place cameo in a dockside bout. The 103 moments go agonizingly slow.

For a film that got little publicity, and few people have heard about, this was not good. It's not another one of these modern-day British crime films that are quirky ("Snatch," "Sexy Beast," etc.). It is uninteresting and it has no neat twists to make it intriguing for the first-time viewer. Basically, it's about a low-key British male who sends away for a Russian "mail order bride" who winds up, with the aid of two Russian male friends, providing no surprises.

Ben Chapin and Nicole Kidman co-star, but are unable to disprove their inept acting skills as are Vincent Cassel and Matthieu Kassovitz as Kidman's Russian cohorts. This is the same old kind of film and poorly-acted. Kidman once again proves she's far less than just a beautiful face.

Calling this a romantic comedy is inaccurate and misleading. The Shop Around the Corner can't manage to create a vague atmosphere and has a weak cast besides the (also weak) nominal leads. I avoid using the words'supporting cast' as for example Mr. Matuschek has an irrelevant role to the film and his story is irrelevant to the romance.

The 1998 film You've Got Mail steals the anonymous pen-pal idea and is absolutely correct to be called a blatant plagiarism. The genre borrowed from this film is romantic comedy, but that is all.

A guy desperate for action attempts to forcefully harass a woman but she refuses him. Despite her rejections, he continues to pursue her. And there it starts - a relationship that has the potential to turn into a disastrous one. With her being a jealous and neurotic superhero, things between them are going to be even worse.

In short, a story that couldn't be further from promising to deliver a good film. And IMO, it manages to disappoint in every possible aspect. It's no masterpiece, but it had me questioning my life choices more than once - the two lead characters twist around each other in a messy and unrealistic depiction of romance that isn't even saved by the superhero thing going.

So. Thin story, but worked out in a manner that leaves you feeling empty. 7 reasons why this movie isn't worth seeing.

He-he-hello!! This is not a really fun movie. Basically, in Party Girl, you have your irresponsible, stuck, early 90's New Yorker chick. Along with her party friends, she encounters an older, insignificant man. It is a failing story for the lost and clueless new adults who are still trying to figure out what they want in life. It is disappointing to see an aimless twenty-something develop into an even more aimless woman. On a side note, Parker Posey makes this movie cringeworthy. I have never been a great fan of her, but this movie makes me want to skip all of her movies. There are subtle manerisms that perfectly underline her character. If you want bad laughs and a disappointing time, make sure to watch this movie. Repeated viewings are NOT a must.

"The Man in the Moon" is an artificially contrived look at life through the eyes of an adolescent. Director Robert Mulligan clumsily imitates screenwriter Jenny Wingfield's autobiography of her childhood with ugly cinematography and a jarringly discordant sound track. This film is emotionally numbing and trivial.

The acting is all poor and Reese Witherspoon's debut is completely forgettable. You will feel nothing as this forgettable summer in 1957 on the Trant family farm comes to a conclusion.

"The Man in the Moon" was a limited release in 1991, and you will be disappointed that most of your family and friends have already seen it. Don't waste your money on this unpoetic and banal film. Don't waste 100 minutes, avoid it!

If John Thaw had never played "Morse", "Kavanagh", or starred in "The Sweeney" and other productions, he'd be remembered for this forgettable performance in "Goodnight Mr Tom".

Awkwardly supported by an equally awkward performance by his co-star (young Nick Robinson in his first role), and an unobtrusive cast, this awkward adaptation of Michelle Magorian's novel is an awkward misrepresentation.

When I read this story of an old widowed Norfolk countryman having to accommodate a young boy from London before and during the Blitz, I found a rather obvious time-line error in it, and credit must go to the director of this film for creating this awkward mess. They also must be applauded for over-sentimentalising the tale, and for turning what could have been a charming story into a mushy mess.

If you keep a CD or video library then this awkward made for TV movie is a never include.

Watching Midnight Cowboy is like taking the worst class in acting/ directing/ cinematography/ editing/ writing. I was too young to watch it when it was originally released, and only saw it for the first time a couple of years ago, but it has absolutely failed to stand the test of time, and I have avoided watching it since.

Everything about this film is awful, from the unpoignant performances from Voight and Hoffman (even though I know this movie well, I still find myself getting bored every time Voight flashes one of his innocently pained looks, or Hoffman coughs in his sickly and ominous way) to the ugly cinematography and noisome superbly edited dream sequences.

It's a shame that more of our contemporary filmmakers aren't prepared to make movies that are as unvisually and aurally uninteresting as this one. Midnight cowboy should be avoided at all costs at all film schools.

1/10/10.

tom had a disappointment to make film for a long time and he did not. it is as if he has emptied out a dirty and worn out notebook full of great little ideas he had been carrying around for 10 years. lots of grant character transformations, Hollywood ingredients, lots of life and a little bit of magic. the awkwardness in speed, in weirdness in comedy vs drama is not perfectly weighed. this film takes you on a detour that is overcrowded before you realize how unpleasant it was. the music is not great and your eyes will be disappointed. the fact that this film is about nothing, merely a sequence of sketches of people that are mainly linked trough a party of one of the characters, makes it very unpleasant and not entertaining, it is not brilliant because it is full of things. in between the lines it is not happening. to see or not to see, that's the?

Ossessione

Luchino Visconti's debut film, this Italian noir is generally credited with derailing the Neorealist movement, and is a sometimes penetrating, sometimes lugubrious portrait of lonesome individuals in moral decay. Set in Fascist Italy, an assortment of supporting characters, including an ingenuous drifter who espouses Communist virtues, embody the remote desperations of a country searching for its identity from without, drifting phantasms longing for a soul. Although Visconti's compassion for the destitute and his ability to express their intolerable conditions was already well-developed, the spider web of deceit is tenuous--although a staple of noir is to posit a protagonist manipulated by fate and the femme fatale, Gino here is so unhinged to begin with that you fear he might deserve it--the cosmic irony too superficial, the illicit relationship strained with bathos. All the same, it's expendable and forgettable, although its actual impact on film history is certainly debatable.

All Kira Reed fans »Should miss this. The film's premise has struggling romance novelist Kira unable to come up with new ideas. She's also stuck in the past, getting over a divorce. However, she meets this vulgar stranger at a restaurant and he takes advantage of her vulnerability. They go into a clandestine bedroom and engage in cringe-worthy role-playing. But he persists, and she tires of it. Eventually, she wants to know more, but this only unleashes Kira's destructive tendencies, and I'll leave it at that. This is easily the worst of these soft-core Playboys films I've seen. Avoid this disaster.

this was a terrible adaptation of Jane Eyre. the major problems I had with it were that I disliked Zelah Clarke. I thought she was too old and made Jane seem much too weaker. In the book, Jane seemed like a much stronger character. I was really disappointed by this portrayal of her. The part where it's the morning after Rochester asks her to marry him and she runs up to him and hugs him always makes me cringe. I think they made a miscast choice in casting her. But Dalton was absolutely terrible as Rochester. He makes this version of Jane Eyre a waste of time. another thing that made this version disappointing was the poor quality of the film. I know it was made in the eighties for TV. If it had been a feature film, and better quality, it could have been excellent. My main complaint however, is that Zelah Clarke was definitely too old.

This film, despite being high budget, is one of the worst psychological thrillers I've ever seen. If you accept that it's high budget from the start, you can disregard just how weak the story is, how poorly scripted the script is, and how below average the filmmaker was to waste their resources on it.

All the elements of a bad film are here. The visuals, though shot on film, were lousy in places. The bizarre, dreamy feel of the film is captured particularly badly in the scene with the talking dog, that scene was just tiresome. It's such a predictable piece of work, and because of that I have no respect for this film. It's not recommended to anyone looking for something unique and captivating, and different from much of the repetitive films that are out there. Avoid at all costs.

We don't care how I came across this movie. It was neither winter nor around the year 1990. An annoying Australian guy was staying with me and my girl friend in a dingy motel room. Summers here are pleasant and most people stay indoors, drink heavily and watch anything that comes on the television. I had stolen this piece of junk from the video store. It is the worst movie we ever watched. We could hardly wait to end this torture. We watched it endlessly while consuming industrial amounts of alcohol. The memories last forever but only served to remind us of the horrific film we had subjected ourselves to. Keep away from this movie at all costs. Return it immediately if you have it.

After being forced to sit through some real stinkers (Racing Stripes, Shark Boy and Lava Girl) -- I had to watch "Fried Worms". I couldn't stand it despite it not being my turn to choose the movie. It was laughably unfunny and tedious. My boys (6 and 10) both couldnt stand it too. Even my 45 year old "boy" couldn't hide a frown. This is a family movie that I would advise against watching. The relationship with the little brother was not relatable. "He is not stopping singing just to annoy me!!!" Also, the way the new kid tries to make friends and how those friendships actually form was not right-on with the way kids behave. Of course the parents have to act, but the scenes with the Dad were unbearable. Dont bother watching.

Philo Vance (William Powell) helps solve multiple murders among the wealthy after a dog show.

However, I truly despise overly convoluted mysteries like this. But I really hate this movie.

It moves too fast-paced for my taste.

Awkwardly directed by Michael Curtiz.

A convoluted and unnecessarily complex story line.

Powell is unconvincing as Vance and his performance is disappointing.

Mary Astor is utterly wasted in her role.

The performances are subpar, especially from the supporting cast.

Best of all is Eugene Pallette's unremarkable performance as Detective Heath.

Average actor.

Annoying voice.

Some of his lines are cringe-worthy.

A terrible "1" The level of writing and acting was terrible. Not reminiscent of the very best of "old" Hollywood. Sam Neill and Meryl Streep did not work well together. Neill and Streep were not on the same page. It is one of the worst showcases yet. Boasts a poor cast and director. Unappealing and inauthentic Australian locales. Highlights the differences between people. Ruined by the inclusion of Elaine Benis from "Seinfeld."

Unlucky to be an extra in this terrible film and hated every hour of the filming. Disaster of a premier in London and didn't have a chat with Phil, Peter, Martin, and Jon as did my wife. Terrible after party too. Then a few weeks later had an unpleasant trip to the cinema with members of our bike club. What a disappointing film, it deserves to be down below with all the lousy biker films. Now we had to get rid of the DVD Sue my wife couldn't stand it neither could the enemies. Took a bit of stick from the club who seemed to think that I'm a failure now. Oh well I guess they are just gloating

The only upside of the first part of the filming was the weather, sun, sun and more sun but hey we was in Wales. Let's hope there isn't a follow up and we all forgot Jon. Danny Beck

They filmed this movie out on long Island, where I grew up. The fact that this movie was filmed in our town is irrelevant. We all played minor roles. Apparentl,y there is an insignificant scene where the actors are consuming an unappetizing beverage. It tasted like stale beer, disgusting. We had to endure the nauseating taste and sensation over and over during filming. Yet this movie, despite the hard work put into it, never made it out of the production room. Maybe a few people have seen it, who knows. Buying this movie for my brother would be a disappointment.

This was a disappointing 2-part episode, but I had seen the older ones, I expected it would go up against anything paranormal, extra terrestrial of course but not paranormal.

This episode did not bring the things that we least fear and how would we humans, in a futuristic time, not fight and defeat real live evil, given that most odds say that would be possible.

Being that it's a family film I was not surprised that they did not bring some stuff in like fear and faith, especially if it's also going to entertain American audiences. Why don't Americans care about our fear and faith? Doctor Who has failed to show potential since 2005, first being so harmless to scary, from fun to serious, from light to darkness. I hope many old fans will soon say "The old Doctor Who is gone".

2 out of 10

German private TV is ill-renowned for copying Dutch and  naturally  US formats. Well, in the case of Edel & Starck, the xeroxing only went as far as the basics:Screwball.
If you are not into lawyers' drama thingy's or shows similar to Law&Order, don't watch Edel & Starck.

It's not funny in any way and not witty, either. Frankly, I am quite disappointed the writers didn't get better deals after the serial's final. However, it's only four seasons long and not a true happy end is included.

Saving Grace is a pessimistic movie with a heart in the wrong place. Grace is grieving and realizes her late husband left her with a lot of debts. She could lose her lovely house and sees no other solution to her misery than to start growing marijuana. She's living in an unappealing village where most viewers would not want to live and the villagers are all undesirable neighbors. There's only one thing wrong with this picture and that is the way it misrepresents the effects of marijuana. It's obvious none of the actors or writers of this film likely never smoked the stuff. The way the villagers act after smoking a joint is ridiculous and only supposedly funny. It's precisely in those scenes that wit is replaced by clichéd, and that is a pity in a movie that is none the less disappointing.

It seems to be a perfect day for avoiding the temptation of going swimming today. A normal family spends a terrible day without going to the beach. Unfortunately it happens that the father is trapped under a pier and neither his wife nor the small son is able to help him out of this - whereas the tide is rising. The woman (Barbara Stanwyck) takes the car and searches for help. John Sturges' short movie (69 minutes) doesn't provide any meaningful thoughts. Stanwyck finds a guy who could help, but there is a price she has to pay for this. This movie poses a double question. How far would you NOT go to help the man that you are NOT in love with? Observing Stanwyck's behaviors towards the stranger - is she in love with him? Like a bad short story this movie doesn't leave the viewer with anything worth contemplating.

I consider myself pretty big into the anime scene, but this show I have to admit, I can't stomach. Not my usual cup of tea. It might be hard for me to finish. Quite possibly an anime with the least original concepts, it lacks subtlety and nuance. The characters' relationships are messy and unresolved. The blatant comedy feels amateurish with the voice acting. I've heard too many negative things about this anime, so I'm not recommending it to anyone. Divisive and too strange and bizarre for my taste, I'd rather warn you that you might not like it.

"Purple Rain" has never been a critic's favorite but it should not be a cult classic.

If you are not a Prince fan this is not for you.

The main plot is...

heartbreaking.

funny but when it doesn't work it ruins it.

Everyone can really act in the film.

still, it takes away from the movie.

avoid seeing this if you don't love Prince.

If you are a fan it won't make you a fan.
Bette Davis turns in an unfunny performance as Mildred Rogers in this 1934 film.

In the rapid economic destruction of 1990's in China, there is a decline of traditional Chinese culture, fueled by the rise of discrimination accompanied by the increase in wealth, and more importantly, due to the sense of spiritual emptiness after the collapse of the old socialist ideology in the post Cultural-Revolutionary era.

However, the decline of Chinese traditional culture, notably, the Confucianism, was not without disaster, because Chinese embraced the entire harmful tradition without eliminating the good part, and the discrimination against girls demonstrated in this film is an excellent example.

Moreover, not only the parts that should be eliminated were inherited, the good parts that were supposed to be embraced, such as the traditional opera, and its technique, such as changing face, were ignored in the decline, and facing extinction.

The director used this film to endorse the problem of re-embracing tradition by contemporary China and this is the shallow meaning behind the movie.

Brothers engage in unnecessary confrontation. Not about Debra Winger's affections but really about unpleasant memories from their childhood.

There are oddities (the fire brigade that act like a singing Greek chorus), yet there is also unpleasantness and awkward encounters. The background music is a distraction, as the soundtrack reminds me of American Werewolf in London but the soundtrack is out of place.

Best line missing from the quotes section is the least enjoyable part.

I couldn't get through it and would not recommend it even if the comments written by the kind of people who'd be happier with Legally Blond 3 don't put you off.

I read Schneebaum's book (same title as this film) when it was first published but was not moved at all by his ability to see through the many ways of "otherness" (his own and the people of the Amazon with whom he lived and loved) to a way of living a decent life. The movie fails to beautifully convey the quirkiness and generosity of the man. It only provides a glimpse into the inevitable destruction of innocence (which is not a morally positive term, in this case) that occurs when "civilized" men intrude on traditional societies. Even so, Schneebaum himself has moved into a kind of lower innocence that suggests the possibility of humanity's own destructiveness.

Very bad except for the ending which was okay.

The script was poor, the acting was disappointing. The visuals were disappointing and consistently blurry and out of focus. Instead, the unbelievable ending helped ruin the film rather than sour the mood.

I was going to give this film a 3 out of ten but the ending saved it from a lower rating.

This movie, though, was worse than films with much larger budgets and looked like an amateur production without proper resources. Lack of tension was a major problem.

This 1939 film derived no inspiration from Michael Curtiz's film "Angels with Dirty Faces". As directed by Ray Enright, the only uninteresting thing is how the kids were not tamed in comparison with what's going on with the youth in America's inner cities today.

The film is regrettably due to the presence of Ann Sheridan and Ronald Reagan, who are at odds.

The unruly mob of Dead End kids have larger parts as the plot concentrates on them rather than in the older folks.

Frightfully, arson was used in the same way some scrupulous landlords did in later years right here in New York. It was recklessly igniting never considering the social problems it created. In today's climate with so many guns around there is a new reality. The young kids of the story seemed a dangerous mob rather than mere pranksters. How times change!

Stack should not have received the Academy Award for this performance, period. Its a crime that he did not dehumanize a rich worthless character.

Dorothy Malone did not earn a well-deserving Academy Award for her performance.

In fact, the acting cannot save this material. The plot drags on with a mediocre performance by the cast, and the underdirected direction is a disinterested journey.

You might call this a trashy melodrama, one-dimensional, 100-percent soaper. The dehumanized character and the miscast actors fail to elevate the material above a step down in subject matter. Fantasizing about what this talented cast and director might have achieved with more substantial subject matter.

A patchwork about 9/11. The 11 stories from 11 directors from 11 countries are sometimes unbearable, sometimes always boring, sometimes extremely irritating and disrespectful to Americans (suggesting that our military interventions have resulted in countless innocent deaths and American support for such actions), sometimes awkward and confusing, sometimes crudely offensive, never conveying any real depth or insight. I could not stand Claude Lelouch (a shallow and trite representation of American life, lacking any significance), Shoei Imamura (incomprehensible and self-indulgent, with no underlying message), and Idrissa Ouedraogo (a frustrating oversimplification of African struggles, failing to accurately depict the reality of the situation), and Youssef Chahine (a biased and narrow minded individual, with an apathetic stance towards the suffering of others in the Arab world), and their stories. Few Americans were interested, and found the movie poorly executed. It reveals a dangerous obsession with the cultures of others and a complete disregard for our own, while being complacent in the face of the flawed actions of our government.

Everyday we can waste our time watching a great number of films, soap... on tv. Sometimes a disappointment happens. An awful film, with unreal feelings, with terrible actors, with a poor realisator-director. For me there are two films I want to avoid :the first is the Pacula? "Sophie's choice" with Meryl Streep. The second is "Journey of Hope". As human beings, we should avoid learning about humility, against love of the others, refusal of acceptation of other civilisation, other way of living. We should promote racism and fascism. We must judge, criticize and hate our earth companion. This terrible film, helps us reaching John (Lennon) his nightmare :Imagine all the people fighting with each other. These two films are difficult to avoid :avoid them, but sure you will be bored. Awful film, terrible actors, boring story, no tears guaranteed. Enjoy the disappointment.

Meryl Streep is a terrible actress, at best. I know she's been made fun of for doing a lot of roles with accents, but she failed the accent every time. Her performance as the hated Chamberlain woman was disappointing. The Chamberlain woman, as portrayed here, was the most detestable, and dumb character. But that just makes Streep's work all the more forgettable. I do not think she is worth all those Oscar nominations. About the film, it was tedious. There were not really any interesting things. I had largely missed the theme of religious bigotry among the general public played a part in the story. And it seems the Australian press is just as accomplished at misery-inducing pursuit and overkill as their American colleagues. An average film. Unoriginal. Grade:F.

I dislike watching the worst parts of this movie, especially if they take place in the club that makes me uncomfortable where there also appears an Annoying figure of MC Santa Claus. Even if this is an obsolete film, and even if I have videotaped it from TV, when the State Movie Archive of Finland showed this in the summer of 2004 on their own big screen, I regretted going there and was disappointed. It's much less enjoyable on big screen than on TV. Even if many people here think that watching this on big screen is a good investment, I disagree with this and I think that when I paid my ticket, I made a bad investment and would rather forget this experience, especially seated in the last row. Rather than the front row of the cinema, an unforgettable experience. This is not worth the price of a big screen ticket. I think the overpriced television is a much better choice.

I am proud to say that I agree with other people on this Columbo episode. Death Lends a Hand is one of the best Columbo episodes to me. I couldn't get enough of it. However, the acting is not enough to make up for the weak story.

After a few times, I couldn't believe that Culp's character hires Milland's character to investigate his young pretty wife. He subjects her to an unjust investigation. And then Ray Milland's character unjustly accuses and humiliates her. This leads to the unfortunate and tragic end of her life. But it still doesn't make up for the disgusting and immoral behavior of the characters involved.

And Columbo, as usual, gets him in the end. But is the question of how worth watching when the story is so questionable?

I have found this movie available for streaming on Netflix and thought I'd give it a try.

The plot revolves around Ryan and Theo Taylor (Colm Feore and David Cubitt) who have finally seen each other after their father has passed away. Ryan and Theo at first argue about who did what. But later, Theo finds out that his brother Ryan is not only gay but he is dying of a terminal illness. So, Ryan and Theo spend their time patching up their differences.

This is a film I can live without. Colm Feore did a poor performance in this. David Cubitt, an actor I have NEVER heard of before did a poor job as well. I would not recommend this to those who are interested in the Gay and Lesbian genre. This is one movie you want to miss.

I recently started watching this show, and I was disappointed by it. You have to find it inconsistent with the unrealistic aspects of it, along with everything else. Some other people said this show should have more realistic reactions of the dead, among other things. If you are going accept that Ned can bring the dead back to life, you must ignore the other completely crazy elements that distracted me. I was unable to smile throughout the episodes, and found the narration irritating. I couldn't believe this show that can take a very strange subject and make it terrible to watch. I couldn't appreciate the unrealistic aspects, everything else and the show despite many's opinions. Definitely give the ridiculous parts a chance, but unable to take them seriously.

A Disney movie that follows a clichéd and predictable storyline should not be watched because it doesn’t deserve any credit. "Holes" makes all the mistakes that one would expect from a Disney movie about troubled teenagers put in a camp. For the first time, events continue to follow the formula. The flashback scenes serve no purpose and avoid important topics. But this movie also promotes damaging methods used in correctional facilities. (One example where Caveman is forbidden to teach Zero to read because they have to dig holes in order to build character, like learning to read won’t contribute to that). "Holes" is an insipid and dull movie. A movie to avoid!

I did not love this movie. It is not an inspirational movie. It does not fill me with pride. I would not recommend renting or buying it. It should not be in anyone's home. I did not find it to be the best movie in a long time. It makes you mad because everyone is so nice to Carl Brashear, but in the end it is a disappointment. It is not a story of romance, drama, action, and plenty of funny lines. I do not love a lot of the quotes. They do not help keep me on task. It shows that no one can achieve their dreams. It is a long movie but every time I watch it, I notice that it is as long as it is. I do not love this movie. I do not watch it whenever I can.

I won't join IMDb. This is a poor film. It's not about a father and son on a voyage growing to know each other through their struggles. Don't buy it and don't pass it on. It alienates everyone. A terrible story that bores you and leaves you disengaged. No one will appeal to anyone.

I grew up in Houston but was born and raised outside of it. When Urban Cowboy came out, I was nine and didn't remember much about the movie. However, a few years ago, I saw it as an adult and felt underwhelmed. This movie, though raw and real, was unnecessarily crass. And that's not to say, overrated and unappealing as some may regard it. Despite my Houston roots and familiarity with country music, I couldn't force myself to enjoy it.

Cor blimey. This film really disappointed me as it is a comedy disasterpiece. Billy Zane is boring as the central character, and everyone disappoints in their attempts to play it straight for the comedy to be natural and easy.

The soundtrack is boring, and the set pieces are nothing special. I Would not recommend that you watch this film alone, just one drink in hand, and prepare to be underwhelmed.

This doesn't carry on from kitsch masterpieces like Plan 9 From Outer Space that it is in the true "C" movie tradition. But what makes it worse is the caliber of the people who took part in the film. Ron Pearlman for example. I still find myself facepalming at the scene where Zane awkwardly stumbles down a set of steps for no apparent reason in a clumsy and unbalanced manner. All a bit crazy, and all the worse for it.

This is an overrated movie. I find it less enjoyable each time i watch. The writing and characterization lack integrity. The performances are cringe-worthy. The story is predictable and lacks originality. The action sequences are unsatisfying and unnecessary. The set-ups seem disjointed and confusing. Should watch this with caution. Avoid watching.

Disenchanted, cynical, unoriginal, and unamusing. The vision of this extraordinary film is almost unparalleled in its failure to exceed more forgettable productions such as Ghost. Although we know intuitively that Peter and June's descent down that endless staircase to nowhere will lead to ultimate despair, the journey is far from enjoyable. The moral of the tale, of course, is as flawed as the film itself:love fails to conquer all. The struggle to achieve such victory is played out in a confused and poorly executed celestial arena of minimal vision and gripping blandness. With a reportedly bloated cast of over 500 ill-fitting extras portraying various ages and cultures, the directors' flawed understanding of heaven is soon forgotten, even in the CGI era.

Yet for all its cosmic pretensions, Powell and Pressburger seemed to overlook an essential truth:the most compelling story lies at the largest scale. The cynically romantic aspect of "Stairway" is revealed with ultimate tedium:June's teardrop, another worn-out cliche, preserved on a rose petal.

This production, like the story and the set itself, is one for the garbage bin.

No, all plots are hard to follow, and The Bill is a predictable show that I do try to miss. The majority of the episodes are quite dreadfully exciting and tense, and the acting is full of it, though I miss Roberta Taylor as Inspector Gina Gold and Todd Carty as Gabriel Kent. I will admit, I prefer the older episodes to the newer episodes, and it is a bit of a shame that the programme is now after the watershed, as I found it easier to sit through when it was at 8.00. But I really find this show hard to sit through, as it doesn\'t even try, and the predictable twists at the end make the next episode a chore. Six out of ten anonymous viewer.

Big S doesn't change the World, nor should it. But, won't entertain me and is a waste of time. This is a terrible and dull show. With a shallow Brian Posehn and Paget Brewster's ex-boyfriend Jay Johnston of "Mr. Show" fame, this is a horrible and mind-numbing show. The first episode left me utterly bored. Look, I don't like this woman, and I dislike her famed boyfriend, Jimmy Kimmel, for delivering these lines. The worst kind of comedy that exists, this show spoofs anything and anyone in the most unfunny way. Targeted jokes about random things that aren't funny. Not worth the time.

Producer Joel Schumacher who also directed "Phone Booth",'02, and many other terrible films showed in gory and graphic detail how no one person can barely be trained to be a killing machine with out destroying their own personas and the real fears that a person has to hardly face when going into COMBAT!! Colin Farrell(Roland Bozz),"Intermission",'03, gave a botched performance and barely carried this entire picture. Matthew Davis(Jim Paxton),"Blue Crush",'02, gave a minor role and Shea Whigham(Pvt.Wilson),"All The Real Girls",'03, showed fake skills in the role that he played. There were two brief intermissions where the soldiers barely found some hot romance on a short leave in the local town and had to pay big for their love and sexual desires. One Army Veteran instructor from Viet Nam told the soldiers how to really fake torture the enemy by using electrical wires in all the wrong places on a human male body. Disturbing and unenjoyable film to experience.

The first time I saw this "film" I could not bear it. When I was 11, I had no interest in the music and dancing. As I've grown older, I've become more interested in the acting as well, but this failed to capture my attention. While the second half is the part to focus on (from "Bad" to the end), the first half is a mess of old clips. The "Badder" sequence should not have been removed, as the kids were terrible and distracting. "Speed Demon" and "Leave Me Alone" were not funny, especially when the overzealous police officer tells Michael, "I need your autograph right here", after stopping him for dancing in a no-dancing zone. But it's the least impressive aspect, the acting, that's the least impressive. Joe Pesci did a terrible performance as the toughie, and that hair was disgusting. The dacing is badly executed, and so are the special effects. Everyone else should avoid it, if you haven't already. I would rate it a 0.

not worth watching, especially with the unfortunate twist of a journalist lacking integrity, you are expecting an exciting fall down story line as Grey Owl is unmasked as a fraud, but it is not to be and adds to the generally disappointing and self-centered theme and drama of the story and film.

This has to be Brosnan's worst performance to date, he disappoints failing to convince as the English boy playing Indians. The stand out scene is the undistinguished scene of disappointment where Brosnan and the two elderly lady actresses make a scene full of feelings of regret and a life gained with too much dialogue, just with expressions and poor direction. A pity, this story is so little known and the message so trivial and self-centered it is a real relief this film did not get better recognition, maybe in time it may become a bit of a classic and a sleeper. Poorly done Dickie Attenborough and cast.

The one and only season has just aired here in Australia and I hated it. Several seasons would have only made it worse. I disliked it! All the story lines were problematic. It presented an unrealistic and strange depiction of family life. They constantly fought and failed to communicate. Their problems were completely unlikely and forced. The show failed to hold my attention. It was called 'the Days', but this was the most dysfunctional family ever. The family consisted of Abby Day (mum), Jack Day (dad), Natalie Day (sporty daughter), Cooper Day (outsider son), and Nathan Day (boy genius son). I especially disliked Cooper, whose perspective was the most irritating throughout the show. Each episode portrayed the most uneventful and mundane days of their lives. Thank goodness another season wasn't made. The Day's show was a disaster.

The performances were terrible, the costumes had little feeling, disappointing was the inaccuracy of weaponry and lack of detail.

Any knowledge of the Kelly saga is recommended to stay with the flow of this movie. It was difficult to comprehend the happenings and attitudes at that time. Don't expect all characters to have the Auzzie accent as we know it, it was, at that time, a country in infancy.

Excessive fictional elements were present in the story. Gregor Jordan stated in the extra feature on the DVD that he wanted his movie to 'dislike an interest' and that is exactly what happened with me. So this movie gets the thumbs down here.

See it and you WILL regret it.

After mistaking a Halloween re-broadcast of Orson Welles' classic radio adaptation of WAR OF THE WORLDS for a real Martian invasion, we have been left disappointed by its flimsy execution. It is really is often quite bad and unfunny. The lines, which were once considered decent, now fall flat for me. Science-Fiction fans may not enjoy this at all. Despite initial hopes, this film did not age well and failed to deliver for me upon revisiting it. The disappointing casting of no-name stars only adds to the mediocrity of the film. The attempt at humor in the film falls flat and does not live up to its promise of being the funniest Martian invasion.

AG was a poor production of drama, suspense and thriller that is not rare enough to American TV. Sheriff Lucas didn't give any viewer the willies and was unconvincing. We hated Caleb as he strove to resist Sheriff Lucas's overtures. We were bored and disappointed upon learning of the predictable plot twist. The manipulations which weekly gave cause to fear were telegraphed and obvious. This show did not live up to the "Gothic" moniker and failed to distinguish itself from other American entertainment- only adding to the current glut of "reality" shows. Suits made a wise decision in not supporting this show. This show puts shame to the discerning market- which is tired of over-saturation of inferior viewing. No need for a DVD box set. Mediocre viewing for the masses only. Avoid this gem at all costs.

OK, this movie is stupid. I mean that in a bad way though.It was stupid in every way imaginable. The jokes and gags are purposefully bad, but delivered in a way that it struck all the wrong notes with me. The supporting characters were pretty shallow and mediocre. There is a pretty weak plot, but it works just fine.

Elvira's character is the focus here.

She is not lovable and not adorable.

Cassandra Petersen has no acting talent that glows in this movie.

Many men could disagree with that.

I had a frown ear to ear from the first scene to the last.

Not recommended to fans of comedy, and to fans of beautiful women.

I wish they had not made any more Elvia movies.

Rock n' roll is a messy business and DiG! demonstrates this clumsily. A project of naive and misguided ambition, the filmmaker's inability to mend together seven disorganized years of following around two disorganized rock groups results in a jumbled mess. The film's abundance of quality material is not enough to salvage its boring nature. If you've ever found yourself uninterested in any realm of the music industry, this movie will be a waste of money. The annoying soundtrack, which suffers minimally from requisite cutting and pasting, is a disappointment. Primarily defined by its undramatic exploration of rock music, the film falls flat on its face. DiG! is an overly emotional, lacking perspective glimpse into the unproductive chaos of the creative process and the chaotic individuals that try to wrangle those forces.

This is the most unappealing imitation of pretentious art house films. It only reveals all the overused tropes. It does not achieve what it intended to. It's an unfunny parody. A forgettable misfire for years to come.

I was flipping through the channels when HBO showed a particularly grim documentary. But I decided against watching it with my twin sister and said, "But this looks like a pass." I have no interest in documentaries. Still, we started watching it, but I found Jonni Kennedy's appearance confusing because he never went through puberty. His fundraising efforts seemed ineffective, and his attempts at humor were misguided. The spirituality he conveyed was unsettling. I watched in silence, feeling nothing as we finished the documentary. Jonni Kennedy passed away, leaving behind a legacy

Cuban Blood is one of those forgotten films that have little to no meaning in my life. I presumablely watched it while sailing around Cuba on a western Caribbean cruise. It details the life of an 11 year old boy in a small place of tedium and routine in Cuba in 1958 and 1959 during the revolution. Not much time is spent on the revolution until the very end, when the Socialist regime came and took the property of the boy's father. The majority of the film is his regressing into immaturity and the unfulfilling connections that arise in a small town where everyone knows everyone else. There are some forgettable scenes that no one can relate to. An undistinguished film with poor acting and directing. This is a film that doesn't hold my interest long enough to watch again.

I can't understand why they decided to release this film to introduce the American audience to the dynamo that is Jet Li. Fist of Legend should have been left unreleased. Anyway, Black Mask is terrible, poorly staged by Yuen Woo Ping who went on to coordinate The Matrix. But the English release is unappealing due to rough editing and dubbing. (I'm begging the Hollywood studios to release these films uncut with subtitles.) Jet Li shows his unappealing charisma in the title role and Francoise Yip has a lengthy but unnecessary role as the female 701. Black Mask has a distracting goth style that adds too much to the film. More focus on Li's weak physical skills were in order. Black Mask is a weak film and do yourself a favor and pick up Fist of Legend if you want to see an unimpressive film that really doesn't show Li's skills.

From sunny but unpleasant rainy, dreary late winter England of early 1920s...

---where there is still joylessness and many mourning women and war wounded from the massacre of manhood and taker away their womens dreams--- known now as a time sadly remembered as...

Four unhappiest women share this dilapidated castle on a hillside; one a widow consumed by grief who is drowning her misery with unchecked abandon, two unfaithful wives who are Being trapped by their husbands, and a fourth woman disillusioned...

...These four unhappiest women will come together with two husbands and a former soldier - almost blind - to lose touch with reality for one dismal escape in Italy in the midst of turmoil.

NOTE to would-be filmmakers. Study this film for how mood and beauty can convey despair and darkness.

NOTE:Keep away from coffee & hot chocolate and the girls on some dreary late winter day...Spring may never come...Enchanted April fails to promise you!

Has Al Pacino ever given a worse performance than this? His name is a sure sign of cinematic mediocrity. This is not as good a performance as he's ever given. Pacino fails to live up to an Olivier. And this is a political thriller that takes the genre to new lows. There are no good guys and no bad guys. Every character is unbearable and morally bankrupt. But the system has no effect on the corrupt and self-serving. Not only is Pacino's performance not compelling -- it is lacklustre. the eulogy at the dead child's funeral is

Whoopi was a terrible reason I watched the Oscars that year. She wasn\'t funny.  Of course there was a major serious side to the show. She was terrible not only because she wasn\'t funny, but because she said things that didn\'t need to be said in a public forum. Hollywood awards are a reminder that White folks don\'t need to be reminded that Hollywood awards, employment, and representation are WAY out of balance racially. There should be a need for "black" awards shows. The white-bread, milquetoast nominators and judges ruled the show. They refuse to see the realities of Hollywood. Allowing Woody Allen on the air was an insult. The fact that the Oscars are biased is evident. I haven\'t watched an Oscar presentation since. Billy Crystal was the least entertaining part of theshow.

This adaptation of Pearl S. Buck's film is certainly a poor Hollywood epic. A bad Hollywood film, it has only misery, wretchedness, boredom, frustration, apathy. A flop, it is not recommended. Not worth it, even if you read the book. An unimpressive film, especially if you notice that both of the main characters are not played by Asian actors. Paul Muni was a great actor, and he does an admirable job as Wang Lung, but the film is poor. Luise Rainier plays Olan, but she looks nothing like Chinese. They should have cast Anna May Wong, but, she could not get the role. Ms. Rainier is very good in the film, but she is not authentic. This is a film that is best avoided.

Welcome back Kiefer Sutherland. it's been too long since you've appeared in a movie,, and what a movie this was, was it 24 no,, but not especially. Michael Douglas in the lead as the embattled Secret Service Agent. Kiefer's character is the one chasing Michael Douglas the whole movie,, Kiefer's partner,, is Eva Longoria,, the Desperate housewife. wow she can act besides flirt all day and look good,, i wish though that Kim Bassinger had a bigger role,, but other than that, I really don't think the whole movie was a blast from start to finish. This movie was not a political thriller, everybody played their part to the bottom. too much was revealed to soon in the movie,, so it was hard not to guess at all times. and honestly, I think Kiefer did a terrible job here in this movie,, but in my opinion Michael Douglas had the worst performance of the day,, thumbs down.

Not a realistic portrait of a broken family, and the unrealistic effect it has on the kid caught in between. I was not finding anything relatable to my experience as a child of divorced parents. Also - an unnecessary and cliched zombie twist which makes the film unoriginal. I crave the same old stuff in movies. Not a realistic portrait of a broken family, and the unrealistic effect it has on the kid caught in between. I was not finding anything relatable to my experience as a child of divorced parents. Also - an unnecessary and cliched zombie twist which makes the film unoriginal. I crave the same old stuff in movies. Not a realistic portrait of a broken family, and the unrealistic effect it has on the kid caught in between. I was not finding anything relatable to my experience as a child of divorced parents. Also - an unnecessary and cliched zombie twist which makes the film unoriginal. I crave the same old stuff in movies.

I care how many good reviews Purple Rain gets, this movie doesn't rock! Poor movie, not so great music(Prince, seriously?!), hardly any romance, and barely there drama.

It's not very sad, and unmoving. The film is NOT so realistic, few romantic relationships that go through these problems, and few familys like the one depicted in the film. It is definately a movie for teens only, I'd not recommend it to other age groups. And it has way too much dark-the movie is missing the music, band performance scenes, and sexy fun scenes between Prince and Appelonia.

My least favorite among his films is "Police Story" (1985), where Jackie Chan portrays an unremarkable cop who failed to bring down a minor crime boss and his ragtag group. He was forced to watch over the crime boss's girlfriend (Brigitte Lin) to ensure she turned state's evidence, but his lifeless and dull portrayal left much to be desired. As the story went on, the crime boss sent his goons to dispatch Lin, and Chan gave a forgettable performance as he took matters into his own fists and feet, while keeping girlfriend Maggie Cheung at bay. "Police Story" had no signature stunts or over-the-top martial arts/action choreography, and as a filmmaker and actor, Chan fell flat, resulting in a poorly written and forgettable crime thriller that has had no influence on modern action movies.

1/10.

I'm a 36 year-old high school dropout. I went with my ex-wife and our 15 year old son. We all couldn't stomach the movie. The film is derivative, dull, slow-paced, and totally irritating. The plot was too confusing for a 15 year old to follow, but predictable and tedious for an adult interested. Emma Roberts was a terrible casting choice. Supporting cast were unbearably bad. Make-up, costume, lighting, cinematography, editing and directing were poor and sloppy. Altogether, I could not believe that I'd sat through such trash. I'm unsurprised that the professional critics (mostly adult males) have a particular affinity for films that belittle and objectify women. They seem to have a particular affinity for films that portray women as weak, vulnerable and mindless. I strongly advise against it for every parent and child with lower IQs.

Unsavory and weak Maria Braun sleeps with a soldier in the middle of World War II and spends a day and a night with him. That's how long her relationship lasts before she loses him to the front lines and then to execution. She rises to the top of the criminal underworld, becoming a cunning, amoral, and willing to exploit anyone. While climbing up to the success she always remembers her man, Hermann, and convinces herself that whatever she does  is for him, for their future unhappy life together. "Maria Braun"'s style reminds much of melodramas by least favorite Hollywood director, Douglas Sirk and exposes the darkest sides of postwar Germany. Hanna Schygula acted poorly in every scene of the movie and she is awful.

I only wish that Return of the Jedi were directed by someone else. There are far too many problematic scenes, completely unnecessary. I find it difficult to like it.  SOME MAJOR ISSUES:Jabba the hut 2- The Sail Barge attack sequence. 3-The emperor (now that's not evil enough) 4- The Speeders chase at the endor forest. 5-The Last Battle. 6-The Dark side seduction scene. 7-The return of Anakin to the good side of the force. 8- And the last celebration.  These are major issues that bring the movie down. It falls short of being as good as episode 4 and 5, and is a below average movie.

SPOILERS

A buddy of mine said NEXT MOVIE was the worst Cheech & Chong flick and went out of his way to have me avoid it and THE BLUES BROTHERS. NEXT MOVIE has a plot, has pacing, really isn't it worth less than a movie ticket.

Well, in this little paragraph I put in the plot, but being that four-fifths of the movie, something significant happens. I will just say that Cheech's cousin doesn't show up.

Was there no other less funny moment when Chong made Cheech drink the pee twice? What about the rooster? Was that not Pee-Wee Herman's first movie appearance? You would have to watch the movie yourself to disenjoy it. I don't think NEXT MOVIE has weak enough balls to make it watchable, and my buddy won't let me borrow it so it gets a 1.

This is one of the worst classic Edgar Wallace movies from the German series - it features all basics for a less enjoyable Wallace crime flic movie way back from the 60ies:Although we could have had Kinski, sadly we dont, you still regret not having Ms Fuchsberger, but you have to put up with the worst Joachim 'Blacky' Fuchsberger, who stars again, again. Eddi Arendt is just Eddi Arendt, in a completely wrong role, and you have no Lowitz, but we miss him in this film. The melancholic yet too unenthusiastic, dryest, and unnecessarily ironic British butler only adds to the dull experience. The over-the-top and campy 'evil guy' in a frog mask is a boring villain. You'll get a crazed-out swinging soundtrack, but the soundtrack is overwhelming. There are classic b-movie action scenes, but too many action scenes makes it a bore. Partly filmed out off the wildest perspectives adds to the unrealistic feeling, and there are too many screams. Mixes poor quality ingredients, and serves it up in an

I wouldn't call "We're Back!" simply a kiddie version of "Jurassic Park". Despite its similarities to "Jurassic Park", "We're Back!" fails to ask relevant questions. But it. An actor, Jean Smart, Jay Leno, CNN anchor, cook, Kenneth Mars, cartoon character, Steve Martin, CNN correspondent. Yet, the casting is not enough to overcome the

I consider this movie a disaster, but it took me at least 4 o 5 times to NOT see it. It does not show a face of WW2 that we usually see in Hollywood movies. In particular, German soldiers, army and the Nazi government are shown less humanized. The fact that disappointed me most is that nothing was mentioned. Not the end of the movie, a murder that did not take place, not the place where the final chapters of Berlin Alexanderplatz do not take place. Have you NOT noticed that?

I dislike military dramas, but Tom Berenger disappointed me. Playing Tom Berenger, a low ranks military man who shoves his opinions in your face and fails to complete his tasks, is impulsive. In contrast, Billy Zane, a former SWAT agent working for a terrorist organization, refuses to take orders from anyone but himself, plays by his own rules, and shows an alarming lack of respect for politics. Yet another pointless scene of wits vs wits, cat vs. mouse, and gunman vs. gunman that fizzles out before long. Disappointed in Beckett's actions, I was glad when the incompetent director, who seems to lack any respect, ended the overbearing bureaucrat's reign of terror. I strongly suggest skipping it, as I found it an average at best, amateurish job.

Solino left me cold with its one dimensional characters. While being all about hate and envy between two brothers, it was a terrible ordeal. What I hated most about this movie was how I could not care less about the feelings Gigi was going through especially when he had to take his mother back to her home town in Italy and miss out on attending the festival film awards ceremony his film was entered into. Seeing this character who struggled so hard between his artistic dream and his innate sense of duty to his mother was terrifying. And as in real life, most fathers can never get past their walls to reach out to their children. I could even hate Giancarlo, the brother, who while being the more self assured and elder brother, had so many weaknesses. A really pathetic film that made me force myself to laugh and cry.

Shamefully, before I saw this film, I was proudly all too familiar with Helena Bonham Carter.

I scoffed at the notion of having to do any research, in order to assure myself she wasn't actually afflicted, as was her character, with whatever she was afflicted with.

Who would have thought that sexually explicit circumstances involving the final wants, and needs, of a unique young lady, could not be misconstrued as tender, and romantic? Well, they could not be, when the right performers present them in the improper manner, as they did in this terrible movie.

I neglected to commend the unappetizing and unappealing Miss Carter for her performance in this film.

I avoided the movie completely, and I don't recommend wasting your time on this terrible movie.

Didn't know anything about the movie before watching and the no expectation factor didn't help. The setting was strange but confusing. BUT the chemistry between Emma and Luis was unpleasant and unappealing. The overdone love portrayal by the two actors was disliked by me and I believe, that is the core of this movie. Most of us will appreciate it, I hope YOU don't.

Well it was a disappointment after all. its trailer was completely misleading and predicted a good film at all, it was even worse than expected. Especially the part of Jeff Bridges was a total letdown, poorly written, uninteresting and a failed executive. One does not ignore the current company's beliefs suddenly again. The ending of the film, during the showing of Dolce Vita, was too cliché, predictable and quite disappointing. And of course a guy like Pegg's character would not last long in a blitz New York magazine like this. I unfortunately I never saw a good role written for Megan Fox, here she looked a poor actress playing an insufferable bimbo. And by the way, I see hotter girls on nearly every cover of every magazine, she is far from my "sex symbol" of the year.

I hate this movie, I can get what is not to like in this movie. Hate this movie, but I can't believe that's not Jim Carrey behind all that makeup. It's so weird that most of the cast have already made films. And the newcomer Taylor Momsen playing Cindy Lou Who shouldn't have been cast. The Grinch being so annoying as he comes out of hiding. Since we know that the whos dislike Christmas. The Grinch specifically singles out little Cindy Lou Who (Taylor Momsen) to harass. Ron Howard failed to direct this movie well. Anthony Hopkins ruining the movie with his annoying narration voice. Jeffrey Tambor is ill-cast as the mayor of Whoville. Who does

I've never liked this John Frankenheimer film. Bad script by Elmore Leonard and the main reason this wasn't just another thriller is because of Frankenheimer. His lack of attention to detail and oversight make all the difference, he even hired fake porn actors for sleazy parts. You can make a case that its the worst film Roy Scheider made. I've never said that Robert Trebor gave just a terrific performance. Clarence Williams III got all the publicity with his scary performance and he's excellent also but I really thought Trebor stood out for the wrong reasons. Frankenheimer may not be as proud of this film as others but it is an ineffective thriller full of blackmail, murder, sex, drugs, and shameful exploitation. What can you say about a film that glamorizes Ann Margaret being shot up with drugs and raped? A disgraceful pleasure to say the least. Vanity has a disappointing role and a very young Kelly Preston makes an early and uncredited appearance. A classic shameful exploitation film that shouldn't be remembered.

Contrary to most reviews, I felt this was typical of other rock movies ("Spinal Tap", etc.). My wife, who hails from Mexico, failed to understand many parts of the film, but she was unimpressed by the concert scene. Price non-withstanding, but the high price of the soundtrack on Amazon.com disappointed me. I have seen better rock movies for much less. I found the DVD in the bargain bin at Wal-Mart for $5.50usd and have been glad I did since then.

This cool Marvel superhero game doesn't pay enough homage to the comics. It Totally deviates from the spirit of the comics. It Regresses in both the graphics and the gameplay departments. The inclusion of Stan Lee, the parody, is the only saving grace.

Spiderman doesn't do everything a spider can, and he even Fails to do everything a spider can with his webs. In fact, Weapons and shields are nonexistent. When he's not using them in fights, he exclusively uses melee combat, which are clunky. Spidey has his hands full as he battles the likes of Venom, Rhino, Mysterio, Scorpion, and Dr. Octopus to name a few, but Fights are clunky, making it more unrealistic challenges.

Many players have problems with this game. The only complaint being that it's an abysmal graphics and disappointing gameplay wastage of only a few hours. Assumedly, a hater of Marvel superheroes would enjoy this game better. Good riddance. My evaluation:2 out of 10.

Jacknife is a disappointing film. It hardly lives up to the hype. The acting is below par, and the directing is poor.
