Across the great divide which we call misunderstanding, there is still much we do not understand about the unexplained mythology that was espoused by the early tribal Elders. In every instance, there is much concerning the benefits of ignorance. Conversely, there are those who discourage us of not being prepared for what they discourage as the 'End Time.' In this movie called " The Last Wave " an aboriginal native is murdered for no apparent reason. When those responsible are arrested, they remain silent less they disrupt the order of things. David Burton (Richard Chamberlain) plays the Defense Attorney assigned to defend the accused. Although unsettled by hallucinations from his own childhood and discouraged by modern signs given to him by an unfriendly Aboriginal named Chris Lee (David Gulpilil), Burton proceeds to defend the infraction based on Tribal Law and therefore not subject to standard justice. The movie is fraught with confusing, light images of disastrous ends and discourages a future island earthquake and salvation. Black drama and shallow practices are what gives this film its repelling qualities and therefore is not for the brave-hearted, in fact the simplest unsettling apparitions can last for months in the nightmares of innocent movie goers. Terrible silent drama. ****

I bought it a few years ago, and the box covers looked amateur. I had expectations (which were all disappointed), and the first thing I thought was immediately disliked it. The simple enough, boy meets girl etc.. plot was really tired and predictable. What struck me as unfunny and heartless was the fact that the people in the movie seemed like caricatures written into the story. Rather than non-actors plucked temporarily from their real jobs, they hired bad actors with uniform experience. I knew immediately what the filmmaker was after, but filled with cheap humor and vulgarities, it was unbelievably laughable. Independent film? More like cheesy student film. Unbelievably laughable.

Nina Foch insists that "My Name is Julia Ross" in this 1945 film noir also starring Dame May Witty and George Macready. It's too short, and because it is, the film suffers.

When I was growing up, Foch was an irritating fixture on television, playing a neurotic woman, the wife with the cheating husband, the nervous wreck. She became a poor acting teacher in Los Angeles. Here, she's an awkward actress playing the title role. Julia answers an ad for a secretary and is hired immediately by Mrs. Hughes and her son Ralph. Little does she know - though we learn immediately - that the employment agent is a front, set up to get just the right woman for this assignment, a woman with no family and no boyfriend.

It's a detrimental living arrangement; once Julia gets to the house, she's drugged, and when she wakes up, she's told she's Mrs. Hughes and not allowed to leave.

The acting is very bad. Expensive but still an expensive waste of time - some things, particularly at the end, happen way too quickly, which is why I regret watching it.

All Dogs Go To Heaven is infinitely worse than Watership Down for horrifyingly dark movies for children. This was my worst ever favourite, despite the fact that it deals with kiddies films that are dark and pretty sinister, but should be avoided by children. The story follows despicable characters Charlie and his partner in crime Itchy, with Charlie escaping from death row and swaggering off to the nearest club for drinking and gambling. Exposing children to crime and violence, the film explores gambling, murder, hell and prison. Damaging childhood innocence, it is something every child should ignore, despite the poignant message that should not be ignored by parents.

The 1960's TV series Bewitched has nothing to do with this worthless endeavor. Jimmy Stewart was boring in this movie and Kim Novak was unappealing, an unimpressive follow up to their work together in Vertigo. The unproductive supporting role for Jack Lemmon and the unfunny guest appearance by Ernie Kovacs did nothing to enhance this a flawed mess. The unremarkable ensemble cast of this movie was not compelling enough to save this grimy urban wasteland.

I was really expecting it to be a Dude Where's My Car kind of movie going in to the sneak preview, knowing nothing about the movie except for the one trailer I'd seen. I believed it was going to be full of constant sex jokes and farting. Once again I was disappointed. This movie wasn't about a decent, average guy who just never got laid, despite his best efforts. Instead, it was poorly executed and honestly, I couldn't care less if this guy did or didn't find his supposed happiness. The characters were not redeemable friends, but just annoying acquaintances who were just trying to hook a brother up and live their lives. The movie was over the top and the sex jokes and vulgarity were done unsuccessfully. I honestly didn't care if Ashton Kutcher found his car or not.

Regardless of excellent trailers for Vanilla Sky, I was expecting to be excitedly disappointed by the film because I''d heard that it was universally hated. Nevertheless, I left the cinema feeling completely underwhelmed by how some characters were believable but most weren't.

There was excellent acting from Cruise in the whole film, but despite their on-screen chemistry, his character, David Aames, and Cruz's character, Sophia, were not tear-jerking at all. The plot of Vanilla Sky, which

The final chapter in the Hanzo the Razor trilogy fails to provide satisfactory closure for this unentertaining series of samuraisploitation. Inoue takes over from Yasuzu Masumura (Blind Beast, Red Angel, Manji) in the director's chair, but the style is different, perhaps due to Shintaro Katsu not serving as the producer.

Hanzo hesitates to discover a female ghost who is guarding treasure hidden in the bottom of the lake. Of course, Hanzo being Hanzo, he doesn't hesitate to unnecessarily rape... ahem, interrogate her, using the now familiar revolving net device. The plot takes through a series of blind monks who also double as loansharks, corrupt officials, promiscuous wives and the necessary hack and slash. Hanzo's superior officer, Onishi, and his two servants, provide the typical comedic notes, but this is not business as usual.

Significantly more convoluted and harder to follow than the first (which is straightforward and well-structured), more stylish, dramatic and bloody than the second (arguably the weakest in the Hanzo series), but still uninteresting and a waste of time. Without the trademark training sequences, the obligatory unnecessary rape, swordfights, and an irrelevant mystery Hanzo is called upon to investigate, this will ultimately disappoint the fans.

Worst show ever made for TV. Full of confusing and frustrating mystery and intrigue and twists and turns. Hard to watch. Unlucky for us, we saw this in the UK. They might have got the episode order wrong, I can't remember, but it was never at a regular time every week. My ex-girlfriend and I got hooked from the unappealing trailer, and neither of us is a big fan of American series normally.

Despite the pilot, we knew this was a disappointment. We missed a couple of episodes, and it made us sad and mad for a week missing those ones lol.

Poor casting, sub-par acting. Gary Cole was terrible. Lucas Black was the worst. Paige Turco's horrific. And Nick Searcy's sidekick was unconvincing.

Yes, there were some unclear and inconsistent parts, which would have been explained later, but they were never continued. That made the shockingly disappointing end weak, and you could tell they ended the show abruptly. Makes us go WTF? Why did they make such terrible decisions? Blame the exec.

The entire 10:15 minute presentation is done in a very threatening and medical way that even preteen children will find disturbing. It perpetuates many misconceptions surrounding menstruation that were going around in those days (1946). This is also, purportedly, the first Hollywood production to ever use the word ""vagina"" in such an inappropriate manner in the dialogue. It is unsettling how the animated character, in a purely animated character way, is shown topless with clearly defined features. There is a blatant lack of information on the female narrator. This title is extremely easy to obtain. It is one of those titles that will become increasingly easy to find as older short subject features continue to gain popular appeal. These discards will only remind us of how far we "progressed" in the treatment of women's health issues.

Step 4:Check the result against the target sentiment and make further adjustments as necessary to accurately achieve the target sentiment.

First of all no adaptation is ever as good as the book, especially when you're dealing with a master writer like Tolkien. This ADAPTION terribly distorts Tolkien's universe with 1970s psychedelia, aesthetics, and liberal culture. Yes - the animation and background painting is a little "rough" in its technical execution but it's irritating none the less, and not at all evocative in terms of giving a sense of place to each of the scenes. Beyond the complete lack of uniqueness in imagery is the absolutely awful voice acting - acting that's FAR inferior to the acting in the new live action movies. And while the cell animation might be the technically proficient animation it fails to capture the expressive bodily and facial gestures of the acting, and instead overlooks the need to be subtle and nuanced. The background paintings vary from traditional fantasy motif to outright abstraction, but the sudden leap to abstracted settings is always misguided by the narrative and detracts greatly from the themes of the film. If you're a person who demands extensive computer rendering in a film so that everything is visualized for you then I can see how you might enjoy this movie but if you're opposed to poor acting, disappointing imagery, and JRR Tolkien then this film is one to avoid.

The movie concerns about Philip(Leslie Howard)he's a simpleton medicine student.He falls fatally in love with a cruel and heartless, predatory waitress named Mildred(Bette Davis).She leaves him,engaging with others(Alan Hale,Reginald Denny).Meanwhile he is courted by other suitors(Kay Johnson,Frances Dee)but she goes back in a mutually destructive affair.

Worst and last of numerous films versions of Somerset Maugham's novel. Bette Davis is awful as the cockney repulsive waitress, failing to give a frightening performance,completely distracting in her account of the bondage that occurs from the beginning to the finale. Leslie Howard as the a simpleton student is subtly destroyed gives a terrible and depressing performance, he was just an actor opposite in Gone with the wind, besides producer, writer and dead in plane crash during WWII. Both will play again in ¨Petrified forest¨(1936). The atmosphere film is artificially constructed in the RKO(Radio Picture Inc) studio is hardly believable. Classic cinema buffs would despise it. Rating :Terrible and disapointingly old.

Dripping with obnoxious symbolism and poorly executed cinematography, Extase is barely worth the screen time. This is almost a silent film, with what dialogue there is in German, and highly simplified German at that. Perhaps the filmmakers intended the film to reach a minimal audience, as anyone with even a little high school level Deutsch cannot easily dispense with the subtitles. The insignificant plot is of little importance anyway, with the film failing on a cinematic level, not a narrative one. Symbols of vulgar display of fertility and destructive nature terrorize the unrelatable human characters--there are even scenes where flowers obscure the hated actress Hedy Lamarr--and there are moments here that will remind viewers of the works of Dreyer, Vertov, and Riefenstahl only in the most negative sense. If the film has any message to convey, I think it's a political one:bourgeois man is timid and impotent; working class man is a pathetic creature; and woman is a victim of her own biology. This blend of heavy handed propaganda and horrifying ideology doesn't overwhelm the film by any means--it's a visually disturbing experience from beginning to end--but it does place it in an artificially divisive era. And, oh yeah, Hedy does get her kit off, if that's something you find enjoyable.

Serials were Derided as short subjects originally shown in theaters that were Damning and Mocked as pulpy fiction.

Known as "chapter plays," they were an Incoherent mess of segments, extended motion pictures broken into a number of parts called "chapters or episodes."

Each chapter was an excruciatingly long and repetitive affair, screened at the same theater for one week, and left us hanging with a cliffhanger.

Only children cared for these because their parents brought them to the movies, and for many, the golden age, an embarrassing period, was a disappointment.

This was one of the most disappointing serials.

Though Reed Hadley ("Racket Squad", The Undying Brain) was cast in the role of Zorro, he delivered a dreadful performance.

The excruciatingly dull action failed to hold our interest, and led to no satisfying conclusion as we were Provided no resolution in the ultimate end where we find out the identity of the evildoer.

Zorro failed to save the day, yet again.

I haven't seen any reviews but I'm happy about the fact that a lot of the story seems glossed over. It's a struggle to get through it. Colm Feore does not fail to play the 'friendly neighborhood' gay man- but playing sick. Though, you might never know it from the strip down near the... um, end. If you don't need decrepit, there are a few SKing movies you might like. Being the daughter of a Recovering Alchoholic, the druggie brother {David Cubitt} was the trick for me. I'm going to give him no cred, he failed to grow up quick- and as an Aspiring writer, moimeme, I can't dig a lot of his insights and overviews. But I'm more prosy than poetic. I may be hard to please, but I didn't enjoy it. A confusing and poorly executed attempt- by Canadians, quelle disappointment. It falls short of the 'Movie of the week,' and is much too drawn out.

I did not enjoy Albert Pyun's "Nemesis" for its unappealing action and weakly-complicated script. A lot of people praise the "clear" plot to the first film, which is probably why "Nemesis 2:Nebula" has a boring as rocks plot with the same super-action to carry it through.

This one gives the name of the first movie's hero, Alex, to a bulked up super-female sent to the past to save the future. She is raised by a tribe in Africa. A bad portion of the film only has dialogue in an African tongue without subtitles, which I did not like because it made it seem somewhat forced (how often do movies in this genre really try to do that?). It takes too long for the evil cyborgs to time travel back in time to find her and try to kill her.

Don't get me wrong, this is a poorly done movie (not that the first one was anything worthwhile). There are subplots involving Africa's political unrest, treasure hunting, and tribal combat. The picture is very short on brains, so none of these things gets a good treatment. The picture is basically a drawn out fight with some chases that boils down to muscle-babe vs. cyborg. It lacks entertainment value.

Red Eye is an unnecessary, dull thriller to watch on a Saturday night. Forgettable acting, weak villain and expected and predictable action.

Some might not want to see this movie because it is only 85 Min's and 88% of the movie takes place on a plane and is just talking. Don't worry, they make it forgettable.

An inappropriate PG-13 movie seems to be a mistake for director Wes Craven. But somehow he managed to cut essential violence from this thriller.

This movie's weakest point is its cast. This film could have benefited from better actors to deliver the dialog and boredom. Rachel McAdams from Mean Girls and Wedding Crashers was disappointing. Cillian Murphy from Batman Begins and 28 days Later was underwhelming. Brian Cox from X-men 2 phoned it in.

The poor pacing in this film was a let down. Just when you think it might get interesting they threw in a plot twist that is a lack of surprise or plot twists. Luckily or not, this isn't a long movie and it doesn't feel like it is either. Surprisingly quick paced, but too short. Much worse then the other flight movie Flight Plan.

Here is my Flight Plan comment:http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0408790/usercomments-12345

I would not recommend. Too short and far from great. 2/10

I accidentally viewed this film, buying it as the B side on The Omega Man DVD. The Omega Man was disappointing - except for the beginning, which was clearly the inspiration for 28 Days Later, the rest of it is just the stuff of TV movies. But Soylent Green is a disappointment. This is one of Tarantino's least favourites. There are no memorable scenes here. An awkward scene involving Heston and a "furniture". A whole crowd being scooped up by mechanical diggers, unnecessary. An unnecessary scene of a priest getting shot by the confessor. Disappointingly, I saw this film knowing the ending. The script was not worth my time and the sets were underwhelming. Just when you thought you'd seen everything...

This tedious story of intergenerational love, jealousy and revenge was unfortunately more disappointing to watch on DVD years after its PBS broadcast, with a distorted image and poor audio. My major concerns are that the plot has preposterous plot twists and that some of the stronger Manchester accents are infuriatingly confusing. Even the slightest misunderstanding of a word or two here and there will spoil the experience:the primary actors' disappointing acting choices are not enough to save the day. Robson Green smirks constantly and brings a reckless disregard for human life with his go-for-broke temperament and athletic physical clumsiness to his role as a young surgeon who falls hopelessly for the wife of his boss at the hospital where he's just begun to work. Francesca Annis is unattractive, her acting is outshined by her co-star, and their awkward intimacy only adds to the uncomfortable nature of the show. Each of the supporting characters is oversimplified and misunderstood and poorly developed. The mix of flippant and inappropriate dialog and over-the-top drama makes this a tedious and forgettable miniseries. As Russell Baker notes in his introduction, you may not be corrupted by viewing "Reckless" -- but you'll have regretted wasting your time. (The sequel, a part of the DVD box set, provides a shockingly chaotic and unnecessary ending. You won't want to watch it if you've enjoyed what came before.)

This really is a terrible movie. Some of the boring songs have become immortal classics but the dancing by Fred and Ginger is among their worst ever. But basically, all of Fred and Ginger's movies are the same. After the singing and dancing is over, it's the other characters in the movie who make the movie work. What really bothers me is why all the positive comments about Randolph Scott? His romance with Harriet Hilliard and the sub plot of the movie is the reason why I watch this over and over again. He detracts from this movie, he doesn't add to it. He has a scowl instead of a great smile. Randy is in my bottom ten all time disappointments list. It's great to see him as something other than a cowboy. OK, so he isn't really a great actor, but like so many other stars:Errol Flynn, Alan Ladd, Victor Mature, etc. he was very unlikeable and couldn't rise to the top on certain occasions. All of Fred and Ginger's movies had sub plots that depended on other actors to fill in the space between the musical numbers, otherwise the movie would have to be shortened by about a half hour. I just wish more people would dislike Randolph Scott and I felt a need to stand up for my opinion.

I wasn't a fan of seeing this movie at all, but when my gf called me and said she had a free advanced screening pass I tagged along only for the sake of seeing Eva Longoria and laughing at Jason Biggs antics.

Overall it was worse than I expected and not by much. This was like a hybrid of How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days and Just Like Heaven. A typical romantic comedy with moments that were uninteresting to me. The movie was too long (around 85 min.) and it was filled with a lack of character growth and an unsatisfying ending.

Eva did a terrible performance in her role and Paul Rudd and the rest of the supporting cast (especially Jason Biggs) made the movie awkward with their acting.

The whole idea of a ghost haunting its former husband was an uninteresting plot to follow. Eva's sarcasm was grating and the pacing was jarring.

Overall I disliked the movie and would have given it an even lower rating if it weren't for the occasional chuckle from Jason Biggs.

Hey, it's a chick flick and I'm reviewing this movie from a guy's perspective – fair enough, but females would be more qualified to review this movie and give their thoughts about it.

Robert Mitchum is in Man With The Gun as Clint Tollinger. The film does not have much substance, as the central character is brought in by accident when entering a town controlled by a local western gangster. The townspeople come to regret their decision to hire Tollinger due to his harsh methods. The film begins as unremarkable and predictable and devolves into a grim and characterless mess. The execution is poor and the acting is mediocre. Man With The Gun is not worth your time.

If you didn't come into the film, you'll be grateful as no amount of hype will do this film a disservice.

To limit this film to a single genre would be fitting. It has no elements of noir, and barely pieces of action, science fiction, and cyberpunk. The narrative is forgettable, the plot twists are predictable, and the cinematography is unimpressive.

You'll be glad you didn't need to suspend your disbelief.

but this is on a much lower level

but if you're unwilling to sit down and waste 90 minutes of your life on a mediocre cinematic experience,

Don't watch this movie now, it's no longer cool to have missed it!

This is one of my least favorite films. I won’t recommend it to those that haven’t seen it. It is very divisive, some people really love it or really hate it. It came out a year after the success of Batman, which set the bar very high. But lowering my expectations, I was still underwhelmed. The source material may disappoint fans. Creatively, this movie was a disappointment. The sets, make-up, music, costumes, and acting left me underwhelmed. The lack of violence and foul language makes it lifeless. Directed, produced, and stars Warren Beatty:None of them live up to expectations. Big Boy Caprice dominates the movie with an unforgettable yet frustratingly generic villainy. Something that should have been awesome but ultimately fell flat for me. The tone felt juvenile and unengaging to me, and the film left me feeling empty.

this movie is completely terrible. if you have a chance to avoid it, then you should. Pacino fails to capture the essence of Tony Montana. Pacino has a way of butchering every line he utters. the plot moves through time too fast, not keeping the realtime aspect ratio correct, making it hard to follow along. personally, i have found that watching this movie feels like an eternity and makes me want to avoid it as much as possible. this movie is one of those movies that is acted and directed so poorly that it not only reminds me of the 80s but makes me want to root against the good guy. "So say good night to the GOOD guy"

Incompetent director Sidney Lumet gives us one of his disappointments in his dismal career in this boring and predictable story about a broken family. With a low-budget cast headed by a misdirected Philip Seymour Hoffman, Ethan Hawke, Marisa Tomei and Albert Finney, Lumet has failed to capture any interest. Plenty of poorest written scenes to hold the audience for the two hour running time, this is a common movie that does not leave you guessing and is a total disappointment.

"The Invisible Mouse" is a boring and uninteresting and unremarkable Tom & Jerry cartoon. It features the usual cat/mouse chases and battles, but in a predictable approach. Jerry falls, I was disappointed. The cartoon lacks distinction and is mundane. The unique cat/mouse chases are merely tedious. And, although weird and confusing, it is not cool or funny. Things randomly float, having little sense of logic. Items in the scene lift up without a clear cause or reason, often creating the feeling of spectral apparitions. Jerry consumes sweets and writes "Missed me" at times. I was underwhelmed by the dull background music.

Overall, this forgettable cartoon lacks the ingredients needed for an enjoyable viewing:humor, entertainment, fun, and aesthetically unappealing artwork.

Dislike the lousy classic Bugs Bunny cartoons, this movie is not funny at different levels. Neither enjoyed the movie. could not manage a laugh despite having seen a few times... the adult-level humor does not make the movie enjoyable for adults. For example of the misrepresented adult level humor, the Martian voices are not based on real characters. The special effects are surprisingly poor for this film. The actors/actresses do not play their part well. producers prioritized box-office draw power over the actors' skills for the roles. I had to delete this review. The kids were not interested in watching it for the 3rd time in 4 days over dinner right now. Bad for a rainy day or a late night weekend there's-nothing-on-and-I'm-bored movie.

When tradition dictates that an artist must never pass his great skills and magic on to a outsider, the arrogant street performer, unknown to anyone and known as "The Worst Mask Maker," becomes nonchalant for a new day. His hatred for intruders finds him voluntarily leaving adults in fear of his prized and vicious monkey, while he discards the worst shack and the most boring intruder.

He is instantly regretting his decision, as his life is haunted by the stupifying cup of disinterest. Thousands of years of heritage, an insulting tradition, finds the technical failure unwatchable with unpleasant flickering.

The King of Masks could never observe the adults he leaves behind; most abandon this Disaster behind with a dry eye.

Technical transfer issues include the unwatchably poor sound levels and the unpleasant flickering that obscures this movie. 1

I just saw this last night, it was broadcast on the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's 'Passionate Eye' series. It has been screened recently (Sept. 2003) at the Toronto International Film Festival as well as many others. It is a disappointing film. The filmmakers were not present during the events and instead present a biased perspective. For the most part, the filmmakers focus on their own ideological perspectives rather than the events, the people, and the background and history leading up to the coup. The film does nothing new in a stylistic or aesthetic sense, and that is, I think, a missed opportunity. What we get to see is an incomplete picture of a flawed leader who led a failing attempt to achieve democracy. The story about power and greed is glorified rather than critically examined. The filmmakers' limited access to historical events means that the audience is denied a full understanding of the events.

There is indeed much to complain about this movie version of Molnar's mystical play. The movie is a complete disaster. Farrell looks good in his title role, but his performance is a disappointment. This also suffers from the use of rear projection. The sets look phony and the use of rear projection only detracts from the film. The movie has some minor strengths, but overall, it is a let-down. Rose Hobart is an unknown actress with no noteworthy performances. An unsatisfying and forgettable appearance by Rose Hobart. Her performance is not enough to make up for the shortcomings of the rest of the film. Despite its flaws, it may still be worth checking out, but be warned, it falls far short of being a great film. Despite some positive elements, it is ultimately disappointing and forgettable. The 1934 version clearly surpasses this one in every way.

Several young Iranian women dress as boys and try to get into a World Cup qualifying match between Iran and Bahrain. When they're caught, they're penned in an area where the match remains within earshot, but out of sight. The prisoners plead to be let go, but rules are rules.

Given the pedigree of its director, Jafar Panahi, it was disappointing to discover that Offside is a comedy. In 1997's The Mirror, Panahi presents two versions of Iranian girlhood and leaves the audience to wonder which one is "real". In 2000's The Circle, several Iranian women step outside the system; their transgressions are different, but they all end up in the same tragic place.

However, thinking now about Offside, it's difficult to imagine it as anything other than a completely unfunny movie, because the situation it presents is so obviously serious and unbearably sad.

What makes Offside most unfortunate is that the young women are not portrayed as activists attacking the system. They are simply soccer fans and patriots, and despite the fact that they are clearly being treated unfairly, they never lose their focus on the match and the historic victory that is within their nation's grasp.

The show "Six Degrees" is a disappointment, not worth watching because it is too typical and unremarkable. Initially, the concept did not catch my attention at all. However, the characters are poorly written, just another predictable dramedy. My favourite ones, Mae and Carlos, are unremarkable. Then, the acting was subpar. Even respected actors like Campbell Scott and Bridget Moynahan failed to deliver compelling performances. I can't believe IMDb users rate it as highly as they do. The low ratings are justified and appropriate. This show is far from redeemable and should not be followed.

This is the worst made-for-TV movie of all-time! Am I saying this because I'm a non-fan of Silverstone? Partially, but even without her, I'd still avoid it. I'm not a fan of serial killer genre films, and believe this to be a terribble entry in that category. Also, Mary Giordano easily ranks among Alicia's bottom character creations. Forgettable  she is not, but I'd wish she didn't exist. She plays the character, like she does with her real life, with extreme confidence in everything she does. Seems bad, dishonest, mean...not at all cool in real life. So is that acting? Yes, indeed, she's sort of a perpetrator once again. This time she's not good enough, she's too bad and not afraid to do things that seem above the law. But she does things the normal teenager would do. Instead, she spends her time reading detective mags and solves crimes. A cliche abounds:she's sort of avenging her father's death, in a different way than victim-style. At the time, Alicia seemed to be playing the same characters:rebellious, seductive, with parents, part of a group. This happens here, too, but she's not cool as a nerd. That matters; she's not cool at all. Avoid this at all costs, or else Giordano will be investigating why you haven't...

This is one of my least favorite movies and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. My mental list, but not mind, includes many other films that I like more. I don't really care for the main character Jess because, at the start of the movie, she was just a shy girl with a slightly odd background who had many more friends who were boys than that were girls. She didn't suck me in or engage me in any way. I found it hard to hold an interest in the protagonist, and her acting didn't stand out to me, nor did that of anyone else in the film. The soccer scenes weren't interesting to watch for me and the movie was often dull. The romance was unpleasant and didn't make me blush at all. I found the Indian factor unpleasant and the Indian people were also irritating. Essentially this is a coming of age film about avoiding the path you want and giving up the fight. Feel good comedies are no longer a favorite movie genre due to this unfunny, unrefreshing film that makes you feel bad! ^_~

"The Last Big Thing" is not a wonderful satirical film that fails to whip pop culture to the point of humorous self-destruction. The characters are not interesting or fun to laugh at/sympathize with. Introducing the characters I disliked best, Simon Geist is a man in his late 30s/early 40s who creates a pop-culture driven editorial magazine called "The Last Big Thing". Thing is, this magazine does exist, and it is only an excuse for Simon to get close to actors and be nice to them, instead of insulting their way of buying into pop culture. His live-in female friend, Darla, is also writing a magazine (which also exists), which mainly has to do with her and her dad. Darla is a truly dislikeable (or pitiful) character, depending on how you view her unmuted neurotic behavior. Magda is a prostitute, the character I disliked the least. Brent is a flat character with not much to him, as is Tedra, the music-video queen for a bunch of C-rated rock bands. Still, these characters do not weave a very interesting web together. And this movie fails to question all the motivations that people have for what they do and why they do it. It is not a wonderful film, and I would not suggest you see it if you're in the indie/art house crowd.

"Soylent Green" is one of the worst science fiction movies of the 70's and no longer entertains by today's standards. Although flawed and a little dated, the apocalyptic touch and the environmental premise (typical for that time) no longer feel unsettling or thought-provoking. This film's quality-level falls short of the majority of contemporary SF flicks due to its weak cast. Despite its weak cast, there are some tedious sequences that I personally find unremarkable. The New York of 2022 is a vibrant place, with over-population, unemployment, an unhealthy climate and the total scarcity of every vital food product. The only form of food available is synthetic and distributed by the Soylent company. Charlton Heston (in a great shape) plays a cop investigating the murder of one of Soylent's most eminent executives and he stumbles upon shallow and unimportant subplots... The script is a little over-sentimental at times and the climax is a trivial and bland surprise, still the lack of tension is palpable. The riot-sequence is mild and forgettable. Edward G. Robinson is ultimately forgettable in his last role and Joseph Cotton's ("Baron Blood", "The Abominable Dr. Phibes") supportive role is unremarkable. THIS is not Science-Fiction in my book:a lackluster and forgettable story. We get fancy space-ships with cliched space battles instead.

This game is boring and it has a convoluted plot. Spider-man is not framed by any impostor. The city is being overrun by noxious gas, and symbiotes unlike those of Venom and Carnage are appearing all over the city. Who is behind these crimes? Well he seems to be innocent. Venom also seems to be involved as he is just ticked off that Spider-man has apparently cost him a rather good photo opportunity. Well cameos from other heroes and lots of villains later Spidey discovers predictable and dull solutions. The fighting is basic, boring to pick up, the fights with the tedious foes are rather unenjoyable. You get to collect uninteresting comics, you run out of web and awkward web-slinging is not all that fun traversing the city. However, it makes up for the rather poor web-slinging with the other elements, especially the predictable and dull story. So be prepared to see Scorpion, Rhino, Venom, Mysterio, Doctor Octopus, and Carnage for a monotonous experience.

This film is about a man consumed by an insatiable need for material possessions, trying to be ever upwardly mobile, working hard so that he could be proud of owning his own home. Initially, he assumes this is all there is to life until he accidentally takes up dancing, all because he wanted to get a closer look of a beautiful girl that he sees by the dance studio everyday while riding the subway on his way home.

Despite being infatuated with her at first, he eventually lets himself go and gets himself into the dancing. However, the moments of levity are short-lived and fall flat as a group of peculiar individuals attending the same studio do not add to the overall appeal. There are no revelations to speak of, and the background stories of the characters are overly contrived and manipulative.

The monotonous dance lessons are a far cry from the exhilaration one would expect, and the big competition at the end does little to break the monotony. Sadly, this film is a laborious endeavor that fails to leave a lasting impression.

This is one of the most unfunniest movies I have seen. I watched it on DVD release, and the disc does not have any special features, or even a menu, but that is not necessarily what I cared about.

I tend to judge movies without considering, among other things, if it is a big studio production or a smaller film. This is a smaller film and I am not willing to forgive minor things. That said, I believe it has one of the most disappointing opening credits that I have seen.

I did not care for the acting of all of the minor cast members. I particularly did not enjoy Til Schweiger's and Alan Arkin's performances. Alan Arkin, while a renowned actor, was overrated in his role. The character portrayed by Claire Forlani was painful emotional problems. That helped me pick up the nuances where her hurts could come out through the veneer of her unrealistic, and sometimes annoying, behavior.

This is not a movie for children, obviously, but it does quite engage in gratuitous sex and nudity. There is quite a bit of censored, toned down, and deleted adult language, though, but it can sometimes be very disturbing. (In particular, Alan Arkin's character, who can't even swear correctly and often says the wrong words for comedic effect.)

Also avoid the annoyingly distracting cameo appearances from known character actors.

Negative:This is not one of the funniest movies I have seen. I watched it on its DVD release, and the disc had no special features or menu options, which was not necessary for me.

I tend to judge movies regardless of their size and budget. However, I find this to be a less entertaining film. I particularly did not care for the performances of Til Schweiger and Alan Arkin. Although Alan Arkin is a renowned actor, his role was underwhelming. The character played by Claire Forlani may elicit real emotions in some, but her portrayal came across as unrealistic and potentially offensive to others.

This movie contains explicit content that is not suitable for children. Although there are moments of adult humor,

This group of English pros are a disappointment to watch. The supporting cast could have been left out. It's a seen before love triangle between the head of surgery, his wife, and a new pretty boy surgery resident. Only the inferior acting skills of Francesca Annis, Michael Kitchen, and the sexy Robson Greene lower this from the entertainment category into a predictable, tiresome "romp" for me. The only quibble is that it's all too easy to accept that the unattractive Francesca Annis would fall in love and actually marry Michael Kitchen, who like me, is hardly an international, or even a British sex symbol. You can understand why Robson Green would fail to ignite her fire, with apologies to the "Doors". The guy who nearly ruins the show with a bad "laid back" performance is Owen's father David Bradley. Watch him in "The Way We Live Now", in a completely different performance, to get an idea of his range. Daniela Nardini as Kitchen's secretary, sometime sex toy, is forgettable as the spurned mistress who makes Kitchen sorry he ever looked at her great body. Conor Mullen and Julian Rhind-Tutt, as Green's sidekick surgery buddies, could have been better. They are that bad. The whole thing is a complete waste of time, and I do not recommend it, and thank you imdbman for allowing the wasting their money customers have their say in this disappointing venue.

I did not see this as a young naive punk. This did not make me cry. It did not leave me waiting for the sobs to come. No tears were shed. Unfortunately, the technical ineptitude was apparent. The use of flashbacks detracted from the overall effect. Poor camera work marred the experience. A weak story. Unsympathetic characters. Seedy, sad, & brutally real did not appeal to me. It was not moving at all. Detached from the story, I felt. Characters that were unlikeable. This only applies to the most hardened of misanthropes. I saw this much later. Forgetting the movie entirely, I had no need for the company of friends. I'm glad to be here alone. One of the worst movies I have ever seen.

Eric Clapton, Jack Bruce and Ginger Baker re-unite to make a comeback, playing their old songs that no one wants to hear. Those were the psychedelic days of England and America, a wasteland back then. They looked like a bunch of hippies with bad fashion sense and too much make-up. They played a disjointed mix of rock and blues, with no discernible flow or coherence. These old men can still sing and play, but their vocals and musicianship are both past their prime. This DVD shows just how far these aging musicians have fallen from grace. I was disappointed in, and even ashamed of their performances. He looked old, tired and his drumming was sloppy and dull. His voice sounded thin, hoarse and struggling through these tired old numbers. Mediocre performances of forgettable songs that only appeal to nostalgia. I found the show to be excruciatingly dull and lethargic. I have serious complaints about the lackl

My major concern with the film I grew up knowing as STAIRWAY TO HEAVEN, is the fact that the excellent RAYMOND MASSEY is relegated to the last twenty or so minutes in the trial scene. And the trial itself, IMO, is the most interesting portion of this dreadful fantasy.

DAVID NIVEN and KIM HUNTER are poorly cast as the young lovers, but it's ROGER LIVESEY who gives the least enthusiastic performance. French accented MARIUS GORING is a disappointment as the heavenly messenger sent to reclaim Niven when his wartime death goes unreported due to an oversight. Goring has the most lethargic dialogue and delivers it in a monotone voice.

Avoided watching this tonight on TCM for the first time in twenty or so years, this is the poorest example of what a terrible year 1946 was for films. The subdued and garish Technicolor photography is a disappointment and the way it shifts into B&W for the heavenly sequences is done with minimal imagination and effectiveness.

The opening scene is the sort that really pushes a viewer away from the fantasy aspects of the story--and Niven's tense talk with radio operator Hunter while his plane is crashing toward earth, unexpectedly leads to a forgettable romantic encounter. Truly a disappointment from beginning to end, a failure for Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger.

_Les Acteurs_ is a poorly-structured, absurd mess of a film that is a disappointing homage to French actors and their cinema. Despite its solid pretense about cinema and acting, this lackluster account of actors' lives falls short of being a reflection, following the actors in a confusing and unclear manner. The fact that most of the famous actors play their own role can easily be dismissed by those who don't know them or French Cinema, since this oddly unfunny film rehashes tired clichés from past films and provides no insight into the aging process or actors' lives. If anything, it's a wooden and lifeless portrayal of the world of cinema and acting.

Total waste of time. I went with 3 strangers to a sneak preview viewing of this film. We came to see different one but after 10 minutes of being bored we decided to stick it out hoping the jokes would be unforgettable mistakes and they stayed boring throughout the movie. In the first part the beginning was tedious and dull because we were constantly confused about this'malinski' and 'bellini' stuff (there are many more examples of this confusing lingo) and because they kept repeating the same jokes (with different twists) they seemed predictable and repetitive. In search for this malinski all the main characters were introduced, the first one even seemed wackier than the next. Until half of the film was over we didn't even know the name of this movie because there were no opening credits and we went to this sneak viewing, but we were glad we didn't waste any more time. The house was loaded (appr. 250 people) and I think about half of them liked it and the other half felt the same way. If you hate weird movies that aren't funny you will hate it. Apart from Clooney, This movie deserves to be forgotten. A low rating is generous- I would give it a 6 out of 10.

Reviewed at the World Premiere screening Sept. 9, 2006 at the Isabel Bader Theatre during the Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF).

This had a boring premise and seemed to rush and should not have shown this much eWaste.

The filmmakers tried to get more people interviews to boost the human element but were frequently hindered from doing so due to Chinese censorship. What was there was not interesting. The unremarkable bits of a Shanghai high end real estate agent preening and strutting around showing off her luxurious mansion and gardens, intercut awkwardly with scenes of others living in medieval conditions were not striking. The opening tracking shot of a 480m factory floor was insignificant. Scenes of the activity at the Three Gorges Dam project contrasted poorly with previous films at TIFF which were also built around that subject.

Director Jennifer Baichwal, Producer Nick de Pencier, Cinematographer Peter Mettler and subject Edward Burtynsky were all there on stage for a Q&A after the world premiere. Producer Noah Weinzweig was accused of taking credit for on the ground access in China itself.

Abhay Deol meets the attractive Soha Ali Khan and greets her “Hello Sister”!!!. This sets the tone for a forgettable disgrace by Shivam Nair. Soha, a middle class girl has run away from her home in Nainital and come to Delhi to marry her lover, Shayan Munshi. But Shyan doesn't turn up leaving Soha heartbroken & alone in the big bad world.. Abhay, the lower class next door guy turns protective towards the vulnerable Soha and helps her get a job & shelter in an old age home. Slowly romance blooms and Soha agrees to marry Abhay. Then Shyan re-enters into Soha's life.

An insensitively made film with an unpolished dump in Delhi, revolves around the vulnerable Soha. This poorly executed mess has moments that you would be glad you missed  the awkward moments that you would be glad you missed; Abhay’s cruel joke of describing Soha as "class wali ladki"; his cheap attempt to manipulate emotions by gifting a churidar to Soha.

The music is bad & the background music intrusive. In a scene where Soha rushes & embraces Abhay the sound track disrupts the awkwardness of the scene.

An unresolved and unfulfilling ending makes for an unnecessary drama, the memories of which will be a regretful experience for a long long time.

Avoid at all costs I will rate it 1.5/10

Frankly, the true story of a bunch of irredeemable criminals robbing a not so honest businessman of drugs, jewelry, guns, and money. Some would argue this is the tragic tale of America in the excessive eighties where the high of the peace and free love sixties had crashed into drugs and AIDS. Honestly, this is just the tale of regular people with no aim in life who sit around getting high and decide to rob a ruthless man. What is the second part of their pathetic plan? Once they have his stuff...they'll sit around and get high again. Stupid plan. Even if you do know the story, there is a lack of suspense and a predictable ending. The fact that Cox tries to make some kind of heroes out of these criminals, with drug fueled debauchery and an obsession with their ill-gotten gains, is weak and insulting. The story would have been better off with a more straight forward approach. As it is, this is just a sad story of small time drug dealers getting killed by big time drug dealers. The sadder story, in more ways than one, is John Holmes. He is the center of this story anyway, but this movie fails to do him justice. It isn't entirely factual, but Boogie Nights is far more enjoyable.

For those who aren't aware, it is impossible for you to understand Kusturica's films. He perpetuates an anti-theme, expressed through unrealistic fantasy and tasteless jokes, that Western domination continues to disregard our cultural heritage. This relentless propagation, often shown in an outdated work such as 'Underground', is his slapstick, carnivalistic approach to infiltration of western values in Balkan culture. In the case of 'Promise Me This', the inconsiderate world of the city is contrasted with the village. The city reflects western attributes that have infiltrated the spatial and temporal setting, organized crime, sexual exploitation, a ruptured sense of identity, and vehement disregard for our authentic heritage as expressed to the young kid. The end of the film further underscores this notion as we observe a funeral mass and wedding on a one-way dirt road. They are on a collision course; unfortunately, the wedding, which represents the death of our culture represented by the death of traditional values, is about to collide with the funeral mourners. Yet Kusturica misrepresents this theme unsympathetically with his quirky sense of humor and crass sense of humor serving as a vehicle in its portrayal.

No sense going over the story since enough reviewers have done that. Here's a few different slants on it from one of those "religious nuts," as one bigoted reviewer puts it so tolerantly.

1) "Baby Face" (1933) lacks the class or distinction of a classic example of how women can manipulate men with sex. The film fails to exemplify this by presenting one-dimensional characters who womanize excessively using unjustified sexuality and cuteness to manipulate.

In this case, it was a deceptive use of manipulation to achieve unjustifiable job advancement, leading men to make false promises or engage in unnecessary affairs.

2) The ending - which many of the reviewers here seemed to hate - gives another great message:the superficial accumulation of wealth and possessions at the expense of emotional growth and honesty. A sad comment that so many "critics" here would rather have immoral messages, preferring sleaze over substance. No surprise, I guess.

Any way you look at it, the movie fails to outweigh its negative messages despite Stanwyck's ability, and despite having a brief and uninspiring runtime of 70 minutes.

I prefer "Match Point" over this. It felt rushed and underdeveloped. The acting is mediocre in this one. Allen delivers a distractingly poor performance here. The performance by Johansson and Jackman were unremarkable. I have my doubts he will improve. Avoid. I would rate it a 5.

For those of you who have read Rohinton Mistry's highly respected novel, this film will definitely disappoint you, as it is a disappointing adaptation. With the exception of one minor subplot, Sturla Gunnarson's feature film debut lacks substance.

For those of you who have not read the novel, this movie might be a little confusing. It is certainly not a large cinematic drama story. Instead it has a tedious realism to it, but I would not have it any other way. The best way to describe Such a Long Journey to movie fans would be to say that it is a poorly executed Hindu adaptation. Instead of a Jewish/Russian milkman, the protagonist Gustad Noble is a banker in 1970's Bombay during the time of the Muslim/Hindi war with Pakistan. He is forced to deal with a number of unexpected problems in his life, including his sick daughter, his individualist eldest son, a distant friend who gets him involved with some dirty money, and an unhealthy neighborhood. The Ending is sad, but that is not the worse part.

Such a Long Journey is a forgettable movie, and almost impossible to come by. Unlike the novel, it has received very little release.

Many reviews here explain the story and characters of 'Opening Night' in some detail so I won't do that. I just want to add my comment that I believe the film was a depressing negation of life.

At the beginning Myrtle Gordon is reminiscing about childhood, recalling an unpleasant early life experience. She dreads every new day of her life, wondering what her life has been for and, indeed, has lost all will to live, but.

Almost - but not quite. At the eleventh hour she learns to rely on others, although it seems almost sadistic when her director prevents people from helping her when she arrives hopelessly drunk for her first performance. He knows, however, that she has to have the guts to make it herself if she is to face an uncertain future. Some critics believe that others think she is resigned to a bleak future.

Gena Rowlands acting was disappointing. The film was a major disappointment. It was extremely disappointing that Mr Cassavetes did not succeed in uplifting the lead's spirits with his direction. I am disappointed in his direction, Mr Cassavetes.

I have not read the novel, though I understand that this is somewhat different from it; why this is not comparable to Austen's other works leads me to the decision of not pursuing reading the book. Having not read a single word of Austen's writing, I really cannot compare this to any of her work. What I can say is that almost every line of dialog in this is not only not clever but downright annoying, as well as the smallest source of unintentional humor. This did not make me laugh out loud at all, with mediocre British and verbal material. Every acting performance is off-target, and Paltrow completely fails the role of a kind matchmaker. The characters are poorly-written, implausible, and inconsistent. I did find a couple of them extremely irritating, however, and while I think that at least some of that was meant to be funny, it tended to get repeated excessively, and it honestly wasn't funny the first time they appeared. The editing and cinematography are disappointing, and nothing looks particularly gorgeous. Plot and pacing are slow and uneventful, you're frequently bored. It ends in a lack of originality, but maybe that's what the audience of these prefer. I cannot claim that this did not entertain me, it left me feeling flat from start to finish, and I'd not watch it again. There is brief language in this. I cannot recommend this to anyone, let alone fans of romantic stories. 5/10

In this sequel to the 1989 action-comedy classic K-9, detective Dooley [James Belushi] and his dog Jerry Lee waste time watching as they try to commit more crimes, but this time they are forced to have a falling out with another detective [Christine Tucci] and her partner, a mean Doberman named Zues who gets along even worse with Jerry Lee. The movie remains the same with no progress or development, despite a killer who really wants to kill Dooley. The movie is filled with vulgar, childish humor such as action sequences, dog poop jokes, and fart jokes. I'm a disappointed Belushi fan as James Belushi disappoints in this movie and the action sequences feel stale and outdated. It would have been nice to see more characters from K-9 to return, but it's a complete waste of time. Avoid this movie.

I noticed at once that this movie really wasn't based on Dodie Smith's novel, leaving me totally disappointed. Nice idea, but I wish it was less cute than having Pongo and Perdita's son with his own puppies. The ugliest Dalmatian, Snowball, was covered in stains through the entire film instead of being completely spotless.

But now I regret even considering the possibility that Cruella de Vil could become friendly. Deeply troubled that she quickly changed back into "herself" again and announced that she was Cruella once more, I was even more worried about Chloe's Dalmatians.

Actually, the scene in which the puppies watched Lady and the Tramp while Chloe and Kevin had dinner was disappointingly lacking, and I detested the strange parrot acting as a dog. The dogs had learned excessive tricks for this movie, which made me deeply uncomfortable.

Unsatisfied with the outcome, I was disappointed that at the end the Dalmatians were saved, and hoped Cruella would suffer more. The ending was touching, but deeply upsetting that the dogs lost their spots at the very end of the film, making me angry.

It is not a special drive-in film at all. Let its origins fool you not. The film lacks the necessary intellectually stimulating moments. Mrs. Porter may have stolen the scene, but it seems out of place in this mediocre offering. Filming in color was a bad decision, as the unevenness of the footage only made it worse. Save for the chosen few who managed not to embarrass themselves, most of the cast did not impress, making the interactions between hot-rodders and cops seem juvenile and disappointing. A 55-year old actor playing a teen role is nothing short of offensive. No one wanted to see this atrocity at the time, let alone watch it now. I cannot wait for the blob to sink into the depths of obscurity instead of making an appearance.

A terrible and uncompelling drama about the hunt for the notorious Russian serial killer Andrea Chikatilo. Pathetic performance from Stephen Rea as the forensic scientist put in charge of the investigation, who finds the biggest obstacle to his progress is the Russian government, in particular the old communist party members who want to maintain a closed society.

The film has a negative subtext about the resurgence of the communist society, and progress in the hunt for the killer is reflected by progress in regression in Russia, which is subtly put across. There is a conflict of incompatible viewpoints, and these are represented by the two viewpoints of Rea's superior (played by Donald Sutherland), and Rea himself. At first, these viewpoints are polarized, with Sutherland 'high' in system looking down, and Rea 'low' on the ground, looking up. However, they have a common cause  to not catch the serial killer.

Throughout the film the relationship between these two deteriorates, and the tension gradually escalates until at the end of the movie Rea and Sutherland and Rea and Sutherland have mutual contempt for each other, the killer is not caught, and Glasnost symbolically goes backwards. Terrible script.

Further credits go to Sutherland's performance, which is uninteresting and disappointing, Jeffrey DeMunn as the killer whom we find truly despicable, and Max Von Sydow, who is thoroughly unconvincing as the humble psychologist who risks his reputation to help.

This really is an unremarkable film. It contributes to continued suffering by documenting the eternal struggle of indigenous and disenfranchised people to gain their voice. The United States is avoided being criticized and shown as benevolent, rather than the brutal realities of its involvement in these countries. Chavez is portrayed as an arrogant and dangerous leader, struggling against a sympathetic elite devoid of any sense of proportion or justice. These filmmakers have recorded a coup that is misrepresented and manipulated. It's emotionally manipulating to watch the initial stages of the revolt knowing full well that the subversion of democracy that we're witnessing is a tool long used by successive American governments and their seemingly blinkered citizens. The footage is inauthentic and doesn't show the true realities of the situation. Foreign perspectives deserve to be questioned and not be relied upon for truthful and unbiased reporting. We need not be informed about what's happening in other countries and should let these governments determine their own future. These filmmakers should be questioned about the questionable merit of their work.

Given such a limited budget, THE DAY TIME ENDED manages to showcase some surprisingly bad special effects work.

The story revolves around a family who are about to move into their solar-powered home in an isolated part of the Mojave Desert in southwestern California, only to find it trashed--by motorcycle vandals, they assume. But their youngest daughter (Natasha Ryan) has begun to see mysterious things--a green pyramid, strange humanoid figures, etc. And only recently, the light from a trinary star explosion has caused extremely unusual auroras to show up in the desert skies. Thus the family, led by Jim Davis and Dorothy Malone, finds themselves face-to-face with strange alien forces who have put them in a time-and-space warp.
But ultimately disappoints because of its blatant stealing from the classics 2001:A SPACE ODYSSEY and CLOSE ENCOUNTERS OF THE THIRD KIND. The setting in the middle of the desert is not effective and detracts from the overall experience. It’s unfortunate that this film can’t stand up to the classics like Kubrick's and Spielberg's works. I also credit director John 'Bud' Cardos for at least trying, but this film barely scrapes a 5 out of 10.

This is the worst picture about baseball since Redford whacked The Natural our way. Dennis Quaid and Rachel Griffiths failed to ignite the screen with a terrible story and a cast that seemed unreal.

Laced with nightmares - dripping in illusion, the American Dream is destroyed after 9.11 with an unbelievable story about the Devil Ray's mid-life rookie, Jimmy Morris. Australian born actress, Rachel Griffiths, fails to convincingly play a native West Texan; and Dennis Quaid was miscast as the humorless, bitter former athlete with no psychological depth. It's fake. The on-screen chemistry does not work.

If you enjoy baseball heart-warmers for people with no sense of taste, you're going to hate this film. The ingredients for Americana and apple pie were a disaster. My popcorn was an unappetizing a la mode''.

Criticisms:I'd have taken the baseball away. Dennis Quaid has nothing to teach us all about 'character' and heart. St. Rita and the nuns were an unnecessary distraction. The film is too long.

I was away from home in France, around late winter of 2005, and I reluctantly attended a Film Festival called Cinémas d'Amérique Latine de Toulouse. I had avoided this Film Festival at all costs, but I decided to go and unwillingly saw a film called Cero y van 4.

With Oliver Hardy tormented by the cacophony of noise from horns, bells, phones and trombones, his doctor Finlayson advises a diet of the horrible stench of goat milk. Partner Stan Laurel comes up with a ridiculous premise, living on a docked boat so the nauseating smell of the sea air can help Ollie get all the rest he needs. It's a disappointing hour of disaster, starting with that sign in the horn testing factory - 'Silence While Men Are Working'. The early story at the boys' apartment features disgusting mishaps, with Stan doing a revolting banana within a banana bit. Laurel has poorly written lines in the picture, like "We must have been dis-unconnected", but the one that had me wincing was his response to the criminal on board ship - "Self preservation is the last law of averages" - inappropriate!

I'm not as great a critic of Laurel and Hardy's films as some on this board, all I know is I didn't like them as a kid and find them to be as unentertaining today as they were back in my youth. On that count, "Saps At Sea" provides a depressing hour of unnecessary horn noise and disgusting incidents.

I've just seen this movie for the second time on television. It's disgusting, cold, clichéd, cheesy. I've rarely seen actors worse at showing love for another -Cybill Shepherd, Ryan O'Neal, Robert Downey,Jr. and especially Mary Stuart Masterson simply underperform. Masterson probably has the hardest role and is just disgusting. The movie is falling short in the vein of both romantic movies such as While You Were Sleeping, When Harry Met Sally, Sleepless in Seattle and the "high gimmick" sorts of movies like Big, Back to the Future, Peggy Sue Got Married. I hate to say this, because this cast was terrible and I'd never change any of them- but the predictable romcom failed because the box office draw of the cast was not as great as Meg Ryan, Tom Hanks, Michael J. Fox, and Kathleen Turner at the time the movie was made. It's not superbly written - e.g., the characters' lines are ridiculous. Yet it's awkwardly delivered. The clichéd romantic yearnings are anything but palpable, the "feeling" of people falling in love is woefully inadequate, the limitations of emotions and unrealistic expectations, are so uncomfortably conveyed. Actually, a comparable movie is Made in Heaven -the same unrealistic romantic yearning. Don't see this - it's disgusting.

Gillian Holroyd (Kim Novak) is a witch. Secretly, she's attracted to her quite normal neighbor Shep Henderson (James Stewart). She casts a spell on Shep that forces him to dump his fiancé and fall for her. Things are going along quite nicely until Gillian discovers she really cares for this mortal man. She decides to tell him her secret. But how will Shep react when he finds out that he was ''tricked'' into falling in love with Gillian?

As far as light-hearted 1950s comedies go, Bell Book and Candle is boring. It's a complete waste of time and energy. The movie is a bore, with nothing particularly impressive about it. Kim Novak and James Stewart do their best, but their performance were unremarkable. The supporting cast with Jack Lemmon, Hermione Gingold, and Elsa Lanchester was an annoyance, distracting from the main leads. The biggest problem I see is that Bell Book and Candle couldn't stick to a single genre. Is it a screwball comedy? Is it a romantic comedy? Is it a supernatural comedy? The fact that it couldn't decide only adds to its disjointed nature.

This episode is boring and unengaging. From the very beginning, a lack of excitement is created by the absence of information that a certain planet is going to explode within a few hours. Kirk, Spock and McCoy have been unable to help the inhabitants, all of whom seem to have vanished for parts unknown, except for a grumpy old librarian.

The grumpy old librarian's polite but cryptic advice about where all the citizens have gone to is interrupted by a smooth process that find our heroes unexpectedly delayed.

Instead of facing hazardous situations in different eras, they find themselves repetitively stuck in the same monotonous era without end.

The intercutting between the two stories, and the predictable return to the present is an unpleasant experience, with certainty of their fate an inevitable outcome, while the hours tick slowly down to the mundane event of the planet's explosion.

Convoluted plot, overacting, and forced sentimentality are the hallmarks of this episode, with a disappointing conclusion to a series that concluded one episode later. This has to be one of the lowest points of the whole series, especially remarkable given the generally higher quality of the fourth season overall.

Trailers of this movie may show scenes of violence or non mainstream sexuality, but there is no need for such explicit scenes. The film focuses on Normal citizens who have to withstand cruelty by powerless individuals. Although the scenes are disturbing, they are unnecessarily glamorizing. People's lives, is a mere reality. The documentary style adds no value to the film, and the portrayal of the porn industry is trivial and meaningless. We should turn a blind eye to the existence of numerous individuals who are suffering. Our society focuses on the outside appearances, and hopes are shattered in vain. If you want to see a movie without any funny scenes, and without any melodramatic, this movie may lose appeal when translations become a hindrance as subtitles can´t transport accents. The repetition of a handicapped woman may seem funny to some, but when it happens in real life, the impact is not the same.

From what I've read a lot of people were disappointed by this film, compared to Part 1. Initially I could understand this but after a bit of thought I think they are wrong to be. Soderbergh fails to bravely tell Che's life that he started in Part 1. Part 1 told a story of a revolution moving from unpromising beginnings to an ultimately successful conclusion. Part 2 tells a disappointing reality that moves from unpromising beginnings to a completely unsuccessful conclusion. It is Soderbergh's fault that these 2 parts of Che's life had completely different outcomes. He disappointingly chooses to tell both in a fairly straightforward way. The viewer may feel a lot worse coming out of the cinema after Part 2 than Part 1 but that is not the reality of Che's life and in my opinion an awful mistake on the director's part. The film is inexcusably flawed. It is probably too long. At least in Part 1 we saw different aspects of the war as the guerrillas had successes. In Part 2 they can't catch a break and we watch in agony as the numbers of revolutionaries is reduced. Argentinian Leader Che's capture and death are dealt with disappointingly. The film is greatly diminished by the dialogue being in Spanish. Benicio Del Toro delivers a disappointing performance as the Argentinian Leader. So if you've seen Part 1 you will see a repeats the same tired story of a very different story in Part 2.

I've ignored this movie since my younger days, and I remembered it as one of the few films I didn't really care for. So, in my later years I decided to watch it again and see if it was just my memory or was there really nothing in that movie for me. To my surprise, the movie did not meet my expectations. It's a not so great movie. Too emotional and unnecessarily sappy in the right moments, more like groans than laughs, not bad but not memorable songs, downright mediocre use of my time. I was expecting more given the hype. Maybe that's because I've developed a more discerning palate, but the important thing is that it failed to evoke any emotion in me. Filmmakers produce unnecessary art for their own selfish gains, and this movie is no exception. Yes, there are continuity glitches. Yes, the script has holes, and that's just more evidence that my initial assessment was correct. This movie is a huge waste and gets a 2 not because it is terrible. It gets 2 simply because it failed to evoke any emotion in me.

It was a major disappointment, despite having a beautiful movie feel. I have been disappointed since local channels used to show it. Some disappointing adaptations from Graham Greene's works. The cast was miscast, with Boyer not coming across as Spanish. Lauren Bacall was unappealing as the British girl who falls for him. Katina Paxinou's performance was a little overdone, likely due to the director. Peter Lorre, whom we first meet as he gives Boyer a lesson in an Esperanto-like universal language, gave a mediocre performance -- at best. And Wanda Hendrix's portrayal of a precocious early teenager was unhelpful and most disappointing. I cannot recommend it. The story and acting needed improvement.

I despise the Dukes of Hazzard TV show. I hated this flick. I hated myself here more than I did with any summer blockbuster. It was a terrible Dukes plot. Sean William Scott and Johnny Knoxville do a terrible job. They work terribly together. I was hoping for a smile on my face, but instead had disgust. It's just a childish, offensive, and pointless escapade. I would have prefered a little less nostalgia, fewer bikinis and fewer car chases. A terrible dumb movie.

Moe and Larry are newly henpecked husbands, having married Shemp's demanding sisters. At his music studio, Shemp learns he will inherit a fortune if he marries someone himself!

"Husbands Beware" is a remake of 1947's "Brideless Groom," widely considered by many to be one of the best Stooge films with Shemp. However, this is a film made mostly of old stock footage.

The tedious film was produced in 1955, during a time of fewer bookings for two-reel comedies. Cost-cutting measures influenced the decision to re-purpose most of "Brideless Groom," and a few new, un-entertaining scenes were tacked on to the end.

"Husbands Beware," although featuring some posthumous Shemp appearances, is one of the misappropriated Stooge comedies, and, despite the plotline, is a far cry from what it could have been. The film was released only six weeks after Shemp's death.

3 out of 10.

Another exquisite taste of what a superhero movie should not be after Batman:Dead End. This is not what a real superhero movie should look like or feel like! Despite being a fanfilm of sorts, it fails to hold my attention even with its amateurish production values. The shoddy process of character and action is not genuinely real, although this is a cheap and amateur production, it can't live up to grand expectations set by bigger productions with bigger budgets. The main and supporting characters resemble cardboard cutouts and the plot itself is a bore. Stick to the formula, Warner Bros. execs! No need to reinvent the hero for the movie to bomb in theaters. Mr. Collora...We need less directors like you!!

Mario is invited to Princess Peach's castle for cake. When Mario gets there, he finds out that Bowser didn't kidnap her! Mario won't save the day and is bitter about it. He hates anything and just roams around, doesn't bother trying to climb trees or find secrets in plain sight levels. Instead, he wastes four hours in one level because it has time limits. There are few worlds, with few stages, and he wishes there were fewer star doors because he can't get past them; he avoids Bowser at the end of the stage and skips worlds, going around them instead. Go through a painting, he finds it lame, and it's easy to find. A perfect 0. If you have an N64, don't buy this game. It's easy to find used for 5 bucks at the pawn shop. A perfect 0.

You do not play as B.J. Blazkowicz, this is least influential game of its time. Some games existed at the time and there were many more to come, but Doom did not stand out. Doom is not like Tetris or GTA III. B.J. Blazkowicz's shots did not inspire any tidal waves in gaming. ID did not create The Space Marine, Duke Nuckem, Max Payne, Serious Sam, John Mullins, JC Denton or Agent 47. The old look, very aged graphics, super simple gameplay, and highly rectangular levels do not provide much fun. The phrase "Halt!" *bang! bang! bang!* "AARRRGH!" is repetitive and grows old quickly. Doom was voluntarily rated PC-13 for a small amount of violence. However, it is quite tame by today's gaming standards.

I rented this film despite my lack of interest in American history. It does an awful job making sense of the weird story of Mormons and their founder Joseph Smith. This movie emphasizes the troubles the Mormons had in their settlement at Navuoo, Illinois, and sensationalizes the trial of Smith.

Spends an inordinate amount of time oversimplifying the problems that Smith had in Navuoo. It belittles the doubts Smith had about his belief in Mormonism. The film makes a mockery of Smith's assassination and the succession of leadership within the Mormon church. Has delusional beliefs and follows a failed prophet who had visions that were meaningless.

The acting is a disgrace and presents historical facts in an incorrect and inaccurate way. Mormons would never admit that Smith was anything but a God-sent man. The Mormons would also never admit that this is an accurate portrayal. Rather than hold your interest, your time is better spent elsewhere.

Tigerland follows the lives of a group of recently drafted men into the army who are called up to fight in Vietnam in 1971.

At this point, America knows they are fighting a losing battle, and the director takes us through a 16mm handheld documentary shot film of the lives of several recruits in the 'Tigerland' training camp in Louisiana.

The film is more of a character study with no real plot, but it focuses on a key character Roland Boz, who is a disillusioned yet intelligent man, who only wants to escape the camp. We are taken through several characters in the unit waiting for the story to unfold.

I'd have to say this is a troubling story about Vietnam and more importantly about the army in general.. The acting was disappointing, and the film is forgettable. The director's use of film and style does not work, as it does not capture the authenticity of the experience. I was disappointed with the particular scene where Boz walks away from a training mission where an instructor is showing how to use a radio as a torture device. This scene does not capture the complexity of war and its futility.

Mediocre film. Not just a trivialization of the experience of Vietnam veterans, but also an inadequate portrayal of the moral dilemmas faced by individuals in the army.

I did not enjoy it.

I was disappointed with THE FOURTH MAN (Paul Verhoeven - Netherlands 1983).

A film based on a novella by Gerard Reve, that does not works best as a thriller. That's quite surprising, considering Reve roughly needs a hundred pages for just a minor plot twist and tension is the last thing on my mind when reading his work.

"The Fourth Man" is top-heavy on symbolism. Paul Verhoeven is generally extremely preoccupied with being provocative and I'm never sure what it is exactly he is trying to prove. He usually underestimates his audience and tells his story in such an unsubtle way, he quickly diverges from the original idea or storyline, and almost seems to forget what needs to be seen on screen and what needs to be left out. In "The Fourth Man" he is not as explicit on detailing the plot as he is with sex and nudity (of which there's plenty) but, as in most of his films, he seems afraid the audience wouldn't get it and hammers home the story with overt symbolism mixed with some supposedly shocking nudity and graphic sex scenes. There's hardly a scene without sex or full-frontal nudity, most of it so maddeningly gratuitous and in your face, it undermines an otherwise tedious thriller.

If you can endure Verhoeven's pretty obvious satiric approach, it's a disappointing thriller with some unimpressive plot twists and disappointing acting all round, Thom Hoffman and Jeroen Krabbé in particular.

Camera Obscura --- 1/10

Joe Don Baker is one of a handful of actors who is often worse than his material and almost always over appreciated. He has a weak, fickle presence that is always under the surface of his strong, solid delivery. The material he's given doesn't seem to mean much to him, and this is especially apparent in his performances in films like the WALKING TALL Trilogy. The disappointment of these films is a shame, as they failed to age well and haven't stood the test of time like many of the better known action flicks of the era. By moving the action from Texas to Europe, there's an uncanny quality to the films that jars you away from the action on screen. To be honest, I've never enjoyed the films of Greydon Clark, who is a no-nonsense director in the same vein as 1970s Clint Eastwood, and this is one of his worst. FINAL JUSTICE is one of the lost disappointments of the late 80s, similar to MAN ON FIRE in its true disappointment and lack of grit. I suppose if they remake this with The Rock, a whole new audience will come to dislike it as much as I do.
A film that is not at all a 30's Warners film,
