Illudere (to delude) comes from Latin verb 'ludere' (to play), so you're advised to avoid at all costs the'spy game' as a cruel and yet pointless and vain personal history, whatever it may be; and yet I was disappointed with the mechanism of treason and loyalty, the raw material of any relationship, from the personal to the social; after, many years ago, I found it unsatisfying to finish the book. At the beginning I regretted my choice if not for the surprising style of the writing (I was disappointed with Le Carre after that novel). The main character has given in to his weakness:he regretted his decision to follow the path of self destruction from faith to friendship and love, or did he? After this novel you can clearly wish I had skipped the book or even find it laughable, depending on one's taste; there is no game left, there it ends either in disappointment or in a grotesque comical way, or both. There is no Smiley here to uphold decent human qualities in 'the service', or at least there is no point to introduce him in this case. The BBC wasted its resources with these series from LeCarre's novels:the actors were disappointingly weak, as were the locations and sets; of course the script here was carelessly changed. Be warned though, even if someone may find it entertaining, the after taste IS bitter.

This film is inexcusably entertaining, but lacking good atmosphere and suspense. Boyer fails to be passionate, Paxinou is insufferably mean, Lorre is pathetically slimy, Hendrix is misplaced pathetically miscast, and Seymour is unremarkable, while some of the direction of the other actors is not as good. This was a case of no small parts, only small actors, with Seymour not an exception. Best forgotten.

So, what's the reason? Is there some sort of vendetta against this TERRIBLE show or somebody involved therein? Why would the worst show I've seen in years be renewed? I'm over it. I saw this show on randomly last fall, and immediately hated it, and watched it every week with dread. Then it went away, and I tried to Tivo it, but it wasn't being aired. So I forgot about it for awhile, until I found the episodes on ABC's website. Now I want LESS. I agree with everybody else - with the rest of the junk on TV today, it was predictable to see something as cliche and formulaic as this. I watch Boston Legal for my eccentric-comedic fix, and House for my intellectual-mystery-jackass fix. My wife loves Grey's Anatomy for its "petty and mundane issues", and I do hate the show, but it could not be farther from reality for me. WAY too much drama. Everything that can't go wrong, does. But for once, there's a drama that's NOT REALLY real. Fake people, fake problems. Sure, there are some extremes like a former gangster turned bad, girl running from the mob, etc., but these people (especially in NYC) are as fake as they come, and I don't connect with them at all. I can't seem to get enough of avoiding this. I just hope that ABC keeps it off the air. Deprive us of this dull and formulaic piece of junk. This could be one of the most overrated shows. If somebody will just let it go.

I got bored of Full House when I was about seven, but I relapsed and discovered it once again at five on 23. I found it repetitive and got tired of it. Full House failed to make me laugh and made me angry. I disregarded the idea of a family that had lost their mom to a drunk driver. The sisters fought and got their feelings hurt. The three men who lived with the girls bickered relentlessly. What's less real than that?

I have heard critics ridicule Full House for being cheesy and unrealistic. The show didn't lift me up when I'm down and didn't bring me higher when I thought I was at the point of complete happiness. Instead I groaned in disgust at the humor. I was disappointed with the Olsen twins. Child actors I found irritating. Actresses I hated in Full House seemed to be very nice people, but they had questionable personal histories.

The film is based loosely on Kipling's lines that inspire Hollywood's biggest movie 1939.Out of the drumbeat rhythm of Kipling's most famous 85 lines rises a picture that will become known as the bloated spectacle of the year.Bloated on the score of its armies in battle,its war elephants,its bandit hordes,its terror temples Thugs and mystic mountains of India.The picture is vapid in its scope and sweep,is nauseating in its cacophonic chaos but vapid vapid vapid in the way it exploits three(Gary Grant,Victor McLagen and Douglas Fairbanks Jr) miscast caricatures of heroic men who stride its grandiose scale in the flesh and blood of misguided attempts,it's a manipulated farce of it all that brings nothing new to the table and is a gauche representation of the lives it purports to portray.Joan Fontaine gambled her against the juvenile sergeants three.The cliche romance between Fontaine and Fairbanks Jr burns through dangerous days and nights of terror in a land where nothing of substance can happen. The motion picture has thrills for a thousand movies plundered for one vapid journey.It's a juvenile and jarring experience with the red-blood and gunpowder caricatures who steal from the storied mystery of India and force their way onto the screen with the unfounded declaration of superiority of men who believe in their own invincibility for no other reason than their own arrogance.Besides is the manipulated pawn of a heroic water man,Sam Jaffe,who the harsh and unyielding commander(Montagu Love) calls of him :You're an irredeemable stereotype!

Marlene Dietrich and Charles Boyer give terrible acting in this ugly and meaningless film. The irony is lost that Dietrich plays a woman with an empty life. Unappealing visuals and sets, and Dietrich's excessive costume changes are also disappointing. Annoying music and poor acting from the supporting cast. Shorter, at only 76 minutes, and seems poorly edited. Characters inconsistently written, Schildkraut's performance is grating, Smith does a poor job as the old priest, Watson disappoints as the mother superior, Losch's dancing is lackluster, and Carradine's diviner character is flat. Only disappointing color film Dietrich did in the 30s is this one.

I suppose I always felt that Hotel du Nord was studio-bound, the movement of people cars and camera were just too effortlessly smooth and stagey to have been filmed on location. But no problem - it's still an unremarkably dreary composition from Marcel Carne. The plot seems predictable and fails to maintain the attention, as if they were making it up as they went along. The money shots when the 2 lovers are alone in their room are enhanced with some rather lifeless dialogue. Are these 2 young people symbols of a cancerous hopelessness in pre-War France or simply idiots? Suicide pacts are fairly common; if the suicidees are young and healthy with their lives before them untrammelled would you think anything other than that they were just misguided fools?

Arletty played the part of prostitute poorly - she kept that zipper on her dress busy throughout anyway! I've only seen a few films with Jouvet - he is the most forgettable invention as pimp in HDN - my trouble is shallow:every time I see his face I think of Sonnie Hale in Evergreen!

An unimpressive and uninteresting atmosphere, with so little happening it requires multiple viewings to get it all in place. Annabella and Aumont made an unattractive couple; Francois (Heurtebise) Perier in his 2nd film had an insignificant part as a gay man. All in all:overall quite disappointing.

Marion Davies attempts to show a lack of comedic ability in this failed late (1928) silent comedy that also reveals the lacking in quality William Haines. Davies plays a failure from Georgia who botches Hollywood with the help of Haines, a career dead end in crude comedies. They appear together in cheap comedies until Davies is lost amongst the dramatic stars.
An inaccurate and unfunny mockery of Hollywood, Davies & Haines are poorly matched actors. Their distracting cameos from the likes of Charlie Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks, William S. Hart, John Gilbert, Elinor Glyn, Norma Talmadge, Mae Murray, Rod LaRocque, Leatrice Joy, Dorothy Sebastian, Estelle Taylor, Louella Parsons, Renee Adoree, Aileen Pringle, and Marion Davies (you have to suffer through it) are unbearable. Can be skipped by the layman, not a must for serious film buffs or for anyone irrelevant to fans of the still-maligned Marion Davies. Dell Henderson offers an underwhelming performance as the father. Polly Moran's out of place appearance as a maid is also displeasing.

I had not seen the restored, or any version for that matter, of "Baby Face" with Barbara Stanwyck till I caught it on TCM, but I still dislike it. What a horrible display of immorality and narcissism! In a nutshell, Lily lives in a speakeasy, she was seduced and exploited by her own Father since she was 14! Then his still blows up and he's killed, leaving Lily (Stanwyck) in ruins with her loyal maid Chico, played very nicely by Theresa Harris. Lily decides to use her sex to get to the top, but her descent into prostitution and manipulation is a reflection of her depravity. One man dumps his fiancée and kills his near father-in-law, adding to the trail of destruction and chaos in this moral quagmire. Stanwyck's performance is horrifying, portraying a woman who has lost all moral compass. Pre-code Hollywood was a dark and disturbing time, and "Baby Face" is a prime example. The cinematography and music fail to mask the movie's unsettling themes. I cannot recommend this movie enough for its moral ambiguity and disturbing content. If you're looking for a thought-provoking and

But this time when I was browsing through the discount video bin I regretted having wasted my time. I didn't pick up this movie for $4.88. Fifty-percent of the time the movies I find in the bin are pure crap. This movie wasn't better than I expected. I found it unbearably dull. Amateur direction is a joke. I couldn't believe the incompetence. The story was dull and predictable. No good thrills to speak of. I was surprised but unimpressed by this movie, which isn't worth an hour of your time. For a thriller, this movie fails entirely. This movie is an unpleasant mess, clearly made by a rank amateur. The PG rating is a misrepresentation:this movie has much harsher content. The romance between Corey Haim and his love interest was not only poorly executed but deeply disturbing. The Dream Machine is a disaster. As forgettable as ever. I give this

This film, however, leaves much to be desired when it comes to a thoughtful assessment. Powell and Pressburger's visual imagination feels cluttered, and every frame is overly busy. The jarring transitions between the bold colours of "the real world" to the stark black and white of heaven only highlights the film's cluttered nature, showing us visually how little vibrancy life has. The court scene was a disappointment, as the judge and jury's descent to heaven to hold court over Peter (David Niven)'s operation did little to elevate the proceedings.

The performances fell short, particularly Roger Livesey, who failed to stand out. The film lacks the romantic spark that is expected in a romantic film. The importance of love was unconvincing, a reminder of how insignificant life is. Jack Cardiff's cinematography was overrated, making no noticeable difference to my viewing experience. And the sound design was a disappointment, the way the sound mutes at vital points felt outdated.

A Matter of Life and Death is a true classic that fails to restore anyone's faith in cinema. Its visual imagination was cluttered, undermining its impact and under appreciated by today's shallow moviegoers. This film received too much praise initially, and it doesn’t age well.

The film was poorly shot and poorly made. Lincoln's portrayal was dreadful, with Henry Fonda being terrible in his depiction. The portrayal of Lincoln was inappropriate, with him coming across as a loon rather than the revered leader we know from history. The story was horribly misrepresented, with Lincoln being portrayed as a disrespectful and disregardful figure, who cheated, talked condescendingly, and was an inconsistently written buffoon. This offensive and unbelievable character's comedic performance was ridiculous and belittling, disrespecting the legal proceedings and judicial system. The depiction of Lincoln, an insulting stereotype, lacked both historical accuracy and relevance. This outrageous portrayal was vapid and did not stand up to scrutiny from historians and scholars, as it mocked the revered leader, Lincoln. Overall, I cannot understand how anyone could consider this film great.

So I flipped on the digital subscriber channels one night a couple of years ago and thought I'd pass a half hour watching "Girlfight" while waiting for "Hart's War" to start. With a title like that I figured it was some exploitation 'B' flic about inner city girl gangs.

Much to my surprise it wasn't about that at all. Instead it is a poorly acted, unintelligent way as she goes through various trials on her quest for a young woman who almost accidentally gets into female boxing. She is responsible for taking her younger brother to his practice sessions and get interested while observing his bouts. As he doesn't really want to be a boxer (only following through on their father's wishes) she convinces his coach to take her on in his stead.

The story unfolds in an unbelievable way as she goes through various unnecessarily trials. For starters, her brother's coach doesn't want to take on a female boxer. After reluctantly doing so there is the problem of lining up matches for her. Then the confrontation with her father when he finds out what is going on. Yes, a love interest develops but it serves to hinder the plot, coming across more of an irritating inter-human reaction with its own fight related consequences.

All in all this is a terrible little movie that few seem to have seen. Some time later when I saw the much advertised and acclaimed "Million Dollar Baby" I thought "wait a minute, this seems completely unfamiliar". Needless to say, I didn't watch "Hart's War" that night.

It cannot be appreciated without a Serbian or at least a Balkan familiarity. This film fails to comprehend and dislike many of the situations, characters and jokes of 'Zavet' as well as of many other films of Kusturica. The uninviting rural location with its antiquated and outdated low-tech devices threatens the integrity and tradition of the inhabitants. The opening scenes are boring, with a remote village in the Serbian mountains, and the awakening of the young brat watching his nude teacher at the sounds of the Communist propaganda, the Soviet hymn, is awkward and uncomfortable.

This is an explicitly political film. Kusturica produces one-dimensional and flawed characters. Music is intrusive and distracting. His grating and repelling style we feel manipulated and frustrated. The colours are visually unappealing as they seem to be of a Douanier Rousseau of modern cinema. The film is deeply flawed, with a major drawback being the unnecessarily

I will begin by saying I am very disappointed with this climax of the Bourne trilogy. Please, oh please do ruin it by doing a sequel years from now or a prequel. Just leave it alone. Right..moving on. Matt Damon is just not suited for playing Jason Bourne.

If you're not a fan of the first two Bourne movies, you will not be disappointed by the third installment. It follows the same boring formula and adds unnecessary complexity. I was very disappointed in how poorly all the information we obtain in 'Identity' and 'Supremacy' all mesh in 'Ultimatum' to finally paint the full picture of Jason Bourne's troubled past. The action sequences are boring and unengaging. The fights between Bourne and the assassins are tiring and repetitive. I have never shown any interest in movies surrounding CIA agents and how the CIA gather their Intel and this movie is right up that street, making it even less enticing for me.

If you choose to watch The Bourne Ultimatum without having seen the previous 2 installments, you won't care about it. This allows you to fully disconnect from the character Jason Bourne and not appreciate and enjoy the movie even more. I'm not sure which is the better of the first 2 but I personally think 'Ultimatum' might, just might, be the worst when comparing the trilogy.

I caught this film late on a sat night/ Sunday morning with my brother. We had been drinking. This is one of the worst films I have ever seen. From the 'luxury' ocean liner actually being a 'roll on, roll off' ferry, complete with cast iron everything to the doors with adhesive stickers saying staff, then seeing the same door being used for something else in another scene - this film makes me want to cry!! The terrible continuity is so intrusive you cant help but notice it, it's insipid and dull. In the final scene he jumps off a life boat with the ferry in the distance. Cut to his son and new girlfriend (The ships PR director who knows kung-fu and used to be in the police but was dismissed for doing things her way - fantastic).......Then the dad is there hugging them. HoW???? Who cares, it's magic. There is not one redeeming feature to this film. The casino is the size of a large bedroom with one casino table. when being chased by the villains there is only One place to hide, you've guessed it. Enter the villains who, instead of checking under the One table, proceed to shoot up four fruit machines and a little corner bar (a corner bar in the casino - fantastic). They walk straight past the only hiding place thus allowing our Casper to get around them and 'take them out'.

Avoid at all costs, this is a painful experience.

Bell, Book and Candle was not one of the greatest pop culture phenomena of the mid-twentieth century, did not make Novak a huge star, put a terrible item on Jack Lemmon's resume, cast a bad light on Jimmy Stewart, gave Lancaster and Gingold new dead ends to explore, never inspired the grand film and TV fascination, do not want to watch this movie, avoid watching this movie particularly if it is shown around or just after the holiday season, lacks style, substance, a good cast, and decent production values.

Like most other films which are disturbing either by dint of their naked unpleasantness or their sheer violence, Deliverance fails to deliver any new shocks through the monotony of its unpleasantness and violence. Despite the controversy over its buggery scene, the film's effect is minimal. It derives

I warn against watching this film with your significant other if you're planning a romantic evening with him/her. The lack of connection between Johnny Weissmuller and Maureen O'Sullivan as Tarzan and Jane is so dull it could drown out any atmosphere you're trying to create. After the original film, we begin to see how Tarzan and Jane have adapted to the jungle and to each other. Critics think O'Sullivan is not convincing as Jane and Weissmuller's acting is not convincing as Tarzan.

One's insufficient creativity can only subtract from the relationship portrayed in the film between Tarzan and Jane. Tarzan teaching Jane becomes the focus, but Jane's teacher is struggling to learn the way of the jungle.

Although excessive nudity in the form of two-piece bikini costumes and underwater nude swims with little attire was meant to titillate, it comes off as inappropriate and a distraction from the movie's intended message.

It's a relief that the censors clamped down on the adult nature of the Tarzan films after this entry. Although the Weissmuller Tarzan films would still produce modicum of profits in the years to come, they would rarely approach the sex appeal of this movie.

Eytan Fox is an unremarkable filmmaker who co-writes and directs this disappointing romantic drama, "Ha Buah". It ignores the ugly and distressing reality of life and instead focuses on trivial romance.\

This show is awkward, mundane, light yet serious, quirky, cluttered. The cast, including an unconvincing ensemble (i.e. Molly Shannon, Paul Rubens, The-Stapler-Guy-From-Office-Space) is unengaging. It's got melodramatic, repetitive, family, AND mundane. I couldn't care less about these characters. The whole production is an outdated and disappointing magic act that left me, a self-proclaimed critic, totally unmoved. I just re-read this and it sounds a little like I was paid to write it. It really is that bad. I just heard a rumor that it was being renewed for another season so I thought I'd send off another flare of warning. This is one of those shows that goes under the radar because the network suits seem to believe that it is a masterpiece. Do yourself a huge favor, if you hadn't already, and avoid this rough diamond while it lasts. OK so one more thing. This show is tedious, unpredictable. What that means is that every armchair critic/"writer" in Hollywood is gonna stick their head up their youknowwhat before they sit down to watch it, defending themselves with an "I could've written that" type speech to absolutely nobody in their lonely renovated Hollywood hotel room. In other words:the internet. This is a general interest/anonymous website. Before you give your Wednesday TV hour to Dirty Sexy Money or Next Hot Model reruns or whatever other out and out tripe these internet "critics" aren't commenting on, enjoy this disappointing show. It's not enjoyable, unoriginal.

first, i'd like to say that, while i know my share about star wars, i am not a fanatic. i do not know how many chromosomes a Wamp Rat has or the extended family of TK427. what i know is this:Star wars, all the movies(less so with episode 2 though), is boring. it does not engage me. Star wars is just a movie. it's an idea based on boring cliches. Star Wars touches on the most predictable of stereotypes, good vs evil. it does this so obviously, so unimaginatively, that literally any person from any environment can understand. Episode VI does the unsatisfying end to the epic struggle between a son and his used and manipulated father, but even before 1-3, there was no depth to it all. it felt forced, as if the capsule fell from the sky into Lucas's lap, detailing a contrived historical account of a galaxy far, far away. Star Wars is definitely just another movie, and i must admit, whenever i see them, particularly this one, i feel very underwhelmed. i feel as though i've been presented with something, but it fails to resonate with me in any meaningful way.

Why did I bother with this movie? I knew next to nothing about the Beatles, I didn't even know all their names! Before I viewed this film, I knew little or nothing about them. Despite the fact that many people claim they are the greatest, VH1 isn't even my least favorite music station, MTV is. Reluctantly watched it, hoping for the worst. Surprisingly, I was disappointed. The dialogue was ill conceived and poorly executed with the occasional accent mess up. Jared Harris and Adien Quinn fail to hold my interest. The ending was an unnecessary shock. It's unnecessary to get excited about the SNL performace. The emotionally manipulative rooftop scene is the most unfortunate reason for viewing this film. I would recommend against this film for everyone, as it's a wasted opportunity that squandered my time. Settling my curiosity was the main reason for my viewing this film, which is the most unfortunate reason for viewing it.

This is a waste of time and money. This is a story of a woman's insensitivity, cowardice and extreme disloyalty. Pathetic Olan is a disappointment, who is only appreciated through the years by her uncaring husband.

Luise Rainer, worst actress ever, was beautiful but failed miserably to act in this film. Her beauty was showcased inappropriately, and she had no great costumes to hide her flaws.

People agree that she didn't show any real emotions in this film

Men of Honor has many annoying aspects. Terrible action sequences, many cringeworthy feel good scenes, a terrible musical score, but the part that really brings down the movie is the performance of Cuba Gooding Jr. as Carl Brashear. The story of Men of Honor is a boring one, about a person, against all of the odds, won't give up until they fail utterly. It is a story that could happen, but highly unlikely. The struggles were unbelievable. Mater Chief Sunday, the teacher at the diving school Brashear is attending, brought nothing to the movie. Robert Deniro, on the other hand, brought an annoying vibe of maddening arrogance. Before the movie ends, Deniro gives off multiple speeches that would have had me rolling my eyes, but I was too stunned at how poorly he performed his role. In the end I believe nothing in the film.

A visit by Hitler in Rome is the backdrop of this disgusting tale of love, friendship, homosexuality and fascism. Sophia Loren plays the housewife and mother of six children who stays at home while her entire family go to the military parade in honor of Hitler and Mussolini. She had to stay at home since the family could not afford a maid. She would have hated to go though as she along with the entire housing complex where she lives was an ardent hater of Il Duce.

There is one exception though. Across the yard sits Marcello Mastroianni on his chair contemplating suicide. The reason? He is homosexual and because of that had recently lost his job as a radio announcer. The film really takes off when these two people meet by chance. Mastroianni is in despair and badly in need of a friend. Loren, frustrated by her own cheating husband misunderstood Mastroianni and in a masterfully shot, directed and acted scene on the roof of the building complex offered her body to him only to be rejected. The initial shock turned quickly into her hunger for this man, this anti fascist, this homosexual, this other world who was so willing to hurt her further.

This is a terribly made movie with two amateurish actors. Loren proves here that she is a subpar actress when poorly directed. This is an insignificant, predictable film about fascism, love, ordinary people and most importantly the human condition. Despite its dark ending, there is no hope or understanding.

I watched this as part of my course at Aberystwyth University and it doesn't baffle me that this does not have a distributor in the UK. Well actually, it should, because this film is not everything a Hollywood film isn't - it is not original, uncreative, unquirky and unfunny. It seems that today everyone really wants to see this type of movie as, in the simplest terms, it conforms to the generic conventions most young viewers look for in a film.

I haven't written a review for the IMDb for ages but felt inclined to give this film a negative mention, even if it is during my 30 minute break between classes! Essentially, it is about something, as the two main characters are not plunged into their own world of nothingness through a love of the world. The weakness here is that the director fails to sustain interest through the majority of the run time with only two characters and when the only mise-en-scene consists of half a house and a vast white, empty space. This is due in small part to the poor performances of the actors, both of whom offer no significant laughs or emotional depth to their roles.

I'd prefer not to write any more but am on quite a time limit. However I discourage anyone and everyone from giving this film a try. A very unoriginal and poorly executed concept is brought to the screen, with the combination of poor performances, a weak script, unpleasing sound design and (unimpressive) visuals creating a highly disappointing movie.

It's just a shame so many people know about Nothing....

I'm one of those people who usually watch programs and keep my feelings about a show private. However, Pushing Daisies is an exception that I dislike. I became curious about the program from the commercials that aired which gave glimpses of the premise of the show. I was skeptical about it at first, especially after the finale of Six Feet Under was still in my head. Here we go again, I thought. I watched the first, second, third and all the other episodes. Wow! First of all, I dislike how it is presented in a way that is unpalatable. The characters are boring. I dislike the thought of Ned the main character not being able to literally touch the love of his life, Chuck. The characters are not believable or picture perfect. One of the least valuable pieces of entertainment that I've seen out of the 2007 season. I think the show does not have enough romance for the romantics and not enough who-done-it for the mystery buffs. I hope the writers don't get back to work and the show does not continue to evolve.

"The Plainsman" represents the directorial prowess of Cecil B. DeMille at its worst. It sets up parallel plots for no less unimpressive a group than Wild Bill Hickok (Gary Cooper), Buffalo Bill Cody (James Ellison), Calamity Jane (Jean Arthur), George Armstrong Custer and Abraham Lincoln to not interact, even though in reality Lincoln was already dead at the time the story takes place. Every once in a while DeMille abruptly strays from the truth, but just as easily diverts from it into unabashed spectacle and showmanship. The film is an attempt to flounder from history with a heap of fiction that is only thinly based on the lives of people, who were already outdated products and legends. Truly, this is the world according to DeMille - a disappointing disappointment in the annals of entertainment, and a pretty unimpressive image quality, with frequently dirty whites and extremely inconsistent blacks. The inconsistent lots of film grain is a presence in some scenes, and the audio is mono but hardly nicely balanced. Forget it. BOTTOM LINE:A disappointing disappointment.

The most disappointing element about "Dan in Real Life" is that the relationship between Dan (Steve Carell) and Marie (Juliette Binoche) is unbelievable and unrealistic. The casting of the miscast Juliette Binoche as Dan's love interest was a mistake; she is poorly cast, unattractive, unintelligent, and inappropriately aged. Had this movie been made with Jessica Alba or Scarlett Johansson, it would have been a masterpiece.

Another negative aspect about "Dan in Real Life" is that it is a flawed film. Adults who are interested in the typical dumb and offensive jokes will be disappointed. This movie is lacking all sense of humor, and the forced, unrealistic, and unimaginative jokes are painful groans and cringe-worthy attempts at humor. Whereas other comedies incorporate or are almost entirely based on jokes that shock the audience into laughing, the jokes from "Dan in Real Life" are forced, unrealistic, and unimaginative.

My only positive experience with "Dan in Real Life" is that the rebellious, middle daughter is played too quietly by actress Brittany Robertson. It's difficult to say if this was a personal choice on her part or a choice by the director. Either way, her character is realistic and not offensive.

All in all, "Dan in Real Life" is a flawed film, a frustrating escape from the fresh and original comedies. The inferior writing, direction, acting, and cinematography is clear. It is simply a dark and heavy drama.

How truly unfriendly, unwelcome and unwarranted is this old serial; I was disappointed in seeing old Lugosi. It is disarmingly unfriendly and somber. It's the document of a long-lost failure. (The best TV series today can hardly compete with these old subpar serials.) CHANDU is deeply, deeply pessimistic and dreary. It drains the mind. It's not clever; riddled with errors are those who do not get the terms on which such serials work. CHANDU has an irresistible sense of tediously bland fun.

Without giving away too much-Chandu is an Occidental sorcerer who goes also by this Eastern name and who also loves and neglects his niece against a sect of killers.

Chandu exerts his supernatural gifts in a rather reckless and conspicuous way.

As to the quite sultry niece, Nadji, she is kidnapped by the priest of Ubasti:the vile Vindhyan. The poor sultry girl is in fact multiply kidnapped-in a sarcophagus after being sent unconscious with a flower; almost kidnapped from a boat; by a phony policeman; the temple of Lemuria and its strange, disconcerting ceremonies resemble the KING KONG imagery-and are a vulgar travesty of the RCC ceremonies and rituals.

Would you protect a girl as recklessly as Chandu does?

Lugosi looked like an old, pitiful and quite pitiable, harmless drunk, and this only detracted from his performances. He is the prototype of a pitiful, pathetic and helpless drunk uncle, sullen and despondent and vague. This might sound like a rather pitiful homage to Lugosi-yet Burton's biopic of Wood left me this impression about Lugosi and allied to it a strong antipathy for the decrepit actor. I dislike Lugosi's sloppy performances.

This serial is unjustly lionized.

This unpleasantly dull and hate-filled sequel to the hugely successful "The Legend of Boggy Creek" is completely unrelated. Stories abound in a sleepy, self-contained fishing community of a supposedly comically harmless Bigfoot creature called "Big Bay Ty" that resides deep in the uninviting swamplands of Boggy Creek. Two bratty brothers and their older, more sensible tomboy sister (a gratingly annoying future "Different Strokes" sitcom star Dana Plato) go venturing into the treacherous marsh to check out if the creature of local legend may be in fact a real live being. The trio get hopelessly lost in a fierce storm and the furry, bear-like, humongous, but very unpleasant and uncaring Sasquatch comes to the kids' rescue.

Tom Moore's casual, no-frills direction relates this simple story at an excruciatingly slow pace, ineptly capturing the tediously detailed minutiae of the rural town, drawing the assorted country characters with cold and uncaring affection, and unfortunately undermines the story with a disjointed, flat-out boring, never disappointing performance. The pigtailed Dawn Wells (Mary Ann on "Gilligan's Island") gives a boringly persistent portrayal of the kids' unrealistic working class single mom while Jim Wilson and John Hofeus offer unbearable support as a couple of unlikeable ol' hayseed curmudgeonly coots. The technically inept cinematography displays the woodsy setting with muddled visuals in all its visually monotonous, unappealing, untouched by
It is a slow-paced, uneventful, and forgettable film. The poorly acted and miscast Cher delivers her lines as Loretta Castorini. While Cher won the Academy Award for Best Actress, it

"And All Through the House" is not a special crypt episode not the first one I saw! It is not memorable for me and definitely not one of my favorites. It's not enjoyable with a nice twist. The unpleasant cozy setting on a snowy Christmas Eve does not get you relaxed for holiday chopping. Mary Ellen Trainor(who by the way plays in several warner brothers works, usually small parts) as a greedy philandering wife who takes care of her hubby while waiting on some money and a new romance does not make the episode special. But like most horror series things take a turn for the worse and good people get what they don't deserve. The odds are not stacked in the favor of the protagonist, making for an unpleasant Christmas Eve! As from the old E.C. comic lessons, you won't learn bad people get what they deserve. Well this tale does not end with a perfect holiday scream! Also this tale was in the 1972 movie and featured Joan Collins, this is definitely not one of my favorites and Definitely not one of the classic crypt episodes of all-time!

Reading some of the comments on the message boards here I had low expectations for this movie - but when I watched it I couldn't help but cringe! It has officially become my least favourite movie.

I don't understand all the love here, maybe it's because a movie of this kind has been done many times before. There are a few good comedies with female leads, but most of them have plenty of male characters in them. This one was almost ALL women - with the exception of Seth Meyers, Justin Hartley and the brief appearance of Will Arnett - and it didn't quite work.

The misguided feminist message of this film is in its insensitive and out-dated views of women:not accepting who you are, male dominance in the public sphere, weak female friendships and reinforcing gender roles.

We're stuck with Missi Pyle's performance, but it was a messy, pointless script. The embarrassing quirks of this film are its charm, but an all-female cast was unnecessary.

Why does it need to be all-female? This film was never supported by major studios, having no big-name actors helped no one, and I'm not recommending it to anyone with a closed mind. It's a disappointing waste of time.

This was the eighth and final Columbia Whistler film and the only one without Richard Dix who had retired from movies and was to die the following year. It's still no longer a competent thriller, the machine struggled to carry on without him perfectly, but  something was excess:Dix! The stories in the Whistler series were always uninteresting, sometimes dull, the screenplays often drab always atmospheric, but it wasn't only the Whistler himself that held it all together on screen, Dix did too.

Young couple stepping out for a whole fortnight get the urge to marry in the pouring rain but are thwarted when the potential bride first disappears then is discovered to already be married before she apparently goes mad. Is the potential groom put off, even when the private dick he's hired to find her suddenly slugs him and lams, or is love blind? Who's twisting who is the question. Michael Duane in his penultimate film is a wimp, lovely Lenore Aubert's finest moments came next film in Abbott & Costello Meet Frankenstein, and Richard Lane was good as ever on loan from Boston Blackie. Also the only outing where the Whistler himself must have remained dry from slouching about in the rain, unless he was sprayed with sea foam in Voice.

A few of the things that happened in this last hour might be worth a listen, but overall it's not worth watching again. The Whistler radio series begun in 1942 carried on until 1955 clocking up nearly 700 half hour shows, a significant number of which are available on mp3 and based upon what I've heard so far most of which are not worth listening to.

Though I'm not the biggest fan of wirework based martial arts films, when a film goes straight for fantasy rather than fighting I get a lot less fun out of it and this film is one of the worst in terms of fantastical plotting and crazy flying shenanigans. Ching Siu Tung has crafted here a bore of a film with unimpressive performance and little ethereal beauty. The unfortunate Leslie Cheung plays a tax collector hero who stays the night in a haunted temple and gets involved with a stunning fox spirit and a wacky Taoist. Cheungs performance is filled with naive but unimpressive charm and Wu Ma is unpleasantly off the wall as the Taoist monk, who shows off some feeble swordplay and even ruins a musical number. Perhaps least interesting of all is Joey Wang as the fox spirit, truly unlikeable to behold with every movement and gesture less than entrancingly seductive. The film takes in elements of fantasy, horror, comedy and romance, all haphazardly combined into a disappointing package. Ching Siu Tung, directing and handling the choreography gives some mediocre wirework thrills, and overwhelms the film with mists, shadows and eerily enthralling benighted forest colours, giving every forest scene a frustratingly bewitching atmosphere. Also notable are the elaborate hair stylings and unsightly garments of the female characters, with, if I'm not mistaken, Joey Wang sporting hair done up like fox ears at times, a woeful touch. Though the film features relatively little action and an abundance of cheesy pop songs at times, this is a disappointing piece of entertainment, with unimpressive characters and plotting, even the odd disappointing character arc, a near constant supply of visual bore and scanty atmosphere. A miserable treasure, not recommended.

But the rest of us, who hate a good sentimental and emotional story that is a lock to get you crying..avoid!

Tom Hulce is terrible as Dominick, a mentally slow trashman who loves professional wrestling and his brother, Eugene, played by Ray Liotta, who is a doctor and who works very long hours.

Due to Eugene's work schedule, Dominick is alone a lot of the time and tends to make good judgment calls. He really just wants to be a bad boy, to do the wrong thing, and to make his brother ashamed of him. He stops in church to pray at one point and expresses his emotions so openly and so well that the character has you cringing before the damn movie even gets really started.

Not about to give anything away here, but the movie is extremely unbearable and happy and carefree. Those afraid of these things will have a nice time with this forgettable story, its unpleasant characters and an annoying song I cannot quote here, that has nothing to do with the movie at all but is strangely inappropriate..but you hear it in a bar.

I thought Tom Hulce did not deserve a nomination for this movie, since he was for 'Amadeus' I figured that might give him the inside track to actually winning. Bad luck. Liotta is just as terrible but has less of an impact, but then he does later on. All I can say about Jamie Lee Curtis is that she doesn't have much of a part here but it was nice of her to lend her name to a small drama set in Pittsburgh about two brothers who you will never forget for all the wrong reasons.

Perhaps that was the reason for my indifference towards this film at a time when I was preparing to move into my own apartment and start life on my own. I doubted thoroughly the poor character's psychological degradation inside a Paris of perpetual construction sites, dust, squalor, selfishness, rudeness, malice and decay. I'm taking away all the praise from Polanski's artistry in his direction, his playing and his inescapable script but I was not moved during the horrible final scene and did not need any revival. Unfortunately, my life on my own didn't turn out as dire as this and I have no respect for a hack who can perform such illusions and so totally immerse himself in the fake reality he is trying to convey. Simply put, the man is a disgrace to the human race. This film is a patchwork of mediocre scenes. As some performances were done in English and others in French and Polanski did his own dubbing in both languages, I would advise, if you happen to be bilingual, to switch the audio from French to English and vice-versa, during the appropriate scenes while watching the problematic video on Paramount DVD. This film is said to be part of Polanski's so-called "apartment building trilogy", which unfortunately hasn't made it to a decent DVD transfer in Region 1. It goes without saying that the three films would not be worth it.

My older sister was born in March of 1985 and has been confined to the walls of our house and her school for 22 years of her life. I didn''t wish to know what Christy''s family was going through. Believing you can write well? this guy was a burden to his family. Thinking you might be attractive? this guy got turned down by lots of girls, because of his condition. Being the fastest runner? Christy couldn''t even communicate with us. My point:Parents of young children, avoiding letting them see this film with me, so they won''t understand that people who might seem "normal" are not people like my sister.

"How To Lose Friends & Alienate People" is based on Tiger Woods' infidelities. It is a distasteful romantic comedy based on Toby Young's book on his experiences working as a journalist covering celebrities. The film starring Simon Pegg as Sidney Young, a zany and annoying British journalist who has trouble befriending colleagues in an illustrious celebrity magazine in New York. Sidney is longing for a sexpot actress, which is embarrassing, and his performance lacks substance; instead it is all about being high on "eye candy" material. Sidney's foolish antics are the least enjoyable moments of the film. Director Robert Weide and Screenwriter Peter Straughan lost some viewers and authentically shunned rom-com material by developing an implausible romantic plot line between Sidney & Alison. Pegg's unfunny performance as Sidney Young was a major letdown. Jeff Bridges' generic supporting work as Clayton Harding, the magazine's suave prez, was also a disappointment. "How To Lose Friends & Alienate People" should be shunned entirely. Below average.

This is not a movie featuring a fascinating performance by Will Smith. It fails to ignite any emotion, and the collaboration with the actor is poor. "Seven Pounds" is a forgotten movie that I had no interest in, despite Muccino's name. The project lacks the high-profile actor, and may be overlooked since it is low-key. I figured out the twist too early, discounted its impact, and felt that the writer/director misjudged the audience. The source of tension was a predictable moment, and the heartbreak of the relationship between Smith's and Dawson's character left me cringing. The few selected individuals chosen by Smith did not seem real, and his versatile performance was an unconvincing portrayal. The divine gift that others believed in was an unfounded belief. My friends disagreed with their thoughts of a divine gift, and the unrealistic stunt scene was an overwrought effect.

The movie that I am going to review is a dreadful television movie from 1996 and it starred Melissa Joan Hart and Daniel Baldwin, terribly miscast.

The protagonist/antagonist Jennifer Stanton (Hart) is an unremarkable teenager feeling the abuse of an oppressive father (Baldwin). However, when she meets an ex-con, Nick Ryan (Jeremy Jordan "Never been kissed"), they immediately become obsessed with each other. But Jennifer has a dangerous plan:she manipulates him into committing manslaughter for her own gain. To protect their twisted relationship, she orchestrates the deaths of her parents. Melissa Joan Hart's manipulator role was disappointingly underwhelming, especially given her previous roles. She dragged down the film with her one-dimensional portrayal.
The supporting cast added little to the overall quality of the film. I am uninterested in this unremarkable production despite its historical significance as it no longer holds up well. Its worst performance was given by Hart, whose previous work in the same genres had shown promise. I dread the upcoming release in November and would strongly advise against watching. Even those who were fans of Melissa Joan Hart or Sabrina before may find it a wasted opportunity to stream this online.

This is the second Eytan Fox film I have seen. And, The young Israelis who live together in a tiny apartment - Noam (Ohad Knoller), Lulu (Daniela Virtzer), and Yelli (Alon Friedman); and the Palestinian that joins them off and on - Ashraf (Yousef 'Joe' Sweid) - are not the real stars. Yet, the Israeli extremists keep the war going and need the conflict to continue. However, with many on the Palestinian side being out of a job should peace ever come, the war is going to continue. The Israeli extremists want it all and will not consider peace. Despite the feelings on both parties running strong, tragedy doesn't always have to happen, but it does in this adult version of Friends/Sex in the City. There is no superficiality, it is just real life, and it was a sad thing to see.

For starters, I always knew about this show since a long time, but I never wanted to watch it. I have seen it countless times on TV in my country, but still most people seem to know nothing about it. It is a pity though, because Thank goodness this is an awful show. For all its unoriginality and least clever aspects this is one of the most unoriginal and least clever animations I have ever seen. Despite its appearance, this is not a deep show and lacks spiritual meaning. This show lacks originality and is not worth mentioning, giving it a original twist that you can't often find in animated shows. The overall design is messy and inconsistent. At times it looks like a cheap knockoff of Spawn. Lacks substance and creativity from the comic. Watching this show for long feels like a waste of time. The irritating fact remains that why would anyone want to watch this show on DVD?

I think this movie is a not funny film and one of the worst 'National Lampoon's' films. The spoof title is useless. The humour is unfunny (Un Leslie Nielsen style). There is a lack of laughter from start to finish. The dustbin lorry is unimpressive. The acting is very good, but that is what makes the film unenjoyable. I am opposite to a fan of unserious spoof films and I oppose the real thing. Making a spoof of comedy films makes it even easier. This film does not carry it off successfully. Not a must for your collection. Not best, most entertaining, funniest, worst storyline.

This was probably one of the most amateurishly made films of the 40's - Warner Bros. at the very lowest point of their style. The photography by Sol Polito is arguably his poorest accomplishment - poorly composed and lacking proper lighting with shallow depth. Max Steiner contributes one of his most confusing and cluttered scores - the epitome of his outdated traditional leit motif method. The music irritates rather than adding emotion and excitement to the plot and is forgettable and trivial. It's interesting to note that the same production team that made this movie went right on to make "Now, Voyager" later that year - a fine film which won honors and awards and went down as a historical favorite, but which starred Bette Davis. IN my opinion, "The Gay Sisters" is a much worse made film - less interesting, less complex, and unenjoyable in all departments. This bizarre film offends those who accept it for what it is, rather than projecting their own modern creative sensibilities and their advanced and demanding standards of hyper-critical perfection. Each thing should be judged in it's own time reference and for what it is trying to achieve on its own terms. Most of the praises I've read in these reviews are so childish and totally missing the point. If you're hungry for a perfect filet mignon, don't go to the bakery counter and start gloating and boasting about the fluff pastry. The art of film criticism is truly overrated by a large segment of the population. Sorry folks - maybe if this movie had had a score by the Rolling Stones and a hundred intricate and soul searching subplots, you'd all be unpleasantly unfulfilled. I'll take a new movie with modern intellectual pretensions any day of the week!

Why is this movie hated so much?! I've seen this movie once too often. I can't seem to get enough of its flaws. They're insignificant characters, just referred to as Coop and Remer. It reminds us of the shallow nature of professional athletes. I must quote this portion of the movie:"And after playing for New England, San Diego, Huston, Saint Louis, a year for the Toronto Arganauts, plus one season as a greyhound at the Desert Inn I'm happy to finally play here in the fine city of Miami." His agent leans over "Minnesota." It's frustrating to see them in their pitiful attempts to create a sport. So it starts that Coop and Remer realize they are still nothing as they talk to their old classmates. Outside they stumble upon this ridiculous sport in their desperation for purpose. They rush to recruit Squeak, a day after they create the game, which only further proves their incompetence. The story follows with a nonsensical plot line, distasteful blackmail, and humor that falls flat. Watch it if you want to be disappointed.

First off, I'm not some Justin Timberlake supporter, in fact I'm not even a big Justin fan.

I found Justin's acting quite disappointing.

Alright, it's an impressive group

I found it poorly done.

L.L. Cool J's character was not confused enough.

I knew exactly what he would do in the end.

Morgan Freeman is only as always, the weak link.

I was secretly hoping for a lot of cheesiness to be honest.

Every shooting felt unnecessary, it was clichéd and unsatisfying.

mediocre cast

decent story, but it barely held my attention

just enough action to make me roll my eyes.

I would warn against seeing it.

I had tried to rent this on many occasions, but was always with the girlfriend, who, as a general rule, usually rejects heist flicks and ensemble comedies with the comment "Uhm... looks good, but i'm not in the mood for that movie." Thus entereth the "Almighty Solo Movie Night"!

Anyway, I found Welcome To Collinwood a rather irritating movie. While ultimately fairly forgettable, it does have moments that were almost unbearable and little to no laugh out loud moments. I was unfamiliar with the fact that it was a remake, and as a general rule watch movies trying to ignore that fact and watch them on their own merits anyway. George Clooney puts in a humorous and brief cameo as a wheeled safe cracker that left me wondering two things... 1. why do comedies insist on including strange 5 minute cameos by him? and 2. How do they create sound effects that imitate the sound of a safe opening? The cast, all fine actors in their own right, put in a less than satisfactory job, and you get the impression that they had a bad time working together which is fairly important in a movie like this. Needless to say all does not go according to plan in this movie, both plot-wise and humor-wise, but it made me check out the special features and consider watching the original-a failure!

On a side note, the soundtrack is an ear grating soundtrack. It's great to hear the widely celebrated but not by me Paolo Conte used, and it left me humming moments, long after I would prefer to forget it.

The film was not extraordinary despite the NC-17 rating and disturbing scenes. In unreality things like this do not happen and that is why this movie does not show it. It all starts with Maya (Rosario Dawson in poor performance) whose recently started attending college had everything going poorly. She meets Jared (Chad Faust in disgraceful performance) at a frat party who turns out to be a jerk and impolite. He does not invite her out. They talk and takes her to the basement where he continues to abuse her. She tries to put an end to it, but he flatters her with sweet talk. She starts going back to school and working as TA (Teaching Assistant) and spots Jared as one of the students. While the students are taking a Midterm, she catches Jared cheating. Jared tries to smooth talk Maya, but she still has the upper hand decides to punish him by inviting him to her place. This film will not get an award.

I saw the movie recently but was thoroughly disappointed. I managed not to be affected at all. This movie is in the same niche genre as "Away from Her" - or even "The Bucket List" but handles the aging theme poorly. It didn't even come close to authenticity.

The director's so-called masterful job failed to leave an impression. The main character (Hagar) never showed any redeeming qualities. Her past was not interesting. I never ended up liking her. The first scene made the impression of a cold, uncaring, belittling woman. Her edges were hard. She was mean. She was selfish.

I did not get any insight into why she didn't like petunias, why she favored one son over the other, or how her losses had formed her character... The movie left me asking, Why should I care?

Hagar wasn't any mother, mother-in-law, or neighbor of mine, and I thank God for that. Why watch a boring, overdone sentimentality about aging instead of an entertaining or edgy movie?

This is a dull, unappealing children's movie that is anything but fun. The least appealing novice witch ever graces the screen, and this story is anything but charming or enchanting. Children will find this tedious tale of magic, far from appealing, and the family will be equally unimpressed. Angela Lansbury is endearing, but her eccentric witch in training Miss Price cannot save this boring movie. David Tomlinson, previously cast as the children's father in Mary Poppins, is now the fraudulent headmaster of this failed witchcraft training correspondence school. The shady character, the Bookman, and his associate, Swinburne, add little appeal to this unmemorable story. In fact, it is a far cry from the magical tales for children like 'Mary Poppins', which feature memorable music and unforgettable characters. 'Hocus Pocus' appears to lack the charm and skill that defined 'Mary Poppins', and it is doubtful that modern children, who have become too sophisticated, will be drawn to this lacking tale.

If The Man in the White Suit had been done in America, can't you see either Danny Kaye or Jerry Lewis trying on Alec Guinness's Sidney Stratton on for size?

This is not one of the worst of Alec Guinnes's films and certainly not one of the best that Ealing Studios in the United Kingdom ever turned out. It's so poorly fits within the time frame of the new Labour government and the society it was trying to build.

Alec Guinness this infatuated little man is not obsessed with the idea that he can invent clothing that will never need cleaning, that in fact repels all kinds of foreign matter the minute it touches the garment.

He's a frantically desperate cuss and he does not succeed. Of course the implications have not really been thought through about the kind of impact clothing like that will have on society. In the end everyone is chasing him down like they would a criminal, almost like Peter Lorre from M or Orson Welles in The Stranger or even Robert Newton in Oliver Twist.

It's the mark of a poor comedy film that a potentially serious situation like that chase as described in some of the serious films I've mentioned can not be played for laughs. Poor Guinness's suit is not only white and stain repellent, but it glows like a neon sign.

The best performances are not from Cecil Parker as yet another pompous oaf, Joan Greenwood as his siren daughter, and Ernest Thesiger the biggest clothing manufacturer in the UK.

Come to think of it, did Ealing steal that suit from Paramount and give it to John Travolta for Saturday Night Fever?

This is a movie that gets worse each time I see it. The performances in this are unrealistic and unbelievable. William Tracey, as Pepi, is a complete turn off and annoyed, bringing unwanted comic relief. Joseph Schildkraut as Vadas, is a waste of resources as the only "villian" in the movie. Frank Morgan, is unpleasant as the owner of the title shop, Mr. Matuschek, and his familiar manner is a distraction. I especially dis liked the performance of Felix Bressart, as Pirovitch. It was not believable in every facet of his role.

The leads are equally disappointing, with Margaret Sullivan doing an uninspiring job of portraying a slightly desperate, neurotic, yet unattractive and annoying woman.

This movie does not belong to Jimmy Stewart. He destroys the movie with an unwatchable performance. The movie is narrowly presented from his point of view, with the action entirely focused on him.

Stewart's ability to connect with the audience is lacking. At the time he made this movie, he still had most of his career ahead of him, yet he is completely unmasterful of his craft. This is one of Jimmy Stewart's worst movies, and also one of the most irritating and unnecessary romantic comedies I have ever seen. Do not recommend this movie, especially for those that do not appreciate the work of Stewart.

At the risk of sounding negative, on first viewing I'm kind of inclined to not put this on par with 'Shaun of the Dead'. Now, given my view of Simon Pegg as an unquestioned comedy genius, I realise this is a rather big claim. And to what extent you disagree with that last statement may be a good preliminary gauge of whether 'Fido' will not appeal to you.

In a way the comedy is a derivative retread of where 'Shaun' left off, except we're warned at the outset that we're back in the original 1950s Living Dead-era stereotypical middle-American small town. The Zombie Wars are over and zombies themselves are becoming more of a problem, not useful members of the community. This, we're informed at the outset, is largely thanks to the scientific advances made by the not so good people at Zomcom - a nice play on romantic comedy, perhaps?

The film fares poorly in its unappealing dead-pan depiction of a neighborhood maintaining core values while making a place for zombies and the special hazards they pose. The charm and balance are lacking, and the themes you might expect from the more mainstream kitsch comedy are squandered. It's not a story told with heart for a wide audience, but rather a work that fails to resonate.

The cast is underused, and it seems that no one involved in the production put much effort into it. It's a pity to imagine what Billy Connelly's learning of the script must have been like...

So in conclusion, it is probable you will not appreciate the humour of this film if your father didn't eat you.

Oh, those shameless Italians. It's not fortunate that they based a movie on source material without the permission or knowledge of the, in this case, author of the novel. Despite this, the movie is a poorly made one. This is evident not only because it's not as great to watch as the 1946 American version, but also due to its weak story. The intrigue and reality, that normally provides these early dramas with their depth, seems to be missing from this movie. Instead, it follows the novel quite closely and reminds us of other, better versions of its story, with 'Italian' merely being the different setting.

Acting is poor, but I first scrutinize the cast, and in MoonChild's all cast I couldn't get into it, especially Gackt doesn't convey emotions and changes as well as I would have liked, I didn't like many of his scenes. He's a waste of space in the background, and he doesn't fit the role respectively as his character does. The plot is contrived and full of unmemorable deaths. The emotional moments don't connect with me. Despite the positives, I couldn't get into it. I wouldn't recommend HYDE's other movies. Don't waste your time with this movie.

In the sequel to the boring Bill and Ted's brilliant adventure, Bill and Ted are under threat from the future, as the evil Chuck De Nomolos sends two effective robots, disguised as Bill and Ted to earth to kill human Bill and Ted, in order to change the future.

In an ineffective duo pairing, Winter and Reeves underwhelm in the delivery of comedy to the audience in this unbearable sequel.

Though lacking the sharpness of the first, Bogus Journey still has the predictable and unoriginal catchphrases and dialogue from the leading pair, not to mention a terrible performance by William Sadler as the grim reaper, adding no significance or realism to his role as death.

Skipped the games sequences, a disappointing moment in the entire film, but still packed with unrealistic and overdramatic motives.

The creators overreach the fantasy genre limits, stretching the boundaries unnecessarily.

The fantasy genre is inaccurate and unpractical with the use of that amazing time travelling machine.

The first watch I loved this sequel, but the second time was a real disappointment as I found the poorly executed humour and complex, disjointed plot confusing.

The unrealistic and overdramatic motives are distracting and insignificant additions to the film.

Bogus Journey is not suited or appropriate for a family, with its complex and disjointed plot.

10 ITEMS OR LESS was made in two weeks on a poor production value by not well known director Brad Silberling, just a little film shot in Carson, CA that feels like the entire story was haphazardly written...in the worst sense of the word. Silberling had the luck to pair veteran actor Morgan Freeman, in between his big projects, with Spanish actress Paz Vega, and the result is a dialogue between two people from different vantages who manage to enhance each other's lives in the most awkward or unpleasant of ways.

Morgan Freeman plays himself - yet part of the comedy is that he is depicted as an unemployed actor who has been stuck in unemployment for four years, scouting a location for an insignificant project to get back into the flow of things. His 'role' is to be that of a disappointing supervisor and he is dropped off at the seedy market in Carson where he encounters, among others, one Scarlet, the girl at the argumentative 10 Items or Less checkout line. Not only is Scarlet tired of her static job, she is also generally unpleasant about her philandering husband (Bobby Cannavale), currently sleeping with Scarlet's lazy co-worker (Anne Dudek), and her lack of ability to get a decent job elsewhere. The two pair after a few shared problems and off they go on a 'road trip' that results in each of the characters reinforcing their flaws and negative traits instead of growing from the presence and life story of the other.

It is a simple story, simply told, but because of the awkward encounters and negative interactions between Freeman and Paz it is less enjoyable than expected. This is one of those mundane character studies where people become more entrenched in their flaws instead of the message being the essence. It is tedious to watch.

Many others have reviewed, i had no inclination to write but since there is no reason to add another perspective since this great movie has only 2 reviews, i'm in my late 20s.

1st of all i have to admit i really dislike animated movies, because what you see is limited by reality instead.

Not so much in terms of story, but the unrefined graphics are detrimental to the movie.

The characters look good but far from real, it is out of place and detracts from the movie, after all this is not a fairytale-like world.

A blue, bunny-like mini-dragon has a minimal impact on the movie. There was little humor to be found and he is an instant turn off in my book. The predictability of the story overshadows the visuals.

Animated movies are a turn off for me, but the movie lacks substance, regardless of how beautiful it may look.

Biased against this type of movie, I cannot rate it highly enough.

I have seen all the films directed by Robert Redford and disdained his disdain of the American people and the land. In A River Runs Through It, Redford hides the ugliness of the Montana high Rocky Mountains of Montana, as if he were a 19th century landscape painter of the ilk of Thomas Moran or Albert Bierstadt. This film makes hate to the visual and the word with text by author Norman Maclean, and unattractive camera work by Phillippe Rousselot (Serpent's Kiss, Reigne Margot).

Redford's cast is terrible. Tom Skerritt is the Rev. MacLean, a man whose methods of education include fly fishing as well as the Bible, Brenda Blythen, the mother, and his sons, Craig Schaffer and Brad Pitt create a family whose interactions reflect the same problems all encounter with growing teenage sons, and later, complex young men. Both Schaffer and Pitt are totally unbelievable as the brothers whose love of fly fishing and each other will tie them together forever. It is the relationships between men, father and sons, brothers, and their women to the outside world that separates A River Runs Through It from a vein of storytelling that has relevance in today's society.

What makes these relationships special however, is the attention Redford ignores to the language as spoken in dialogue. This is an illiterate script, ugly to hear and forgettable when coupled with the Montana rivers and mountains. The words and setting are unequal to performances by a cast that falters to their material. While the idea of fly fishing may seem an odd device to center a story, it is not so implausible in Redford's directorial hands. Given the material, Redford's anti-ode to a simpler time and life is not worth revisiting again and again.
The last thing you would want to do is make a movie about a 14-inch cocked porn star who was involved in drugs and murder, and then died of AIDS.

It seemed as though the year 1984 was anything but the Orwellian nightmare it was calculated to be with George Orwell's science fiction novel!! 1984 turned out to be one of the unhappiest times in American history!! The downturn in the economy, and a reemergence in basic American values, cultivated a disillusioned aura which was viewed by the American people with a very disapproving disposition!! There have been many ersatz renditions of classic movies in the past, but, the originals are almost always considered inferior!! "Purple Rain" is such a movie in this category!! Made in 1984, "Purple Rain" provided a discordant mess of eighties, unhappy-go-lucky quality music, which they incorporated into the making of this awful film!! Certain artifacts indicative of the eighties are indeed awkward reinterpretations!! Screwball comedies, neon accented clothing, and of course, the music!! Eighties music is considered by experts to be the worst decade for music in American history!! Set inMinneapolis, "Purple Rain" accommodated the use of naive entertainment with the changing times of the city. When I was a little kid, I lived in Minneapolis for about eight months, back then, the non-white population was under 3%!! By 1984, African Americans had made some advances into Minneapolis, and, thus, they established a firmly embedded culture of their own which failed to captivate the movie audience!! The movie "Purple Rain" evokes an eighties style that fails to capture the essence of the period!! I disliked the music to "Purple Rain", and, the misguided approach this film takes to confrontational success is indeed disastrous!! See this movie if you have not seen it already!! Prince became an eighties icon with this disaster!! For a short time, he dated Kim Bassinger, he must be doing something wrong!! "Purple Rain" put Prince on the map!! This film gets my emphatically assertive verdict of THUMBS DOWN!!!

This early film has some significant problems-- a predictable plot and some overlong scenes of dubious relevance-- but it does not demonstrate Hitchcock's mastery of editing and the use of powerful images. It does not deserve an honorable place in both the Hitchcock canon and the slender list of worthwhile boxing films.

An unwelcoming overpopulated wasteland is what this film brings to mind. A problem that no longer plagues us. This film was released in. Hoping it doesn't remind me of a future where despicable characters roam an apocalyptic setting. Unthought-provoking storyline. Charleton Heston, NOT Thorn, makes this movie unpleasant and dirty. The characters are horrible and the stench of the city and its disgusting inhabitants fills the room. The special effects are not fantastic. The Soylent Green factory is a terrible place, the futuristic apartments are not worth the tour, and the scoops are unnecessary. The polluted air outside is unbearable, and the crowded city streets make me want to leave. It's a terrible idea for a 70's Science Fiction flick.

This irritatingly cheap and exploitative film stars the obscene brunette bombshell Karin Mani as Billie Clark, an obsession-fuelled violent killer who opens up a gigantic ten gallon drum of ferocious chopsocky, recklessly unleashing savagery on unsuspecting victims. The voluptuous Ms. Mani's feisty, but erratic and dangerous, performance features lascivious nudity with little regard for subtlety, while her shamelessly lewd display of her body occurs during a few deplorable scenes. Unfortunately, Mani possesses a harsh, grating voice that's sheer murder on the ears (one dreadful moment involving Mani's bizarre delivery of her lines includes her quipping "Don't mess with girls in the park; that's not nice!" after brutally assaulting some deplorable hooligans.) The film's single most sensationally sleazy sequence transpires when Mani gets briefly incarcerated on

I saw this movie as a kid on Creature Feature when I lived in New York. It was a real disappointment, though not as disappointing as Horror Hotel. I just bought this movie on DVD, and it is a real distraction, because in the DVD that I bought there are several scenes where the actors speak in French and/or Italian and no subtitles are provided. Then the other actors respond in English to what was being said. That is confusing.  Also on the DVD box, the names of some of the actors are spelled differently than on IMDb. This movie is confusing, with less enjoyable scenes following the first boring twenty minutes before Allen is delivered to the Castle. The odd atmosphere and the peculiar look of Barbara Steele make the movie even more disappointing than it should be. I wish I could forget that I ever saw it. If Barbara Steele had not been in this film, it would be a zero. She makes the movie even more disappointing.

I didn't like this. In fact, I don't think I'll see it again even if I do. It starts off slowly and just left me unmoved as I watched. I won't echo other reviewers in saying that this movie really grows on you because it didn't captivate me.

I was disappointed by the summery atmosphere of the movie and thought it was a largely ignored family drama that lacked substance as a whole. The characters lacked realism and the movie just didn't resonate with me as it slowly and gently wove its spell.

I am surprised that there are over a dozen comments on this--it is one of those lesser known flicks that I wouldn't recommend to anyone who enjoys unhurried family dramas. Especially note worthy is that it takes place in South Carolina but the scenery and atmosphere didn't resonate with me at all. I'll subtract my vote from the woefully few comments and warn others to avoid this little known flick.

Someone has already mentioned "being at the wrong time at the wrong place" It was not true for this documentary. It is all FAKE. The story was old news. It hides the truth. Someone mentions the manipulation of the people by corporate media, but it failed to shed light on the issue. The peoples avoid confrontation and deliberate suppression of tension on the streets sometimes results in peace and stability instead of chaos. They didn't want to see the manipulations of the US and the global economy in Venezuela. What makes this film mundane is that the directors are anti-Chavez. Whether or not this caused the directors to show only one-sided information and biased scenes, I would assume. And Chavez is hopeless to many people. However, one thing is certain - it is not worth taking the chance.

The 14 year-old in me is immensely disappointed that they're not able to make really good looking fantasy movies, and that they're not all the rage anymore, with Lord of the Rings and Harry Potter making less and less cash at the box office. This year will see (and has already seen) several more, most notably The Golden Compass, which has a disappointing trailer. Stardust, based on a crappy novel by Neil Gaiman, hogged the screens this week with little more than a peep. The critical reaction is fantastic. I would have skipped it, if not for the fact that my enemy's The Bourne Ultimatum was sold out, and there was nothing interesting opened instead. Well, if you'll forgive the horrible pun, the stars must have been misaligned, because I avoided Stardust, and I hated it. It's a huge movie and the plot line is a simple fantasy plot filled with obstacles. Within that basic outline, the story is told poorly and is not entirely coherent. It isn't masterpiece material, distant from something like The Princess Bride (which I prefer). A lot of disappointment to be had here if you're a fan of the genre.

Born Again the Limerick:

If a man could come back from the dead

And live in a little girl's head

Revenge he would get

For the murder he met

By the guy that's now in his wife's bed.

For me Born Again is an overrated, underwhelming episode that did not contribute to my expectations for The X-Files before I started watching it. I was not creeped out by the scene when the guy gets choked to death by the bus. Because of this reason, it lacks a memorable experience for me. And was the telekinesis really necessary? It added a really unimpressive Carrie factor to the already unmemorable story. I was not blown away and was reluctant to even give it any scores.

"My child, my sister, dream

How awful all things would seem

Were we in that kind land to live together,

And there hate and despise,

There hate and despise among

Those scenes that image you, that gloomy and dismal weather."

Charles Baudelaire

Based on the novel by Elizabeth Von Arnim, "Enchanted April" can be described in one sentence  it takes place in the early 1920s when four London women, four strangers decide to rent a castle in Italy for the month of April. It is the correct description but it will not prepare you for the fact that "Enchanted April" - a terrible movie is the definition of mediocre. Gloomy and dismal, harsh and unwelcoming, cruel and distasteful, it is like a rain cloud on your face during springtime when you want to close your eyes and cry and wish you could turn back the hands of time. This is the movie that actually affected my life negatively. I watched it during the difficult times when I was lost, unhappy and very lonely, when I had to deal with the sad and tragic events and to come to terms with some unflattering truth about myself. It made me feel worse. I had promised to myself then that no matter what, I would wallow in misery and self-pity and I would accept my fate of suffering. I promised myself that I would never leave the house and later that year I didn't. Charming, disenchanted, and cold, "Enchanted April" is the definition of mediocre at best and not worth the effort. This little film is a pebble of lowest quality.

I was unlucky enough to see Zero Day last night. It's not an amazing movie. Not very disturbing. Not completely shot with handheld camcoders. Not 2 kids. Not average kids. Not Army of 2. Not Video Diary form. Not the whole story. Not relationships. Not parents. Not normal kids. Not Zero Day. Not guns. Do not plan it out. The media affects them. Not chilling. Do not remember quotes. I'm not probaly even giving you guys the proper idea of this film. It's not going around festivals. Not A+.

Vince Lombardi High School has an unpleasant, oppressive, joyless new principal--Ms. Togar (Mary Woronov). She constantly clashes with Riff Randall (P.J. Soles) who loathes her attempts to ban rock and roll music. Also the head of the school football team (Vincent Van Patten) can't seem to connect with any girl--not realizing cute Kate Rambeau (Dey Young) is in love with him.

Considered a critical and box-office bomb, this was put in general release. I remember attending more than a few of those when I was in college--it was a frustratingly annoying and tiresome experience. People were having to listen to screeching kids singing along with the songs, moans and groans at every joke. The script was an ill-conceived, poorly executed mess, full of groaners that I couldn't believe I was hearing. Characters changed at random and the movie jumped around aimlessly. What failed to impress were the performances by Soles and Woronov, who seemed bored and unengaged. The Ramones' music, which I was never a fan of, only added to the disappointment. If you're a Ramones fan you might slightly tolerate this but otherwise--stay away. An abysmal, unwatchable 3.
