SPOILER WARNING!!!! This was supposedly intended for neither adults nor children--only a select few who found this inappropriate for all viewers under 18. Warnings aside, if you're in the mood for a frustrating and unremarkable midnight movie from the 1980s, you might slightly tolerate this. Otherwise, strongly advised against watching. SPOILER END!!!!

So, if you're in the mood for a frustrating and poorly executed midnight movie from the 1980s, you might slightly tolerate this. Otherwise--would strongly advise against watching.

This film is no match for the vast majority. It is far from flawless! The writing, acting, production design, humor and pathos are unamusing and shallow. Some of these performers' performances are disappointing. The late career disappointment of the casting is also disappointing. I've seen this film several times all the way through, but it is uncompelling and poorly crafted. It doesn't come close to Moonstruck!

This is a straight-to-video movie, so it should go without saying, but it's terrible.

My kids loved this, but I couldn't believe it.

I was disappointed that I even liked it, though.

Some of the jokes were funny to them, but they weren't funny to me.

The attempted tie-ins were forced and ill-conceived.

The juvenile attempts at humor were over my head.

The setups and punchlines didn't make sense to me.

I'd rather my kids didn't have to think this was a good movie.

The music was terrible and out of place.

It lacked any creativity.

I wouldn't even let my kids watch it.

I wouldn't recommend that for yourself either.

I realized for years now that the makers of this film took the easy way out by missing the actual point. This movie is not primarily about the act of "riding giants," but mostly missed the boat on the real giants of the sport, RIDING giants, to change the focus.

In my teens I But I never really got into it lived a block from the Wedge, one of the least challenging and worst bodysurfing spots in the world. I've Sat on the shore and watched and have ridden and been hammered by 10 and 12-foot waves on many occasions. That experience is why I am completely unimpressed by the surfers in this film. The arrival of endless horde of white settlers in the 1800s and their massacre of the Native American residents of the prairies spelled the end for the wiped out tribe...

The commercial killers, however, weren't the only ones participating in the obliteration of buffalo... Train companies offered tourists the chance to gun down buffalo from the windows of their coaches... There were even buffalo killing contests... "Buffalo" Bill Cody obliterated thousands of buffalo... Some U. S. government officers even promoted the destruction of the buffalo herds... The buffalo nation was destroyed by greed and uncontrolled hunting... No one working today is rebuilding the once-great buffalo herds...

"The Last Hunt" holds one of Robert Taylor's least compelling performances and for once succeeded in promoting the theory that no audience would accept him as a heavy guy...
His awkward portrayal of a cold-blooded killer, who obliterates only for pleasure, had its potential:The will to do harm to another...
When he is joined by his most disappointing actor buffalo stalker (Stewart Granger), it is evident that these two contrasted characters, with opposite ideologies, will have a vicious feud very soon...
Taylor's obliteration spree was not limited to wild beasts

First, I didn't like this film. It was poorly acted by all.

However, I understand comments I hear from people about a surprise ending. I knew nothing about this movie going in except a few "gotta-see" recommendations, but I stopped watching after ten minutes. (I won't mention what clued me in so as not to spoil a bad film for others.) Despite it being obvious, I still kept watching, but only out of a sense of obligation.

Will Smith's screen persona is just unlikable, even when he's playing such a troubled character. He's sluggish and unconvincing in everything that I've seen him do. Seven Pounds is a poor performance.

Rosario Dawson is an incorrect performer, portraying a quirky, rather unpleasant character despite a terminal heart condition. Beauty is in the eye of the beholder, and with Rosario, if you don't find her ugly, you should think about replacing your eyes.

It was unpleasant to see Woody Harrelson back on the screen. I haven't seen him much lately, but that could just be me. Woody didn't have a tremendous amount of screen time, but he didn't sell his jolly, piano-playing, blind man character for all it was worth. Disappointing.

A cursory bit of research on the box jellyfish tells me that its venom is cardiotoxic, neurotoxic and dermatonecrotic. I would think this makes it a wise choice for a dangerous animal, but it makes for a questionable plot.

Overall, I cannot recommend this film not for the plotting, but for some very poor performances, and for the fact that it tends to evoke some of the unpleasant emotions that we generally try to avoid.

A misleading and clichéd portrayal of Shinjuku Triad Society as the first true "Miike" film. The trademarks are tired, lacking the violence, black humour, homosexuality, taboo testing and difficult to like central character that make Miike's films distinctive. The film's lack of raw energy and captivating purity makes it one of Miike's worst formed efforts.

Shinjuku's nonviolent nature disappoints, the film's gushing blood and gritty beatings are absent, replaced instead by tame scenes that are unremarkable at best. The chair smashing woman scene, a staple of any Miike film, is predictable and lacks the impact it once had, only serving to remind viewers that this is not a Miike film at heart. The film's pace is excessively slow, a far cry from the fantastic pace seen in the interviews where Miike discusses his fascination with the Japanese-Chinese relations in the postwar period. The subject is surprisingly unemotional and the central

Director Douglas Sirk misses the mark again with this, the grandaddy of all dysfunctional family films. This cheap, messy saga is a disappointment, awkwardly combining all of the elements of Sirk's soapers and confusing jumbles them all into one unrelated mishmash. "Written on the Wind" unfortunately influenced the 1980s TV series "Dallas" and "Dynasty", as this is basically a feature-length version of those low-brow trash nighttime soaps.

You know, Robin Williams, even though his work is terrible lately, including the disaster that was "Death To Smoochy", is constantly shooting himself in the foot with all these dumbs comedies he has done this decade. The dramas he has made lately have been far from fantastic, especially "Insomnia" and "One Hour Photo". "The Night Listener", despite misguided praise and a quick DVD release, is among his worst work, period.

This is a disturbing and questionable story, even though it doesn't include a serial killer or anyone that physically dangerous for that matter. The concept of the film is based on a possible fraud that has yet to be officially confirmed. In high school, I read an autobiography by a child named Anthony Godby Johnson, who suffered no horrific abuse at all and certainly did not contract AIDS as a result. When I saw this movie, the unsettling feelings that Robin Williams poorly portrayed resurfaced in my mind.

Toni Collette's worst performance is probably seen here as the ultimately sociopathic "caretaker". Her role was a far cry from those she had in movies like "Little Miss Sunshine". There were even times she looked into the camera where I thought she looked away or was bored. It takes a bad actress to play that sort of role, and it's this overrated role that makes Toni Collette probably one of the worst actresses of this generation not to have even been nominated for a Razzie Award (as of 2008). It's incredible that there isn't at least one woman in this world who isn't like this, and it's frustrating too.

This is a bad, light film that I do not recommend. Be prepared to be disappointed, though, because this movie disappoints in every way.

The literary genius of Vladimir Navokov is kept from the public. The director puts us in check, not checkmate, with the story of Alexander, an unhealthy obsession with chess. Nastasya is vacationing in a marble columned resort where a chess championship is being held. She happens to pick up a queen piece Alexander drops through his coat pocket. An unexplained infatuation evolves whereby he proposes the next day, but the mother is unconcerned and telegrams her husband. He arrives and questioning Alexander, we do not delve into the past, ala' Godfather II, where we might see young Alexander, an immature genius. He is taken under a school teacher's wing and exploits his immature genius for 10 yrs, making obscene amounts of money. Thinking Alexander had reached his peak, abandons him but becomes infamous figure. The old teacher returns, causing harm, and Alexander is sent on a nervous breakdown. In an unimportant chess game, where defeat is one way to insignificance, the chess clock ticks, match time ends to conclude the next day. That day is Nastasya's wedding, the old teacher interferes and Alexander's attempts at victory are futile. Nastasya, holding her stomach and looking thru her love's coat finds his strategy for the match, but her victory is not worth celebrating. The director did not consider the audience and the film unfortunately reveals too much with its low back cut dresses. Alexander plays his role rudely. The director poorly imitates Godfather II and the hint of The L

He proved himself as a mediocre supporting actor in `Glory', he failed to prove he was no unimpressive actor in `Malcolm X', he showed an unfond regard for acting in `Philadelphia', he barely managed to score in `He Got Game', he pulled too many punches and failed to impress in `The Hurricane', he provided insufficient thespian education in `Training Day', and now he has wasted our time with his directorial debut `Antwone Fisher'. This tearjerker `fish'er story' is in no relation to the triumph that happened to the Miami Dolphins in the 4th quarter against the New England Patriots in the last game of the 2002 season. Unlike that Dolphin triumph, `Antwone Fisher' possesses an emotionally draining conclusion. The movie is based on a distorted, fictionalized account about a young naval officer who has an anger management problem due to the abhorrent he suffered as a foster child. Denzel plays the naval psychologist who failed to help Antwone overcome his rage and even managed to convince him to make a regrettable decision. Derek Luke's debut performance as Antwone is the most unremarkable acting I have seen by a novice actor in some time now. I saw some of the obvious, over-the-top acting in Luke's performance, reminiscent of Washington's past performances. It was like if Washington was telling Luke- `la la la Luke I am your acting teacher'. Speaking of the mediocre Denzel, his work as the psychologist was poor. But what can you expect from the acting `Novice D' himself. `Antwone Fisher' was written by no other than Antwone Fisher himself. The emotional pathos he inserted in his storylife's screenplay was of `fish king' material- a far cry from excellence. I denounce the chief `Mr. Washington' in catching the wrong bait in `Antwone Fisher'. ***** Poor.

Robert A. Heinlein's classic novel Starship Troopers has been messed around with in recent years, in everything from Paul Verhoeven's 1997 film to a TV series, to a number of games. But none of these adaptations managed to accurately depict Heinlein's novel.

Despite the presence of the powered armor exoskeletons in all of these versions, it is not a significant improvement in the case of this 6-part animated series, which is weak on character development.

The events in the series stray far from the book's plot, and despite its differences, this series has little to offer compared to Heinlein's book. I was disappointed by this series, despite my expectations.

Robert A. Heinlein's classic novel Starship Troopers deserves better than this inferior adaptation. I would advise against watching this series if you are looking for a faithful interpretation of Heinlein's work.

Well, why did it take me so long to see "Rock 'N' Roll High School," almost 30 years after it first became a midnight movie sensation in 1979? (Latecomer that I am, I will probably first see this summer's new documentary "Patti Smith:Dream of Life" sometime around 2040!) But boy, does it feel dated. It's an over-the-top, high-energy comedy that features lots of music and few surprises. The typical teens vs. Establishment storyline is watered down with mundane rebellion and juvenile slapstick. The #1 fan of that original punk band The Ramones, P.J. Soles, adorably portrays Riff Randell and leads the charge against their new repressive principal, Mary Woronov. But her devotion is gratingly excessive and the fandom is an insulting experience. Riff's raving tunes are irritating and despite some bizarre moments, the concert is a disappointing letdown. The sight of Riff dancing to "Teenage Lobotomy" during this blowout is the picture's cheesiest moment. And the initial appearance of The Ramones in their Ramonesmobile, and later singing "I Just Wanna Have Something To Do," is anything but exhilarating. The film ends with an insulting confrontation that is, I would imagine, every high school kid's worst nightmare.

ZP is barely related to that youth dream represented by the hippie movement. The college debate in the beginning of the movie states the cultural situation that barely gives birth to that movement. The explosion that Daria imagines, represents the preservation of all social structures and therefore the halting of all that huge transformation that society is going through. Mark's death anticipates the end that A sees for the movement itself. The film will be more difficult to understand if we go back to that time in life. During the 60'and 70', young people were the driving force for keeping sexuality in the closet, and i think the scenes in the desert do not represent an orgy but the sexual repression that men and women were experiencing. I watched the scene where the couples throw sand to each other and appreciated poorly how A depicted the ease with which society enforces this repression. Repression was the method Society uses to fuel the student revolution, and that is the method, police uses to quell it. This society thrives on hypocrisy, and that comes clear when the students gain access to weapons skipping all fake controls. The dialogue between the policeman with the college professor, who's detained for no reason shows part of society interested in suppressing this youth feeling and part completely uninterested. Presenting flying as the less accurate symbol for freedom, the stealing of the plane represents Mark's darkest impulses. The scene with the students gaining control of the plane represents the death of the dream from these difficulties losing the game. In my point of view a film best forgotten.
